site_title: A smoother ride, with Grab for Work
summary: Grab has launched Grab for Work, a free transport expense management platform for corporates in South-east Asia. The service allows companies to track and analyze employee travel, set transportation policies, and manage transport spending. With Grab for Work, employees can automatically submit business ride receipts, and administrators can view comprehensive trip information. The service is fully integrated with Concur and SAP, and has been used by over 150 companies since its May launch.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax Media warns of US$759m writedown citing tough market
summary: Australian newspaper publisher Fairfax Media is warning of a US$759m writedown due to "market realities" in the tough media industry. The company expects to make impairment charges totaling A$989m when reporting full-year earnings on August 10. This follows a move to separate its real estate advertising unit, Domain Group, from the rest of the business. The news comes as the company adjusts to declining advertising revenue and an exodus of readers to online alternatives.

site_title: NTUC Income, IIPL launch insurtech accelerator programme
summary: NTUC Income and Infocomm Investments Private Ltd (IIPL) have launched an insurtech accelerator programme, "Income Future Starter, Powered by TAG.PASS", to foster business innovation in the insurance sector. This partnership is believed to be the first between an insurer in Singapore and IIPL. The programme aims to drive innovation and growth in the insurtech industry, marking a significant step in the sector's growing prominence.

images.alt_text: On Monday, NTUC Income unveiled "Income Future Starter, Powered by TAG.PASS", an accelerator programme to foster business innovation in the insurance sector.

site_title: Bears crowd Ezra as Swiber's woes signal oil industry risks
summary: Bears drive up short interest in Ezra Holdings Ltd, the most-shorted stock in Singapore, amid concerns over the financial health of companies in the oil industry. Following Swiber Holdings Ltd's collapse, Ezra's shares plummeted to their lowest price since February, and the company is trying to strengthen its capital structure by raising US$100 million in new stock and extending loan terms. Analysts warn of a domino effect in the industry, citing high leverage and plummeting charter rates for vessel owners.

site_title: Seoul: Won closes at more than 1-year high on weak US growth data
summary: The South Korean won reached its highest level in over a year, closing at 1,108.0 to the dollar, driven by weak US second-quarter economic growth data. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.7% to 2,029.61, with foreign investors buying 309.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The won's gain marked its strongest level since June 23, 2015.

site_title: SR Nathan in critical condition after stroke
summary: Former Singapore President SR Nathan, 92, is in critical condition after suffering a stroke. He was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit at the Singapore General Hospital, with President Tony Tan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressing sadness and well wishes. Several cabinet ministers, ex-colleagues, and friends, including Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean and former senior minister Zainul Abidin Rasheed, visited him. Nathan, Singapore's longest-serving president, previously suffered a stroke in April and was discharged after nearly three weeks.

site_title: Oil resumes decline toward US$40 as US drilling gains amid glut
summary: US oil producers increased drilling for a fifth week, boosting the number of rigs by 3, amid a glut of crude and fuel supplies. Oil prices declined toward $40 a barrel, with West Texas Intermediate falling to $41.22 a barrel. The price recovery falters after almost doubling from a 12-year low in February. Producers, including BP and Royal Dutch Shell, reported sharp declines in second-quarter earnings due to lower energy prices. A weakening dollar bolstered investor appetite for commodities, but concerns about oversupply persist.

site_title: South Korea's July exports show biggest decline in 3 months, worse than expected
summary: South Korea's July exports fell 10.2% to $41.05 billion, the largest decline in three months, surpassing expectations. The trade surplus also fell to $7.8 billion from $11.5 billion in June. This decline puts a damper on the country's efforts to escape low growth.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports in July fell at the fastest pace in three months, preliminary government data showed on Monday, far worse than expectations and putting a damper on the country's efforts to escape low growth.

site_title: Thousands of Maryland homes certified as lead-free may not be
summary: The State Department of the Environment in Maryland is contacting approximately 2,000 homeowners about 2,000 lead-free certified homes to retest properties due to potential contamination. Lead-paint exposure poses a danger to young children, prompting the retesting. The retesting is a precautionary measure to ensure the safety of residents, especially in areas where lead-paint was commonly used in the past.

site_title: Delphi Automotive to launch test of self-driving taxis
summary: Delphi Automotive plans to launch a test fleet of automated taxis in Singapore next year, in partnership with the Singapore Land Transport Authority. The project aims to reduce cab ride costs from $3 to $0.90 per 1.6km, making automated driving commercially viable. Initially, the cars will have human drivers ready to take over if the piloting systems fail, but by 2019 or 2020, drivers will be removed. The company plans to expand the project to North America and Europe, and launch a regularly operating automated cab service by 2022.

images.alt_text: Delphi Automotive will launch a small test fleet of automated taxis in Singapore next year, aiming to ferry passengers around a city district in one of the first real-world tests of automated rides on demand, the company said on Monday.

site_title: Zika will not be issue at Olympics: Rio health official
summary: Rio de Janeiro's health secretary, Daniel Soranz, stated that the risk of Zika virus infections at the upcoming Olympics is low and has been overcome. Cases of Zika have significantly decreased in recent months due to dry and cooler weather, making it an unlikely issue for the Games. The health official reassured travelers that Zika should not deter them from attending, as the incidence of the virus is rare in the city. US government epidemiologists also estimated that the Olympics presented tiny risks of propagating the epidemic.

images.alt_text: The risk of Zika virus infections at the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro is low and has been overcome, health officials in Brazil said on Sunday, five days before South America's first Games are due to begin.

site_title: Jack Ma takes on murky Chinese charities in blockchain foray
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Financial is using blockchain technology to improve transparency in the country's philanthropic organizations. The company has launched a tamper-proof ledger to record donations made by its 400 million users, allowing donors to track transaction histories and verify how their funds are used. This initiative aims to restore trust in the sector, which has been plagued by scandals and mismanagement, and follows Ant Financial's experimentation with blockchain technology in other areas, including financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma wants to pry the lid off China's opaque charities.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Monday, rising 8.64 points or 0.30% to 2,877.33. The market is expected to be weighed down by Swiber's default on a coupon payment. DBS, SPH, and SIA were among top gainers, with 81.6 million shares changing hands.

site_title: China economic woes, ecology fears hit reclaimed city off S'pore
summary: A $42 billion eco-city, Forest City, is being developed off the coast of Malaysia near Singapore, promising luxury living and jobs. However, concerns arise due to China's economic woes, environmental catastrophe, and potential ecological damage to the area's marine life. Despite pre-selling 500 units, analysts question the project's long-term sales targets, citing risks from aggressive land acquisitions and the potential for negative environmental impact. The project's developers claim to be following guidelines to minimize environmental harm, but environmentalists warn of a "profound change" to the area's ecology.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges up as yen's surge slows, financials gain
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 0.4% to 16,635.77 points, erasing earlier losses, as the yen's surge slowed. Financials led the way, with the banking subindex climbing 3.3%, boosted by the Bank of Japan's decision not to charge more interest to institutions for parking excess reserves. The broader Topix dipped 0.1% to 1,321.83.

site_title: Fonterra holds forecast payout for current season steady
summary: Fonterra Co-operative Group has held its forecast payout for the 2016-17 season steady at NZ$4.25 per kg of milk solids, citing global uncertainty and a high New Zealand dollar exchange rate as factors. The payout reflects the challenging season for farmers, according to Chairman John Wilson. Fonterra also announced a forecast earnings per share range for the 2017 financial year of 50 to 60 New Zealand cents.

images.alt_text: Global dairy giant Fonterra Co-operative Group, Monday held its forecast payout for the current season steady amid continuing global uncertainty.

site_title: Slain soldier's father calls Trump a 'black soul'
summary: Donald Trump faced intense criticism after a speech by Khizr Khan, the father of a slain Muslim American soldier, who called Trump a "black soul" unfit for US leadership. Khan accused Trump of lacking empathy and moral compass. Trump defended himself, claiming he had made sacrifices, but Khan shot back, saying Trump's words were "void of decency" and "shameful." Republican leaders, including Mitch McConnell and Paul Ryan, distanced themselves from Trump's divisive policies. The exchange overshadowed policy debates, with Hillary Clinton criticizing Trump's treatment of the Khans and Trump responding defiantly.

site_title: Ringgit leads gains in Asian currencies as oil boosts sentiment
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led gains in Asian currencies as oil prices surged over 2% due to improved growth prospects for the region's major crude exporter. The ringgit rose 0.8% to its strongest level since July 21, following a three-day decline. The currency's appreciation was driven by a firmer opening in crude oil prices and a decline in US interest rate expectations, with a 36% chance of a rate hike this year down from 45% earlier. Malaysian bonds also rose, with yields dropping one and four basis points for the five and 10-year periods, respectively.

site_title: Japan set to take synchronised monetary, fiscal policies to new levels: economists
summary: Japan is set to announce a 28 trillion yen fiscal stimulus package, combining monetary and fiscal policies to boost the economy. The government aims to "let the government do the spending while the central bank pays the bill," as consumers and businesses have failed to respond to previous efforts. Economists say this move is necessary to address the limits of monetary policy, which has "liquefied banks and supported asset inflation" without reaching consumers. The combined policies are expected to take Japan's approach to macroeconomic policy to new levels, addressing the problems exposed by the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: China factory activity unexpectedly dips in July
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity unexpectedly shrank in July, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) easing to 49.9, below the 50-point mark. This follows a three-month expansion and reinforces concerns about the economy's momentum. Industrial profits rose, but factory output and new orders fell. Overseas demand remains weak, and job losses are expected to rise as the government cuts excess capacity. The services sector, however, expanded at a faster pace, with construction and financial services also showing growth.

site_title: Funding Societies sees overheating in crowdfunding
summary: Singapore's crowdfunding platform Funding Societies warns of "negative competition" ahead as regulations loosen. Co-founder Kelvin Teo fears market opacity and loan default window-dressing, which increases risk for investors. Despite this, the platform remains optimistic about regulations and expects a gradual scaling down of the market, with consolidation likely in the next 12 months. Funding Societies has disclosed a 1.76% default rate and aims to keep it below 3% this year. The platform's credit team reviews loans through pre-filters and borrower interviews, resulting in a 25% final approval rate.

site_title: SATS expands kitchen with $18m new production line
summary: SATS, Asia's leading food solutions provider, is investing $18 million in a new production line to mechanize up to 50% of kitchen operations. The expanded 60,000 sqm Inflight Catering Centre 2 will increase production capacity to 115,000 meals per day, enhancing quality and consistency. The new line features automated dispensers and robotic wok paddles, expected to speed up food production. The facility is set to be completed by Q2 2017, underlining SATS' commitment to the growth of Singapore's aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Update: Swiber defaults on upcoming coupon payment due on Aug 2, 2016
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-based oil and gas contractor, has defaulted on its upcoming coupon payment due on August 2, 2016, for its S$150 million 6.50% certificates. The company has withdrawn its winding-up application and will instead be placed under judicial management. This decision comes after receiving an additional US$24.6 million from claimants, increasing the total to about US$50.5 million. DBS Group and United Overseas Bank, among others, have expressed confidence in recovering their exposure to the company.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Seoul: Won surges to 13-month high, stocks up on weak US economic data
summary: The South Korean won surged to a 13-month high against the dollar after the release of weaker-than-expected US GDP data, tempering expectations for a US interest hike. The won rose 0.7% to 1,112.6, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also increased 0.7% to 2,029.87 points, its highest intraday level since June 9. The stronger currency and stock market gains were attributed to the weak US economic data, which reduced the likelihood of a US interest rate hike in the coming months.

site_title: Australia home price growth slows in July: CoreLogic
summary: Australia's home prices rose 0.8% in July, marking a seventh consecutive month of growth, despite slowing annual growth to 6.1%. This is down from 8.3% in June and 11% last year. Record-low mortgage rates in Sydney and Melbourne continue to drive demand, but prices are not yet reaching pre-2017 levels.

site_title: China said to consider mergers to create two state steel giants
summary: China is considering a merger of its two largest steel producers, Shanghai Baosteel Group and Wuhan Iron & Steel Group, to form Southern China Steel Group, and Shougang Group and Hebei Iron & Steel Group to form Northern China Steel Group. The goal is to reduce excess capacity and enhance competitiveness, helping China rival global steel giants like ArcelorMittal. The move is part of China's efforts to overhaul its inefficient state-run steel sector and bolster its economy, which is growing at its slowest in decades.

site_title: Macau gambling revenue slump continues, drops for 26th straight month in July
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 4.5% in July, marking a 26th consecutive month of decline, amid a protracted anti-corruption campaign by Beijing. The territory's revenue fell to 17.8 billion patacas (S$2.9 billion), surpassing analysts' expectations of a 4-8% drop. Macau's reliance on gambling, accounting for over 80% of government tax revenues, remains under pressure.

site_title: Bangladesh seeks to reopen Philippine inquiry into stolen funds
summary: Bangladesh is seeking to reopen an investigation into the disappearance of $81 million of its reserves via the Philippine banking system and casinos. The probe was halted by Philippine elections in May, but Bangladesh's ambassador plans to meet with Philippine lawmakers to revive it. The investigation will focus on monitoring the casino industry for money laundering and relaxing bank deposit secrecy rules. Bangladesh officials are optimistic that all the stolen funds will be recovered.

site_title: Iraqi Airways plane makes emergency landing in Kuwait
summary: An Iraqi Airways plane carrying 230 passengers made an emergency landing in Kuwait after one of its engines failed. The Boeing 767 was headed to New Delhi. The plane landed safely, and the airline plans to send an Airbus A321 to resume the passengers' trip.

site_title: US police seek man in Texas shooting that killed one
summary: US police are seeking Endicott McCray, a 24-year-old black man, in connection with a Texas shooting that killed one woman and wounded four others. The incident occurred in downtown Austin, where police found a chaotic scene with multiple victims. Authorities have not named the victims, but a woman in her 20s was confirmed dead. The shooter's motive and connection to the victims are unclear. The incident comes amid heightened tensions following a rash of shootings, including a deadly attack on police in Dallas on July 7.

site_title: Asia: Shares gain, won advances as Fed seen on hold; Topix slips
summary: Asian shares rose, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index up 0.7% as investors reduced bets on US interest-rate increases. The South Korean won rallied to a one-year high, while the yen retreated 0.6% after its strongest weekly gain since the UK's Brexit vote. The won's rise was attributed to a decrease in bets on US rate hikes, following weaker-than-expected US GDP data. Global equities have rallied in July to their best month since March on prospects of central bank stimulus.

site_title: Fallout from Swiber, O&M sector to continue
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 1.7% for the year, marking the second time in seven months it has dipped below its starting level, due to volatility in oil prices, central bank monetary support, and the probability of a US interest rate hike. The O&M sector, including Swiber, is expected to continue its fallout, with banks and other companies likely to sustain hits. Short sellers are expected to cover their positions, introducing stability, and the market will focus on the sector's impact ahead of the week.

site_title: US$60 is the new US$50 for oil drillers in US waiting for rebound
summary: US oil drillers are raising the bar for resuming drilling, now requiring crude prices to reach $60 or better to increase production. Industry leaders, such as Anadarko Petroleum Corp's CEO and Hess Corp, are waiting for sustained prices at this level before adding rigs. The move is driven by a desire to avoid the "boom-bust" scenario and to increase capital spending. As prices rise, service-cost inflation is expected to increase, putting pressure on explorers starting back up, and making it necessary for customers to pay $60 or higher.

site_title: Public Transport Council makes raft of recommendations to improve public transport
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) released recommendations to improve public transport in Singapore, focusing on making buses and trains more accessible for families, seniors, and wheelchair users. The recommendations include designing buses to encourage commuters to move to the back and reducing escalator speeds at train stations to make it safer for seniors. These changes were distilled from a six-month public consultation that began earlier this year. The PTC aims to make public transport more inclusive and user-friendly.

site_title: Robots are actually helping to create more jobs
summary: Researchers from Utrecht University and Germany's ZEW Center found that while robots replaced some human jobs in the European Union between 1999 and 2010, the increased demand for goods created more positions in other parts of the economy. A study estimated that 9.6 million jobs were lost due to technical innovations, but 8.7 million were added due to increased product demand. The "multiplier effect" of lower prices led to further labor demand growth, with estimates suggesting 11.6 million jobs were created, or 1.9 million jobs added at the lower bound.

site_title: Hong Kong housing price rebound may be short-lived, analysts say
summary: Hong Kong's secondary property prices rose 1.6% in the second quarter, marking a pause in a correction that analysts predict may be short-lived due to higher supply and weaker demand. Home prices have fallen 11% from a peak in September, and sales have tumbled amid economic uncertainty. Analysts forecast that prices will need to drop 25-35% from last year's peak before the market stabilizes, with some predicting prices will fall another 3-7% this year.

site_title: China consortium to buy Caesars unit
summary: A Chinese consortium led by Alibaba Group's Jack Ma has agreed to acquire Caesars Interactive Entertainment's online games unit, Playtika, for $4.4 billion in cash. The deal will be a boon to Caesars' affiliated companies, Caesars Acquisition Co and Caesars Entertainment Corp, as they navigate a complex merger and Caesars' $18 billion bankruptcy. Playtika will operate independently, with its headquarters remaining in Israel. The acquisition is part of China's growing interest in expanding its online gaming market.

site_title: Asian century is here to stay: Kishore Mahbubani
summary: Singaporean public policy expert Kishore Mahbubani asserts that the Asian century is here to stay, citing the economic rise of China, India, and Indonesia. According to a PwC report, China's economy is expected to surpass the US by 2030, with India potentially joining as the second-largest economy. However, tensions in the South China Sea pose a risk, but Mahbubani believes a major conflict is unlikely due to China's national interest in avoiding war. Mahbubani also emphasizes the need for Singapore to become a global city, requiring bold vision and ambition to overcome its current challenges.

images.alt_text: The Asian century is nigh upon us, with the inexorable march of economic powerhouses such as China, India - and to a smaller but no less significant extent, Indonesia - well underway, public policy mandarin Kishore Mahbubani said on Saturday.

site_title: China legalises ride-sharing services
summary: China has legalized ride-sharing services, clearing the way for US-based Uber and local rival Didi Chuxing to operate in the country. The new regulations, announced by Vice-Minister for Transport Liu Xiaoming, provide a national license for ride-sharing apps and allow private cars to operate until they reach 600,000km, addressing concerns of part-time drivers. Didi Chuxing hailed the move as a "milestone," while Uber welcomed the regulations, saying they "send a clear message of support for ride-sharing and the benefits it offers."

images.alt_text: A mascot of Didi Chuxing, China's local rival to Uber. It says it will make an earnest effort to comply with the new ride-sharing rules.

site_title: Fed's Dudley urges caution on rate hikes, cites risks to US
summary: Federal Reserve President William Dudley urged caution on interest rate hikes due to lingering risks to the US economy, citing uncertainty around the UK's Brexit vote, a strong dollar, and global economic developments. He suggested the central bank may stand pat on rates until December, which would mark one year since the last rate hike. Dudley also hinted that the US economy may outperform expectations, easing financial conditions or fading international risks, making further monetary policy tightening premature.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.62% in the first few minutes of trade on Monday, driven by reduced chances of a US interest rate hike this year following below-par US growth data. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 22,027.65, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.25%.

site_title: New Malaysia security law debuts as PM fights critics
summary: Malaysia's new National Security Council Act came into force on Monday, giving the government power to declare virtual martial law in areas deemed under "security threat." Critics say the legislation is "draconian" and threatens democracy, potentially used against opponents of Prime Minister Najib Razak, who has faced calls to resign due to a corruption scandal. The law was pushed through parliament in December by Najib's government.

site_title: Hot stock: Sino Grandness falls 11%, prompts SGX query
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry shares plummeted 11% on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after opening at 58.5 Singapore cents, falling to 42 cents. The unusual price movements prompted an open query from the SGX at 10.14am, asking if the company was aware of the reasons. Sino Grandness has yet to respond.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC leads heavyweights higher
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.8% on Monday to 9,056.85, driven by TSMC's 2.3% gain, the world's top contract chip maker. The electronics subindex jumped 1.1% and the financials subindex gained 0.5%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.776 per US dollar.

site_title: Staff physically present but mentally absent in over half of Singapore firms: survey
summary: A survey of 100 Singapore chief financial officers and finance directors found that over half of companies have staff who are physically present but mentally absent, a phenomenon known as "inner resignation." This was observed in 57% of firms, with large and medium-sized companies more likely to experience it. Employers can prevent inner resignation by promoting employee appreciation, encouraging open communication, and ensuring job fit. Employees also need to take responsibility for their satisfaction and address any issues with their employer.

site_title: Taiwan apologises to indigenous people for first time
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen has formally apologized to the country's indigenous people for centuries of suffering, marking the first time a Taiwanese leader has done so. Tsai, who has aboriginal blood, will lead a committee to investigate past injustices and ease tensions with the native community. The apology comes amid protests by indigenous people over hunting rights and demands for concrete actions from the government. The indigenous community makes up about 2% of Taiwan's population and faces marginalization, with lower wages and higher unemployment rates.

images.alt_text: President Tsai Ing-wen formally apologised to Taiwan's indigenous people for their centuries of suffering on Monday, the country's first ever leader to do so.

site_title: South Korea July house price growth slows to over 1-yr low: Kookmin Bank
summary: South Korea's house prices in July rose 0.13% from the previous month and 2.35% from a year earlier, the slowest annual pace in over a year, according to Kookmin Bank. This marks the lowest annual growth since a 2.32% gain in March last year.

site_title: China: Stocks fall to one-month low on tighter regulation, new IPOs
summary: China's stocks fell to a near one-month low, with the CSI300 index dropping 0.8% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.9%. The market weakness was attributed to tighter regulation and a fresh wave of initial public offerings (IPOs), which exacerbated investor sentiment. Despite this, a private business survey showed China's manufacturing activity expanded for the first time in 17 months in July.

site_title: Hilton extends its hospitality to youth, the environment, and the community
summary: Hilton Worldwide, a hospitality company, has reaffirmed its commitment to corporate responsibility, joining the Company of Good initiative, a group of 60 founding members that prioritizes giving back to the community. The company, which has over 4,500 properties, focuses on three key areas: youth opportunity, environmental stewardship, and community resiliency. Hilton has implemented various initiatives, such as the Careers@ HiltonLive program, which aims to connect young people to job opportunities, and a partnership with Room to Read to support girls' education. The company has also made significant strides in environmental sustainability, saving $550 million through its in-house energy management system.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.52 points to 1657.18 on Monday, with volume reaching 58.8 million lots worth RM11.7 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 50, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: China new home prices rise faster in July
summary: China's new home prices rose 1.63% month-over-month in June to 12,009 yuan (S$2,421.40) per square meter, faster than the previous month's 1.32% increase. This acceleration was attributed to government policies aimed at stabilizing prices, including reduced downpayment requirements and incentives for migrant workers. Year-on-year, new home prices increased 12.39%, with the government vowing to take "specialized" measures to address regional divergences. The accelerating price rises come amid China's economic growth concerns, including a sluggish manufacturing sector and mounting debt.

site_title: Hopes new wing part could reveal MH370 clues: Australia
summary: Australian MH370 search authorities are hopeful a wing part found in Tanzania will shed light on the crash, amid a lack of public information on debris from last year's discovery. The 2-meter-long wing part, known as a flaperon, may suggest the plane was in a deployed state, indicating someone was at the controls. This could support the "rogue pilot" theory. The search area may be further north, and the Australian, Malaysian, and Chinese governments agree to end the search in December unless new information emerges.

site_title: Gunman in Austin, Texas, kills one woman, wounds 3
summary: A gunman in Austin, Texas, killed one woman and seriously wounded three others in a shooting incident early Sunday. The unidentified gunman opened fire at about 2:15am in the downtown area, fleeing the scene. The motive for the attack is unclear. The shooter is believed to be in his 20s, and police are seeking public help in identifying him. The incident occurred just minutes after bars closed, and it is not believed to be related to a separate shooting that occurred several blocks away, where a man was subdued by bystanders.

site_title: Weak refining profits add to woes at Exxon and Chevron
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported disappointing second-quarter results, with ExxonMobil's net income plummeting 60% to $1.7 billion and Chevron suffering a $1.5 billion loss. Low oil prices and a glut of refined products, including petrol, have forced the companies to adjust to a lower oil price world, resulting in declining refining profits. Analysts predict further declines in refining margins and a potential "peak bad" scenario for the industry, with some companies considering capacity cuts and staff layoffs.

site_title: Vallianz has been cutting dependence on Swiber as key source of revenue
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a US$1.2 billion order book, primarily consisting of long-term charter contracts with third-party customers in the Middle East, reducing its dependence on Swiber Holdings. As of Q1 2016, 80% of Vallianz's revenue came from third-party companies, down from 20% from Swiber-related companies. The company has trade receivables and payables of US$61.9 million and US$58.7 million from Swiber entities, respectively. Vallianz is working with legal advisors to evaluate the impact of Swiber's developments, which include a winding-up application and subsequent judicial management.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Didi to buy Uber China operations in deal valuing combined firm at US$35b: media
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's dominant ride-hailing firm, is set to buy Uber's China operations in a deal valued at $35 billion, according to reports. The combined company would be valued at $35 billion, with investors in Uber China receiving a 20% stake. The deal would end competition between the two firms, following China's recent guidelines for the industry. The acquisition, potentially announced as early as Monday, would come after Didi was created last year from the merger of two companies backed by Alibaba and Tencent.

site_title: Tesla, SolarCity set to announce merger on Monday: sources
summary: Tesla Motors Inc and SolarCity Corp are set to announce a potential merger, combining the clean energy car maker with the solar panel installer. The deal is part of billionaire Elon Musk's master plan, aiming to offer consumers a single source of hardware for a low-carbon lifestyle. A merger agreement was uncertain due to SolarCity's special committee review, but sources indicate a possible announcement as early as Monday.

site_title: Toyota trails Volkswagen in H1 global car sales
summary: Toyota trailed Volkswagen in global car sales for the first half of 2016, with 4.99 million vehicles sold compared to VW's 5.12 million. The Japanese company's North American sales fell, and it was also hit by factory stoppages in Japan due to earthquakes. Toyota warned of a decline in annual net profit due to a stronger yen and slowing Chinese growth. Volkswagen regained the top spot it briefly lost to Toyota in 2015.

site_title: Australia's ASX appoints new chief after high profile resignation
summary: Australia's ASX Ltd appointed Dominic Stevens as its new CEO, following the resignation of Elmer Funke Kupper amid corruption allegations. Stevens, former CEO of Challenger Group, takes the role immediately. His appointment ends the ASX's search for a replacement after Funke Kupper's abrupt resignation in March. The move comes as police investigate bribery allegations at Tabcorp Holdings Ltd, which Funke Kupper previously headed. Stevens brings experience in the financial services industry, having led Challenger Group from 2008 to 2012.

site_title: Nintendo shares drop as Pokemon Go slips in Japan rankings
summary: Nintendo Co shares dropped 6.5% in Japan after Pokémon Go fell from the top of app download charts in Japan, according to researcher App Annie. The game dropped to third place among highest-grossing apps for Apple devices. Nintendo shares touched a low of 20,100 yen before recovering to 20,765 yen. This decline follows the company's biggest decline in over two decades.

site_title: Uber to invest US$500 million in global mapping project
summary: Uber is investing US$500 million in a global mapping project to reduce its dependence on Google Maps and prepare for driverless cars. The company, which has ramped up spending in new technologies, has already put mapping cars on the road in the US and Mexico. Uber executive Brian McClendon, formerly the head of Google Maps, said the company is "doubling down" on its investments in mapping, following new investments earlier this year. The move aims to pave the way for the development of driverless cars.

site_title: Singapore launches unit to fight money laundering
summary: Singapore has launched a unit to combat money laundering, strengthening its financial hub's safeguards against illicit fund flows. The move was prompted by a scandal involving Malaysia's state fund 1MDB and banks operating in Singapore. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) created the special unit to give a centralized focus on combating money laundering, despite plans for the unit pre-dating the scandal. This move aims to enhance the country's anti-money laundering efforts.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Monday formally launched a unit to fight money laundering, strengthening the financial hub's safeguards against illicit fund flows.

site_title: Mitsubishi minicar sales continue to fall, but decline slows
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp reported a 16.9% decline in July minicar sales, with 3,712 vehicles sold, compared to 4,469 the previous year. The drop was smaller than the prior two months, as the automaker resumed sales of two models suspended due to a mileage scandal. Nissan's minicar sales also fell 33.4% in July, but the decline was smaller than the 75% drop in May and June. Suzuki Motor Co reported an 11.2% fall in mini vehicle sales in July.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at near 1-year high as interest rate decision looms
summary: Australian shares rose to a near one-year high on Monday, driven by speculation of a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 25 points, or 0.45%, to 5,587.4, as investors sought equities amid record-low bond yields. A rate cut of 25 basis points is expected, with economists predicting a new low of 1.5%.

site_title: Moody's says New Zealand banking system stable despite dairy sector distress
summary: Moody's Investors Service has maintained a stable outlook on New Zealand's banking system, despite weakness in the dairy sector and higher household leverage. The banks' financial profiles are expected to remain healthy over the next 12-18 months, with low dairy prices and rising leverage representing key risks. However, housing loans are expected to be supported by low interest rates and stable employment conditions, containing any potential deterioration in asset quality. Moody's rates eight of New Zealand's 15 locally incorporated banks, covering 89% of total system loans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after BoJ underwhelms
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, despite a solid lead from Wall Street, due to the Bank of Japan's underwhelming tweaks to its stimulus program. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.93% and the Topix index lost 1.09%. This move follows investors' disappointment with the BoJ's lack of aggressive measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Tokyo Gas in talks with European firms to swap US LNG cargoes
summary: Tokyo Gas, Japan's second-largest LNG buyer, is in talks with European companies to swap US LNG cargoes with those in Asia to reduce shipping times and costs. The utility aims to diversify its operations and supply options amid uncertainty over supply projects, including the delayed Ichthys project and Japan's planned gas market liberalization. By swapping cargoes, Tokyo Gas can reduce its shipping times from 20 days to 10 days and increase flexibility in its supply chain. The company seeks to capitalize on the shift in LNG markets towards a more flexible business form.

site_title: Thai consumer prices rise for 4th month in July
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer prices rose for the fourth consecutive month in July, driven by higher food and cigarette prices. The 0.1% increase was slightly below forecast. Annual core inflation, excluding raw food and energy prices, was 0.76%. The Bank of Thailand has kept its interest rate unchanged at 1.50% due to low inflation, which is attributed to government price controls, subsidies, and sluggish consumption. The central bank is set to review monetary policy on August 3, with most economists expecting no change.

site_title: Under Armour founder pitches US$5.5b plan for Baltimore
summary: Under Armour founder Kevin Plank has proposed a US$5.5 billion development project in Baltimore, comprising 45 city blocks and over two miles of riverfront. The project, one of the largest in the US, aims to deliver a new Under Armour headquarters, tech and manufacturing businesses, and 40 acres of parks. However, residents are wary of the project, citing racial and economic tensions in the city, and concerns that the development may widen the gap between the haves and have-nots. Plank has requested US$535 million in public funding, with the balance coming from state and federal sources, and has promised to create 25,000 jobs and yield hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue.

site_title: India to airlift workers facing 'food crisis' in Saudi Arabia
summary: India plans to airlift over 10,000 Indian workers facing a "food crisis" in Saudi Arabia due to economic hardships caused by low oil prices. The workers, who have been laid off from their jobs, are struggling to afford meals and have no way of returning home. Indian Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj will send a government minister to Saudi Arabia to try to bring back the workers, with a focus on Kuwait, where the situation is "manageable."

site_title: US stocks end week on flat note
summary: US stocks ended the week flat, with fears about central bank policy and economic growth offsetting better-than-expected earnings. The US economy grew 1.2% in the second quarter, but corporations' reluctance to spend on capital may impact earnings reports. The Federal Reserve hinted at a possible rate hike, but its statement was met with a muted reaction, and a strong jobs report on Friday could jolt the market. The US dollar is expected to rise against the euro and sterling if the jobs report is solid.

site_title: Hamilton extends lead over Rosberg with German GP win
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured a dominant victory in the German Formula One Grand Prix, extending his lead over teammate Nico Rosberg in the world championship standings. Hamilton led from pole position, crossing the finish line 6.9 seconds ahead of Daniel Ricciardo, while Rosberg finished fourth after a disappointing start and a five-second time-penalty. The win gives Hamilton a 19-point lead with nine rounds remaining, providing a crucial psychological edge in the title battle.

site_title: Teaching children the life skill of cycling
summary: TWENTY underprivileged children learned to cycle safely as part of OCBC Cycle 2016's "Teach A Child to Cycle" programme at M Social Singapore hotel. Staff from Millennium Hotels and Resorts and cycling enthusiasts taught the basic principles of cycling to the children, who came from various organizations. The programme is part of a three-part series and aims to promote cycling as a life skill. The final session will be a half-day cycling trip around the Singapore Sports Hub.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Sinarmas Land, KOP units to develop Nuvasa Bay
summary: Sinarmas Land and KOP Limited have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop parts of Nuvasa Bay in Batam, Indonesia. The 228 ha development will incur a capital expenditure of S$400 million over five years, with 200 houses and 550 condos to be marketed in the first launch. Construction will begin in 2017, and the project aims to cater to affluent residents and investors seeking a premium living experience.

site_title: May pledges new action to tackle 'barbaric evil' of modern slavery
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged new action to tackle modern slavery in Britain, committing £33.5 million to a five-year fund and setting up a cross-government task force to combat the issue. The move comes after a review of the 2015 Modern Slavery Act showed a 14% increase in prosecutions and a 40% increase in identified victims. May called modern slavery a "barbaric evil" and vowed to make it a national and international mission to eradicate the issue, which affects nearly 46 million people globally.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's oil demand growth at six-year low as economy sputters
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil demand growth has slowed to a six-year low due to low energy prices hurting economic growth. The country's oil consumption increased by an average of 24,000 barrels a day in the first five months of 2016, the slowest growth rate since 2010. The International Energy Agency (IEA) now forecasts a drop in demand in Saudi Arabia for all of 2016. This slowdown is attributed to the economic challenges facing the kingdom, which is the world's largest crude exporter.

site_title: Chaos as nominations close in UKIP leadership race
summary: Nominations for the UK Independence Party (UKIP) leadership have closed in the wake of Nigel Farage's departure. Despite front-runner Steven Woolfe's technical issues, nominations are expected to be announced on Tuesday. Other contenders include European Parliament members Bill Etheridge and Jonathan Arnott, local councillor Lisa Duffy, and party executive committee member Elizabeth Jones. The process was marred by confusion, with Woolfe missing the deadline by 17 minutes. The party's immigration spokesman is now the clear front-runner, but the vetting procedure has yet to be completed.

site_title: Xi pressed for stronger South China Sea response
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is resisting pressure from elements within the military to take a stronger response to an international court ruling against Beijing's claims in the South China Sea. Despite nationalist sentiment and protests, China has not shown signs of wanting to take armed action, instead calling for a peaceful resolution through talks. However, some military hardliners are pushing for a more forceful response, including establishing an Air Defence Identification Zone and deploying missiles. The Chinese leadership is wary of a clash with the US and is instead focusing on maintaining a stable external environment ahead of Xi's hosting of a G20 summit in September.

site_title: Demand for turning condos to serviced apartments wanes
summary: Interest in converting condos to serviced apartments in Singapore has waned, with only four applications received as of July 15, down from 12 last year. Analysts attribute this to a strong primary sales market and a soft patch ahead for such apartments. Developers are opting to sell individual units rather than hold en bloc development, and some market watchers predict an increase in applications if the primary sales market slows down. Serviced apartments continue to face competition from alternative accommodation providers, but still retain advantages such as brand standards and quality control.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hold hefty gains, await RBA rate policy
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged on Monday, with the Aussie reaching a two-week high of US$0.7616, amid downbeat US economic data and expectations of a low interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The RBA holds its policy meeting on Tuesday, with economists favoring a rate cut to 1.5% to curb inflation. Interbank futures indicate a 60% probability of a rate cut by the end of the year, and yields on two-year government paper have fallen to 1.47%, a level never seen before.

site_title: The Exco: a dinosaur in the digital age?
summary: A corporate governance issue surrounds the executive committee, or Exco, within companies. Despite its influence, the Exco lacks clear guidelines regarding its governance. The Code of Corporate Governance provides guidance on other committees, but not the Exco. This lack of oversight reflects the diversity of company needs.

site_title: Savvy investors 'can benefit from Brexit-like events'
summary: Investor Jim Rogers and Steve Quirk from TD Ameritrade suggest that savvy investors can benefit from destabilizing global events such as Brexit and a potential Trump presidency. Rogers believes industries like pollution control, healthcare, and agriculture will thrive in China, while Quirk notes that a Trump victory would not hurt markets due to its unpredictability. Both experts emphasize the importance of spotting undervalued securities in trying times and being prepared for potential changes in regulations and policies.

site_title: 31 SMEs honoured at BT Salutes Enterprise gala dinner
summary: Thirty-one Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) were honored at the BT Salutes Enterprise gala dinner, held at the Shangri-La Hotel. The event, part of the four-day BT Salutes Enterprise series, recognized businesses for their achievements and contributions to the community. Minister of State Chee Hong Tat attended the dinner, where OCBC Bank's head of global commercial banking, Linus Goh, congratulated the honorees, emphasizing the importance of innovation and contributing to a growing community of successful businesses.

site_title: Former Irish bankers jailed after longest criminal trial
summary: Three former Irish bankers, Denis Casey, Willie McAteer, and John Bowe, were sentenced to over eight years in prison for conspiring to defraud customers and investors during the financial crisis. They were convicted of creating a false impression of Anglo Irish Bank's financial health through a circular payment in 2008. The longest criminal trial in Ireland's history, the trio received sentences of 2 years and 9 months, 2 years, and 3 years and 6 months respectively. The convictions followed a trial that began in January, with former executive Peter Fitzpatrick acquitted of charges last month.

site_title: Turkey culls nearly 1,400 from armed forces, purges army panel
summary: Turkey's President Tayyip Erdogan dismissed nearly 1,400 military personnel suspected of links to Islamic preacher Fethullah Gulen, who is accused of orchestrating the July 15-16 failed coup. The dismissals were announced in the government's official gazette, following an earlier announcement that over 1,700 military personnel were dishonourably discharged for their role in the putsch. The move is seen as an attempt to consolidate Erdogan's control over the military after the failed coup, with the government stacking the top military council with government ministers.

site_title: British Airways parent cuts capacity, reviews spending on Brexit
summary: British Airways parent IAG SA will cut capacity and review spending due to economic uncertainty after the UK's Brexit vote. Operating profit excluding one-time items is expected to grow by a low double-digit percentage, down from a previous forecast of 40% due to weaker pound and decreased demand. The company also faces challenges from terrorist attacks and air traffic control strikes. IAG shares have lost about one-quarter of their value since the Brexit referendum, and the company predicts a recovery "at some point," but not before 2017.

site_title: Sinarmas Land and KOP to develop Nuvasa Bay areas in Batam
summary: Sinarmas Land and KOP have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop parts of Nuvasa Bay in Batam, a 228-hectare high-end integrated residential and mixed-use development. The first phase will cost around 4 trillion rupiah (S$409 million) over five years, with 200 residential houses and 550 condominium units planned for launch at the end of 2016. Construction will start in 2017, with the developers expecting Nuvasa Bay to attract investors due to Batam's high property growth rate.

site_title: Champions of good governance
summary: The 11th annual Singapore Corporate Awards (SCA) honored the leading corporate governance figures in Singapore, celebrating excellence in maintaining strong governance in a challenging landscape. OCBC and Singtel won the prestigious gold prize for Best Managed Board, while Frasers Centrepoint Ltd's CEO Lim Ee Seng received the large-cap Best CEO trophy. The Keppel group swept five awards, and the CapitaLand group secured three. Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong was the guest of honor, emphasizing the benefits of strong corporate governance in navigating the business terrain.

site_title: Germany's SAP takes on blockchain challenge by building on it
summary: SAP SE, a leading software company, is addressing the potential disruption posed by blockchain technology. The company is developing specialized software to connect blockchains to its Hana Cloud Platform, enabling customers to leverage the technology's benefits, such as speed and security, without replacing its existing enterprise planning software. SAP is working with various blockchain technologies and partnering with companies like ATB Financial and Ripple Labs to test blockchain applications in industries like banking, agriculture, and energy. The company aims to stay ahead of the curve and capitalize on the potential of blockchain technology.

images.alt_text: About 50,000 businesses run SAP's financial and operations planning software, which is so ingrained that companies design manufacturing, delivery and accounting processes around it.

site_title: Fans celebrate as Harry Potter magic hits Asia
summary: Harry Potter fans worldwide celebrated the release of "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child," a new play set 19 years after the last book. Nearly 300 fans lined up hours before the play's premiere in London to get their hands on the script, with fans in Singapore, Bangkok, and other cities also holding launch parties and queuing for hours. The play's global kickoff coincided with author J.K. Rowling's birthday, marking the return of the series that has captivated readers and movie audiences worldwide.

images.alt_text: Children watching a video preview at a book store during the launch of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child in Singapore on Sunday.

site_title: 2005: Singapore rolls dice with casino plans
summary: In 2005, Singapore rolled the dice on casino plans, despite long-held opposition, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong taking a gamble on the benefits of integrated resorts. The decision sparked debate on economic necessity versus social risks. Meanwhile, China and Malaysia ended their dollar pegs, marking a significant milestone in China's global economic ascension. In Singapore, public outrage led to reforms at the National Kidney Foundation following revelations of financial improprieties and lavish remuneration for its CEO. The government implemented safeguards to address concerns about problem gambling.

site_title: Director buying falls, selling stays low
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a decline in director buying and buyback activity for the fourth consecutive week. Six companies made purchases worth S$0.77 million, while one firm made a disposal worth S$0.19 million. The buyback activity also fell, with 10 companies posting 29 repurchases worth S$10.3 million. Notable buybacks were seen in SIA Engineering, iFAST Corporation, and Olam International, while insider buys were recorded in Tung Lok Restaurants, SHS Holdings, and GL Limited.

site_title: New hope for Taiwan's aboriginal tribes
summary: Taiwan's new President Tsai Ing-wen is set to deliver the first-ever apology to the island's indigenous people on August 1 for centuries of injustices. Critics argue that laws discriminate against aboriginal culture, and tensions have risen over land rights and hunting restrictions. Aboriginal hunter Tama Talum, who was sentenced to three-and-a-half years for possessing an illegal weapon and hunting protected species, fears his traditions will die out. Tsai's apology aims to ease tensions and show willingness to address the issue, giving hope to the aboriginal community.

site_title: Snow City the new hot ticket in the Saudi capital
summary: A new snow park, "Snow City," has opened in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, despite temperatures exceeding 45°C. The facility, which covers 5,000 square meters, features indoor slopes and has become a popular attraction, with women making up over 75% of visitors. The complex is a rare entertainment option in the ultra-conservative country, where cinemas and theatres are not allowed. The project is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy and provide more entertainment options for its residents.

site_title: Meat dishes pack a punch
summary: The article reviews Salted & Hung, a restaurant in Singapore that specializes in meat dishes. While the reviewer enjoyed many of the meat options, such as the fried tripe and blackboard special, the seafood dishes were underwhelming. The reviewer notes that the restaurant's prices have increased and the menu has changed, resulting in a busier and more frenetic atmosphere. The reviewer concludes that the restaurant's self-conscious attempt to cater to a wider audience has led to a less effortless and tasty dining experience. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: Soft-cooked egg sitting on savoury, earthy porcini mushroom crumbs
Peanut tim tam dessert
A thick, meaty hamachi collar
Fried tripe with togarashi, Szechuan pepper and caponata puree
Octopus which tastes better at lunch than during dinner.

site_title: UK, China regulators discuss framework for financial projects
summary: British and Chinese regulators are discussing a regulatory framework for financial projects, including a London-Shanghai link for trading shares and a scheme for distributing fund products. The talks ease concerns that Brexit may hinder such deals. The Financial Conduct Authority and China Securities Regulatory Commission are cooperating on the framework, which could pave the way for landmark financial services projects between the two countries. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the discussions remain "very positive" and may lead to a formal cooperation agreement.

site_title: Attacks take toll on French tourism
summary: France's tourism industry suffered a significant blow in late July, with 8.8% fewer arrivals by air in the week following the July 14 attack in Nice, which killed 84 people. This slump follows a decline in arrivals since the November 13 attacks in Paris, which claimed 130 lives. The attacks have led to a further decline in foreign visitors, putting pressure on the already-battered sector.

site_title: Fosun strikes first Brazil deal with purchase of fund manager Rio Bravo
summary: Fosun Group has agreed to purchase Brazilian fund manager Rio Bravo Investimentos, its first acquisition in Latin America. The deal's value was not disclosed, but Fosun expects to capitalize on the region's economic renewal. Reuters reported the talks were in advanced stages earlier this week. This acquisition marks Fosun's entry into the Brazilian market and its expansion into neighboring economies.

site_title: Hamilton wins German Grand Prix
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the German Grand Prix, extending his lead in the Formula One drivers' championship to 19 points. Hamilton, driving for Mercedes, secured his sixth win in seven races, while Nico Rosberg, his teammate and title rival, finished fourth. Daniel Ricciardo took second place, and Max Verstappen finished third.

site_title: VW, California regulator start testing pollution fix in diesel cars
summary: Volkswagen AG and the California Air Resources Board are testing potential fixes for 475,000 diesel cars sold in the US with improperly designed pollution controls. The proposed fixes, if approved, could help VW avoid buying back the affected vehicles. The testing focuses on three generations of Volkswagen cars with 2.0-litre diesel engines and faulty pollution control systems designed to operate only during government tests. The goal is to address emissions concerns without requiring a massive buyback of vehicles.

site_title: Gold futures gain for second week; wheat slides to decade low
summary: Gold futures rose for the second week, gaining 1.2% to $1,357.50 an ounce, as the US economy grew less than expected, boosting demand for the metal as a store of value. The dollar weakened and a gauge of the dollar dropped to a four-week low, also supporting gold prices. Meanwhile, wheat prices slid to a decade low due to a global glut, with US wheat futures falling 1.6% to the lowest since 2006.

site_title: US dollar nurses losses after hit from downbeat GDP report
summary: The US dollar recovered from its lows after a disappointing GDP report, with the dollar index rising 0.1% to 95.654. The report showed a 1.2% annual growth rate in April-June, below the 2.6% forecast. The yen also pared its gains, while other currencies remained stable. The downbeat GDP figures added to market uncertainty, but the dollar's recovery was driven by a decrease in investor risk aversion.

images.alt_text: The dollar on Monday pulled away from lows it hit following disappointing US growth figures late last week while the yen pared some its large gains made after the Bank of Japan's smaller-than-expected stimulus steps.

site_title: Hitachi invests in stem cell research to spur investor returns
summary: Hitachi Ltd. has invested in stem cell research to boost investor returns, which have lagged overseas rivals in recent years. The company unveiled a cabinet-sized stem cell incubator that promises to utilize a technique pioneered by Nobel Prize winner Shinya Yamanaka for new eye and heart treatments. Hitachi plans to increase research and development spending by 5% to 350 billion yen (S$4.6 billion) and has added 100 research jobs to support expansions in areas such as robotics and artificial intelligence. The company's shares have plunged 37% over the past year, despite predicting a 16% increase in net income.

site_title: Former president S R Nathan in critical condition at SGH after suffering a stroke
summary: Former Singapore President S R Nathan is in critical condition at the Singapore General Hospital after suffering a stroke on Sunday. He is 92 years old and currently in the Intensive Care Unit. The Prime Minister's Office released a statement confirming the incident.

site_title: China steps up campaign to curb rising risks in financial sector
summary: China's banking regulator is stepping up efforts to curb risks in the financial sector by resisting lobbying to relax rules governing bad-loan buffers. The regulator is pushing banks to restore their buffers, which could curb profits, and has drawn up tougher rules for wealth-management products, a key area of concern. Analysts have warned of a growing pile of bad loans and urged the government to take action, with some predicting a recapitalisation of banks within two years. The regulator's stance is seen as a move to maintain financial stability, despite potential impact on bank profits.

site_title: Low-carbon investing in vogue after Paris climate talks
summary: Singapore - Institutional investors are shifting towards low-carbon investing following the Paris climate agreement, with Western investors leading the charge. Low-carbon indexes, such as Amundi's Low Carbon Leaders Index, have shown slight outperformance compared to their respective benchmarks. The strategy involves excluding polluting companies from portfolios and investing in low-emission sectors. As governments consider carbon pricing, investors see a "free option" to tackle climate change. Notable investors, including Norway's sovereign wealth fund and Sweden's AP4, have committed to low-carbon strategies, with plans to increase investments. The growing likelihood of carbon pricing and governments' climate change disclosures are expected to drive further adoption of low-carbon investing.

site_title: Clinton, Trump take gloves off in White House slog
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump escalated their rivalry, trading insults and painting starkly different visions of America. Clinton portrayed Trump as a threat to democracy, focusing on issues affecting working-class voters, while Trump emphasized his outsider status and promises to restore jobs and cut the deficit. The candidates are now in a tight race, with Clinton's unpopularity matching Trump's, and experts predict that "negative partisanship" will play a significant role in the election.

site_title: Tokyo gets its first female governor
summary: Tokyo has elected its first female governor, Yuriko Koike, who defeated two main rivals, including a Liberal Democratic Party-backed candidate, in a high-turnout election. Koike, a former defence minister and environment minister, won the position despite the LDP's initial refusal to support her. She assumes office four years before the 2020 Olympics, which have been plagued by problems, and vows to use the event as a chance to build a new Tokyo. Koike's campaign focused on tackling special interests, increasing day-care slots, and raising her profile as a capable administrator, and she is fluent in English and Arabic.

site_title: Tokyo votes to elect new governor after scandals
summary: Tokyo residents voted to elect a new governor, tasked with managing the city's preparations for the 2020 Olympics and addressing financial scandals. A record 21 candidates are vying for the position, with former defence chief Yuriko Koike, ex-Iwate prefecture governor Hiroya Masuda, and veteran TV journalist Shuntaro Torigoe leading the race. The winner will face challenges including soaring Olympic costs, a dire childcare shortage, and disaster response plans amidst perennial earthquake threats. The election comes after previous governors resigned due to scandals, with the winner's term set to run until after the Games.

site_title: US$60 is the new US$50 for US oil drillers waiting for rebound
summary: US oil drillers are now expecting to break even at around $60 per barrel, up from the previous $50 threshold. This new target reflects industry confidence in sustained prices and a desire to avoid the boom-bust cycle. Industry leaders, including Anadarko Petroleum and Pioneer Natural Resources, expect to ramp up drilling and spending only when prices reach $60 or higher. Rising costs for oilfield-service crews and service-cost inflation are also expected to impact early investment.

site_title: India feeds thousands of Gulf workers 'in crisis'
summary: India is working to feed over 10,000 stranded Indian labourers in the Gulf who lost their jobs after employers failed to pay wages. Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj described the situation as a "food crisis" and announced that two junior foreign ministers will visit Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to address the issue. The migrant workers, mostly from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, have been facing "extreme hardship" without pay.

site_title: Privatised service
summary: A debate over whether Singapore's SMRT train operator should be privatized has been ongoing. Some argue that privatization could improve efficiency and cost-effectiveness, allowing the company to focus on quality and reliability. Others claim that privatization would compromise transparency and accountability, and that the company's management issues are not solely due to market failure. The proposed Temasek takeover has sparked differing opinions, with some seeing it as a potential solution to revamp the company's strategy and improve performance. Ultimately, the key to SMRT's success lies in providing reliable and quality transport services.

site_title: India should rethink basis of inflation target
summary: India is set to announce its first official inflation target, with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) proposed to target a specific inflation rate. The move aims to increase transparency and independence for the central bank. However, critics argue that India is targeting the wrong kind of inflation, focusing on the consumer price index (CPI) rather than overall stability. The issue lies in the fact that food prices make up a significant proportion of the CPI, which are not responsive to monetary policy, and targeting this can lead to a contractionary spiral. Experts suggest shifting the focus to "core" consumer inflation, which excludes food prices, to achieve a more stable and credible inflation target.

site_title: Tokyo elects first woman governor as it prepares for its Olympics
summary: Tokyo has elected its first woman governor, Yuriko Koike, 64, who won the election after two predecessors stepped down over scandals. Koike, a former defence minister, beat Hiroya Masuda, a former bureaucrat, and Shuntaro Torigoe, a liberal journalist. Koike will oversee Tokyo's preparations for the 2020 Olympics, which face numerous challenges, including an aging population and earthquake risks. Her victory is seen as a boost to the city's reputation as a host for the games, and her campaign focused on using the Olympics as a chance to build a new Tokyo for beyond 2020.

site_title: Harry Potter magic hits Asia as fans celebrate new book
summary: Harry Potter magic swept through Asia as fans eagerly awaited the release of "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child," the eighth installment of the series. Nearly 300 fans lined up hours before the book's release, with some waiting overnight to be among the first to purchase a copy. Launch parties were held worldwide, including in Singapore, London, and Bangkok, with fans dressed in Harry Potter costumes and excited to see the new script. The book's release coincided with J.K. Rowling's birthday and the world premiere of the play in London.

images.alt_text: Harry Potter magic hit Asia on Sunday morning, as aspiring witches and wizards crowded into bookstores to get their hands on the first copies of a new play that imagines the hero as an adult.

site_title: Florida cases seen as first sign Zika transmitted locally in US
summary: Florida authorities reported the first sign of local Zika transmission in the continental US, with four people infected in an area of Miami. Testing showed one woman and three men had been infected, with health officials ruling out travel and sexual contact as transmission methods. The state believes active transmission is occurring within a 2.6 square kilometer area, prompting efforts to control the mosquito population and distribute Zika protection kits to pregnant women.

images.alt_text: Florida authorities on Friday reported the first sign of local Zika transmission in the continental United States, concluding that mosquitoes likely infected four people with the virus that can cause a rare but serious birth defect.

site_title: Singapore growth to pick up in 2017, but weak global outlook a risk: IMF
summary: Singapore's economic growth is expected to accelerate to 2.2% in 2017, supported by accommodative fiscal and monetary policies. However, the weak global outlook remains a risk, with slow global and regional growth and potential spillovers from renewed financial volatility. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) also expects headline inflation to remain negative in 2016 and accelerate to 1.1% in 2017. The current expansionary fiscal stance and the central bank's easing move in April are seen as appropriate, but near-term risks are skewed to the downside.

site_title: Paris attacks 'accomplices' charged in France
summary: French authorities have charged two suspected accomplices of the Paris attackers, Adel Haddadi and Mohamad Usman, with "criminal conspiracy with terrorists". The 29-year-old Algerian and 35-year-old Pakistani were detained by Austrian authorities for 25 days before being transferred to France, where they are facing terror charges. Investigators believe they were part of the same Islamic State cell that carried out the November 13 attacks, which killed 130 people, and that Usman may be a bomb maker for Pakistani extremist organisations.

images.alt_text: French authorities filed terror charges on Friday against two suspected members of the same Islamic State cell that massacred 130 people in Paris last November, a judicial source said.

site_title: No clean bill of health for EU banks in stress test
summary: European Union banks have shown resilience in the latest stress test, but still face work to boost credit to the bloc's economy. Eight years after the global banking meltdown, many banks are saddled with billions of euros in poorly performing loans. Italy's Monte dei Paschi, Austria's Raiffeisen, Spain's Banco Popular, and Ireland's Allied Irish Banks fared the worst, with core equity capital ratios below 5.5%. The European Banking Authority says while the results are heartening, there remains work to be done to strengthen banks' capital bases and improve profitability.

site_title: UBS sees outflows from emerging-market clients as secrecy erodes
summary: UBS predicts emerging-market outflows will continue as tax authorities crack down on wealthy clients. In Q2, net withdrawals from emerging-market clients reached 2.3 billion Swiss francs, mainly from Latin America. The Swiss government will start sharing banking data with other tax authorities in 2018, amid efforts by countries like Brazil and Mexico to encourage tax repayment. UBS expects outflows to persist until the full implementation of automatic exchange of information, and analysts warn of potential outflows to Asia.

site_title: UBS Asia investment banking co-head said planning to depart
summary: UBS Asia investment banking co-head Saurabh Beniwal is planning to leave the bank by the end of this year, according to people familiar with the matter. Beniwal, appointed in November as co-head of corporate client solutions, will depart as the bank trims senior management ranks in the region. site_title: Fed's Williams says two rate increases still possible in 2016
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated that the US economy could still warrant two interest-rate increases in 2016, despite a "low" reading on second-quarter US growth. Williams noted that data could support two rate increases or none, and time would tell. He emphasized the importance of monitoring future economic data to make a final decision.

summary: US authorities have issued subpoenas to Goldman Sachs for documents related to its dealings with 1MDB, a scandal-hit Malaysian state fund. site_title: S'pore stocks end month on positive note
summary: Singaporean stocks ended July on a positive note, with the total market capitalisation rising 1.4% to S$860.4 billion, despite oil and commodities woes. site_title: Brazil's former president Lula, BTG's Esteves formally charged
summary: Brazil's former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and seven others, including BTG's Andre Esteves, were formally charged by a federal judge for allegedly interfering in the country's largest-ever corruption investigation, known as Carwash. The defendants are accused of trying to obstruct the graft probe, which has led to the arrest of top business leaders. They have 20 days to present their preliminary defense. Lula and Esteves have denied any wrongdoing, with Lula petitioning the United Nations over alleged human rights violations by Judge Sergio Moro.

site_title: E-trading platform for physically backed precious metals launched
summary: GoldSilver Central, a Singaporean bullion dealer, has launched an e-trading platform for physically backed gold, silver, and platinum, allowing 24-hour trading and physical delivery of holdings. The platform aims to boost retail investment options in Singapore, catering to clients seeking to profit from precious metals price volatility. With small minimum contract sizes and advanced features, the platform is expected to make bullion trading easier and more convenient, propelling Singapore's prominence as a major hub for precious metals trading and investment.

site_title: Deutsche Bank scrapes through European banks stress test
summary: Deutsche Bank has shown a weaker reading in the European Union's banking stress test, ranking 10th from the bottom with a capital level of 7.8% compared to the 7.5% threshold. Despite regulators designating the bank as systemically important, it still needs significant capital. The bank plans to add up to 7 billion euros to its capital buffers by 2019, but analysts argue it will struggle to fill this gap, especially if economic conditions deteriorate. site_title: BOJ disappoints markets by relative lack of action
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) surprised markets by leaving its monetary policy unchanged, despite government pressure for bold actions, and instead announced a pledge to double its purchases of exchange-traded funds to reduce risk premiums in the equity market. The central bank also vowed to conduct a comprehensive assessment of economic activity and prices, potentially paving the way for future policy actions. The decision was met with disappointment, causing Tokyo stock prices to fall initially, and the yen to gain sharply.

site_title: Brazil unemployment rises to 11.3%
summary: Brazil's unemployment rate rose to 11.3% in the second quarter, surpassing the same period last year by three percentage points. The country's recession, triggered by the Petrobras corruption scandal and political uncertainty, continues to affect the economy. Interim President Michel Temer is implementing market-friendly reforms to get the economy back on track, but forecasts predict the recession will last into 2017. The situation comes ahead of the country hosting the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.

site_title: Tesla mulling two theories to explain 'Autopilot' crash: source
summary: Tesla is considering two theories to explain a May fatal crash involving the company's "Autopilot" system. The US Senate Commerce Committee staff was briefed by Tesla staff, who are still trying to understand the "system failure" that led to the crash. The possible explanations include a failure to detect a truck trailer using radar and camera input, or the radar detecting the trailer but being overridden to avoid triggering false braking. Tesla is still investigating the cause of the crash, which killed a Florida man.

site_title: 'Growth is over', Ford says of car industry
summary: Ford Motor Co. declared the US car industry's long recovery is over, citing pent-up demand being satisfied and lower used car prices drawing buyers away from new vehicles. This forecast led to a 8.2% decline in Ford shares and a 3.2% drop in General Motors Co. stock. Ford plans to accelerate cost-cutting measures and axe North American production in the second half of the year.

site_title: India excites OppenheimerFunds
summary: OppenheimerFunds Inc has expressed excitement about investing in India, citing the country's "safest portfolio investment destination" among emerging markets due to its political stability, credible monetary policy, and fastest growth among major economies. The government's plans to implement a national sales tax and the Reserve Bank of India's efforts to improve financial-system liquidity have also boosted investor confidence.

site_title: India's strategic oil reserves unlikely to stir market
summary: India's initial plan to build strategic petroleum reserves (SPR) is unlikely to impact global oil demand, with shipping brokers estimating that just a handful of tankers can handle the 5 million tonnes of crude India plans to store. The SPR program, which aims to cover 10 days of India's average daily imports, is dwarfed by China's 400 million barrels and the US's 400 days of reserves.
