Occupancy remained flat, prompting OCBC Investment Research to review its "hold" rating and fair value of $1.43 pending a management briefing.

site_title: Chernobyl's atomic wasteland may be reborn with solar energy
summary: Ukraine is seeking investors to develop solar power near the Chernobyl nuclear site, 30 years after the meltdown rendered the area uninhabitable due to radiation. The 1,000 square mile exclusion zone has the potential for renewable energy, with high-voltage transmission lines and cheap land available. The project aims to reduce Ukraine's reliance on natural gas from Russia and promote European standards for the environment and clean energy. Two US investment firms and four Canadian energy companies have expressed interest, with a planned 4 megawatts of panels to be installed by year-end.

site_title: Singapore shares open 2.72 points lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 2.72 points lower on Wednesday at 2,930.72. The US markets had a mixed performance overnight, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing lower and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining. Top losers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, Keppel Corporation, and ST Engineering. Trading volume was 76.9 million shares worth S$41.4 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 56 to 54.

site_title: Gold drops before Fed meet as bets tick up for rate hike in 2016
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,317.70 an ounce before a Federal Reserve meeting, which may influence interest-rate increases. Investors consider the Bank of Japan's potential stimulus. Despite a 24% gain this year, gold's rally has been trimmed as traders weigh the Fed's meeting and BOJ policy. The probability of a December interest-rate hike has increased to 50%, up from 15% a month ago, with only 10% odds of a rate increase at the current Fed meeting.

site_title: Australian dollar rises for third day before CPI data give RBA rate clues
summary: Australia's dollar rose for a third day before the release of consumer-price data, which is expected to signal a recovery and potentially keep interest rates steady at the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting next week. The Aussie dollar strengthened against 10 major peers, with the probability of rate cuts falling to 55% from 64%. Second-quarter CPI is expected to rise 0.4% from the previous quarter, according to a Bloomberg survey. The Australian dollar rose 0.2% to 75.17 US cents, extending a two-day advance.

site_title: DBS Private Bank hires ex-UBS banker to head S-E Asia unit
summary: DBS Private Bank has appointed Joseph Poon, a former UBS banker, as the regional head of South-east Asia for its private bank division, effective August 16, 2016. Poon previously led UBS Wealth Management's ultra high net worth and global family office businesses in South-east Asia. The move is part of DBS's strategy to enhance its private banking business and focus on the ultra high net worth segment. DBS's high net worth assets under management stood at S$101 billion as of March 2016.

site_title: Australia's inflation at 17-year low, opens door to rate cut
summary: Australia's inflation rate has dropped to a 17-year low of 1.0% in the year to June, beating the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. Core inflation remains at a record low of 1.5%. The low inflation reading has led to speculation of a potential interest rate cut as early as next week, with many analysts expecting the RBA to provide more support to the economy. The odds of a rate cut have lengthened slightly to 50% but remain fully priced in by November.

site_title: Going postal with missed delivery? SingPost may soothe angst with locker rental service
summary: SingPost has introduced Singapore's first open parcel locker service, POPStation locker, allowing retailers and consumers to rent a locker for parcel delivery and collection. Users can rent from 140 locations island-wide, including commercial and neighbourhood areas, to avoid missing deliveries or arranging meet-ups. The service, launched after a one-month trial with online marketplaces, has seen 50% of parcels delivered outside office hours with a 100% collection rate. The service aims to provide parcel delivery flexibility to cater to busy lifestyles, and SingPost welcomes the government's initiative to ease last-mile delivery challenges.

site_title: Australia's AGL and state-owned funds establish renewables fund
summary: Australia's AGL Energy Ltd established the Powering Australian Renewables Fund (PARF) with a $2 billion to $3 billion investment from the sovereign wealth fund and a Queensland government-owned fund. The fund aims to develop 1000MW of renewable energy, including acquiring two existing AGL solar plants and two wind farm projects. This move is seen as a significant step towards meeting Australia's renewable energy target of 33,000 GWh by 2020, and AGL plans to eventually close its coal-fired power plants. The fund's establishment breaks the logjam around funding for large-scale renewables.

site_title: Philippines posts 45.2b peso budget gap in June
summary: The Philippine government reported a budget deficit of 45.2 billion pesos (S$1.3 billion) in June, bringing the first-half shortfall to 120.3 billion pesos, compared to a 13.7 billion pesos surplus in the same period last year. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has pledged to accelerate infrastructure spending to lift economic growth.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise amid Japan rebound as yen pulls back; oil sinks
summary: Asian stocks rose amid a rebound in Japan's Topix index, driven by a retreat in the yen and gains in mining and consumer stocks. The yen pulled back after a 1.1% surge on Tuesday, while crude oil fell a fifth straight day to $42.67 a barrel. Gold declined ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate review. The rally extended to the US, with Nasdaq 100 Index futures jumping 0.6% after better-than-expected earnings boosted Apple Inc.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slightly up 0.38 points to 1661.80. Gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 33, and trading volume was 17.67 million lots worth RM5.9 million.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q2 profit up 12.9%
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Singapore property developer, reported a 12.9% increase in its net profit for the second quarter to S$8.61 million, driven by higher revenue from property sales and rental income. Revenue rose 40.8% to S$42.2 million. The company noted a decline in China's housing market recovery, but demand for the Dongguan residential market remains strong. Two "problematic" loans totaling S$130 million are at risk of foreclosure if the borrowers do not repay on time.

site_title: US report says Tesla in fatal Autopilot crash was speeding
summary: A US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) preliminary report found that a Tesla driver, Joshua Brown, was speeding at 119 km/h in a 100 km/h zone when he crashed into a semi-truck, killing him. The investigation confirmed Brown was using Autopilot features at the time of the crash, but the probable cause has not been determined. Tesla's advanced driver assistance features were activated, and the car's battery disengaged from the electric motors after the initial impact. The NTSB will release a final report in about a year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally at open ahead of Fed decision
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 0.87% at open on July 27, 2016, rebounding from three straight losses. The Nikkei 225 index rose 143.02 points to 16,526.06, and the Topix index climbed 9.59 points to 1,316.53. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's decision later in the day.

site_title: Thai exports slip 0.1% in June year-on-year, imports slump
summary: Thailand's customs-cleared exports declined 0.1% in June from a year earlier, defying expectations of a 2.02% drop. Shipments to China and Japan fell, but those to the US and Europe rose. Exports to China dropped 11.9% and to Japan 3.8%, while those to the US increased 4.7% and to Europe 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Thailand's customs-cleared exports fell less than expected in June, helped by shipments of cars and gold, commerce ministry data showed on Wednesday, but demand from some major markets remained weak.

site_title: China securities regulator tightens private equity placement rules: media
summary: China's securities regulator has tightened rules for private equity placements, instructing firms to curb the use of borrowed money and limit third-party fundraising. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has advised firms to avoid using wealth management platforms or other third-party platforms to subscribe to companies they own 5% or more of. The regulator also emphasized the importance of firms using banking facilities only for their intended purpose. These new guidelines aim to curb excessive borrowing and promote more transparent fundraising practices in the private equity market.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says Model 3 could generate US$20b in revenue per year
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk stated that the Model 3 could generate US$20 billion in revenue annually and US$5 billion in gross profit. To fund strategic plans and new products, a "modest capital raise" may be necessary, which could cost "tens of billions" over time. Musk unveiled Tesla's battery "gigafactory" near Reno, Nevada, during a press conference.

site_title: Energy acquisitions seen accelerating as fear of bad deals fade
summary: Energy acquisitions are expected to accelerate globally as fears of bad deals dissipate and energy prices stabilize. Oil and gas assets worth about $2,000 are available, with most deals expected to close in the fourth quarter or next year. Industry confidence has increased with oil prices trading between $43 and $52 a barrel, outpacing mergers and acquisitions in North America this year. The market has "reset" with buyers and sellers having a more comfortable conversation about asset values, according to Ernst & Young.

site_title: Pokemon Go craze befuddles analysts at big investment banks
summary: Analysts at major investment banks are struggling to keep up with the rapid rise of Pokémon Go, with some, such as Bank of America's Hiroyasu Eguchi, upgrading their ratings and price targets for Nintendo Co after the game's debut. However, others, like SMBC Nikko Securities' Eiji Maeda, remain skeptical about Nintendo's ability to replicate the game's success. The company's lack of transparency about its financial interest in Pokémon Go has also raised questions among analysts. Despite this, Eguchi's bullish forecast predicts a 71% increase in shares, citing the game's technology and potential for introducing well-known characters across new platforms.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC, Hon Hai up on Apple results
summary: Taiwan stocks rose on Wednesday, led by gains in TSMC, Hon Hai Precision, and other Apple Inc suppliers after the US company sold more iPhones than expected in the third quarter. The main Taiex index rose 0.3% to 9,055.34, while the electronics subindex gained 0.6%. TSMC, Hon Hai, and Largan Precision saw significant gains, with TSMC rising 1.2%, Hon Hai 0.7%, and Largan Precision 1.6%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$32.160 per US dollar.

site_title: Bank of Korea chief says monetary policy rate cannot go to 0%
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Governor Lee Ju Yeol, stated that the country's monetary policy rate cannot be slashed to zero percent due to the need for policy space to support ongoing corporate restructuring. The bank will focus on supporting economic growth rather than price stabilization, and will scrutinize foreign flows to mitigate market volatility. The remarks came after a disappointing G20 meeting, where world leaders discussed supporting global growth and sharing trade benefits, but failed to produce significant new commitments.

site_title: CRCT's Q2 DPU falls 4.4% from a year ago
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 4.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, falling to 2.61 Singapore cents. Net property income decreased 1.5% to S$35.5 million, and income available for distribution dropped 2.5% to S$22.37 million. Despite a 5.9% increase in rental reversion, the annualized distribution yield for the first half of 2016 was 6.6%. Portfolio occupancy remained steady at 94.9% as of June 30, 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: IMF says Egypt seeks financial support
summary: Egypt has asked the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for financial support, seeking a US$7 billion loan program to strengthen its economy. The IMF plans to send a staff team to review the situation and begin consultations. This comes after Egypt's central bank devalued the Egyptian pound by nearly 15% in March due to struggles with economic instability. The move is seen as an attempt to return to economic stability and support strong, sustainable growth, with the IMF welcoming the request and looking forward to discussing policies to help Egypt meet its economic challenges.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff, Lula to boycott Olympic opening ceremony
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff and her predecessor Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva will boycott the Rio Olympics opening ceremony on August 5. Rousseff faces possible removal from office in an impeachment trial, while Lula faces serious corruption allegations. Rousseff's absence highlights the country's political crisis, and Lula's decision underscores the severity of his corruption issues. Both leaders will not attend the ceremony, which marks the beginning of the highly anticipated Games.

site_title: US dollar falls against euro, yen, as policy makers meet
summary: The US dollar declined against the euro and yen on Tuesday, as policy makers in the US and Japan prepared to release decisions on interest rates. The euro rose to 1.0986 and the yen fell to 114.96, with the dollar weakening to 104.62. The US Federal Reserve is expected not to raise interest rates, and Japanese officials are considering fiscal and monetary stimulus measures. Analysts predict the yen will strengthen regardless of the rate decision, potentially reaching below 100.

site_title: Singapore Exchange sees rise in delistings while IPOs slip
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen a rise in delistings, with 13 companies announcing plans to exit the bourse in the first half of 2016, totaling S$4.5 billion in market value. This surpasses the number of new listings during the period. The Straits Times Index's price-to-book value is near its lowest since the global financial crisis, contributing to the delistings.

images.alt_text: About 13 companies with a combined market value of S$4.5 billion have announced plans to delist from the Singapore Exchange in the first half of 2016 as the price-to-book value of shares on the Straits Times Index trades near the lowest since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Indonesia's energy minister to be replaced in cabinet reshuffle: sources
summary: Indonesia's Energy Minister Sudirman Said is expected to be replaced as part of President Joko Widodo's cabinet reshuffle, which is expected to be announced on Wednesday. The move comes nearly a year after Widodo replaced key members of his economics team to boost investor confidence. Analysts say the reshuffle is likely to be politically motivated to consolidate support from parties that have joined the ruling coalition, particularly Golkar, Indonesia's second-largest party. The reasons behind Said's replacement are unclear, but his statement on Twitter, "The big job is over. Let's never tire of loving Indonesia," suggests a sense of resignation.

site_title: Clinton makes history as US Democratic presidential nominee
summary: Hillary Clinton made history as the first woman to win the White House nomination of a major US political party, securing the Democratic nomination after beating Bernie Sanders. Clinton secured the 2,382-delegate threshold needed for the nomination, setting up a showdown with Republican Donald Trump in November. Despite some Sanders supporters expressing frustration, Clinton's nomination was formally put forward by Senator Barbara Mikulski, and she is now poised to become the US's first female president.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton became the first woman in history to win the White House nomination of a major US political party on Tuesday, securing the backing of Democrats at a convention in Philadelphia.

site_title: Hollande rejects opposition calls to harden terror laws
summary: French President Francois Hollande rejected opposition calls to harden anti-terrorism legislation, stating that restricting freedoms won't make the fight against terrorism more effective. This decision came after a Normandy church attack, which killed a Catholic priest and severely injured another person. Hollande cited existing legislation as sufficient to act against terrorism, contradicting opposition calls for further restrictions on freedoms.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande on Tuesday rejected opposition calls to further harden anti-terrorism legislation after the country's second jihadist attack in two weeks.

site_title: Apple sells more iPhones than expected, shares jump after hours
summary: Apple sold 40.4 million iPhones in the third quarter, beating analyst forecasts and slightly above the average of 40.02 million. Despite a 15% drop in iPhone sales and a 14.6% decline in total revenue, the company's shares rose 7% in after-hours trading. Services revenue, including the App Store and iCloud, was a "very big bright spot" for Apple, with a 18.9% increase. The company forecast fourth-quarter revenue of $45.5 billion to $47.5 billion, beating Wall Street's average estimate.

site_title: Europe: Shares pushed up by healthcare and consumer stocks
summary: European equities rose on Tuesday, driven by gains in healthcare and consumer goods stocks, which outperformed despite concerns over the banking sector. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.1% and the FTSEurofirst 300 index advanced 0.2%. Healthcare stocks, including Novo Nordisk, climbed after a positive forecast, while consumer goods and leisure stocks also reached record highs. Bank stocks, however, fell under pressure, with Commerzbank shares declining 4.5% due to a decline in core capital.

site_title: HK jeweller planning diamond wholesale business in US
summary: CHOW TAI FOOK, the world's largest publicly traded jewellery chain, plans to launch a diamond wholesale business in the US within a year. The move aims to offset the effects of a slowdown in China's luxury sales, which has led to a 46% slump in net income. The new business will sell polished and rough diamonds to US retailers, rather than its own-branded diamond jewellery. The strategy reflects the company's lack of confidence in the Greater China market, with analysts warning of challenges in a new market with a need to expand business networks.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q2 net profit falls 63% from a year ago without disposal gain
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 63% decline in Q2 net profit to S$102.2 million, down from S$277.7 million a year ago, due to a S$18.7 million loss on disposal of its Vietnam subsidiary and unfavorable market conditions. Gross premiums increased 25% to S$2,276.3 million. The insurance arm attributed the lower profit to unrealized fair value losses from asset valuation amid low interest rates. Despite this, the company remains positive on long-term prospects and has declared an unchanged interim dividend of 10 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Katrina Group sees strong debut on Catalist
summary: Singapore-listed food and beverage firm Katrina Group made a strong trading debut on the Catalist exchange, with its shares surging 93% from its IPO price of S$0.21 to S$0.405. The company raised S$7.5 million through the placement of 35.8 million new shares. Katrina Group operates 32 restaurants in Singapore and two in China, offering a range of cuisines from Indonesian to Vietnamese. The company's founder and CEO, Alan Goh, attributed the success to its diverse F&B concepts and ability to appeal to a wide range of patrons.

site_title: US: Dow slips on weak McDonald's earnings
summary: The US Dow Jones Industrial Average closed in the red on Tuesday, down 0.1% at 18,473.75, due to disappointing earnings from McDonald's, which fell 4.5% on a 9.1% drop in second-quarter earnings. Analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low, but may signal a greater likelihood of rate hikes later in the year. Other Dow companies reported mixed earnings, with Caterpillar and United Technologies rising, while Under Armour and Gilead Sciences fell.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib gets new powers amid planned protests over fund scandal
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has been granted sweeping security powers under a new National Security Council (NSC) Act, which comes into effect on August 1. The law allows him to designate areas as "security areas" and deploy forces to search individuals or premises without warrants. Critics say the law threatens human rights and democracy, and could be used to silence critics of the 1MDB fund scandal, with planned protests scheduled for July 30. The law was passed without royal assent and has been criticized by opposition parties and human rights groups.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak will get sweeping security powers on Monday amid planned protests calling for his resignation over US allegations that millions of dollars from a state fund wound up in his personal bank account.

site_title: Top pork eater gobbles more imported feed for expanding pig herd
summary: Vietnam is becoming one of the world's largest importers of soyabean meal, a key ingredient for pork feed, as the country's per-capita pork consumption has more than doubled since 2000. With local farmers unable to grow enough feed, imports are expected to double by 2017 and reach 20 million tonnes by 2018. Foreign companies, including Cargill, are building new feed mills to capitalize on the growing demand, with the industry's value projected to reach $10.55 billion by 2022.

site_title: Joko hits his stride with several key policy wins
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has achieved several key policy wins, including a controversial tax amnesty bill and the appointment of a new national police chief. He has also taken a tough stance on terrorism and China, detaining a Chinese boat and signaling a strong stance on Indonesia's sovereign maritime rights. Despite market concerns and economic challenges, Widodo's popularity has increased, and he has consolidated his position in Parliament. His success is contingent on the economy continuing to grow and infrastructure projects being completed on time.

site_title: Twitter dives after update disappoints
summary: Twitter shares plummeted 9% after the company's Q2 update revealed more losses and sluggish revenue growth. The platform reported a narrower loss of $107 million, but revenue rose 20% to $602 million, lagging expectations. Monthly active users increased 3% to 313 million, while advertising revenue surged 18% to $535 million, with mobile accounting for 89% of that. Despite progress, Twitter remains unlikely to post a profit, as it has since its 2013 IPO. CEO Jack Dorsey expressed confidence in the company's product roadmap and user engagement.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse shareholders back London Stock Exchange merger
summary: Deutsche Boerse shareholders have backed a planned merger with the London Stock Exchange, creating a new global player. The merger, which had been scaled back to 60% due to Brexit uncertainty, was approved with 60.35% of capital. LSE shareholders had previously voted overwhelmingly for the tie-up. The combined company will have 54.4% of capital, with Deutsche Boerse shareholders holding 54.4% and LSE shareholders holding 45.6%. The deal still requires approval from several national authorities and the European Commission.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler revises sales figures
summary: Fiat Chrysler has revised its US car sales figures, revealing a six-year streak of monthly gains ended three years ago in September 2013. The company's US unit, FCA US, previously reported a streak of monthly year-over-year sales gains from April 2010, but the revised numbers show a decline in August 2015 and May 2016. The revision affects 4,500 over-reported sales out of 7.7 million, and the company will now take into account vehicles that dealers report as sold.

images.alt_text: Facing federal probes over its reporting of US car sales, Fiat Chrysler on Tuesday announced revised numbers showing its previously-touted six-year streak of monthly gains actually ended three years ago.

site_title: Petrol glut worries hit US oil prices
summary: US oil prices dipped in New York, but rose in London, as high petrol supplies continued to pressure the market. Crude prices have declined over the last month, with US petrol supplies 11.4% above the year-ago level, according to the Department of Energy. The high supplies come despite the start of peak summer driving season in the US.

site_title: Debate ensues over the kind of startups S'pore needs
summary: A debate among industry players in Singapore centered on the type of startups the city-state needs. One camp advocated for "unicorns" and "deep science" startups, while the other emphasized the potential of information and communications technology (ICT) startups. Industry experts, including Lim Seow Hui and Shirley Wong, discussed the need for innovative startups and government support. The discussion also highlighted the challenges faced by startups, including scaling up and accessing investors.

site_title: Yahoo's identity crisis led to its demise - a decade in the making
summary: Yahoo's demise began in 2006 when senior executives gathered for a management retreat, revealing the company's identity crisis. Despite $1.9 billion in profit and lucrative advertising deals, staff's responses to "what Yahoo is associated with" ranged from mail to news to search, foreshadowing the company's decline. This internal struggle contributed to Yahoo's inability to adapt to the changing online landscape, ultimately leading to its demise.

site_title: Higher rental rates lift Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q1 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 6.8% year-on-year increase in first-quarter distributable amount to S$51.5 million, driven by higher rental income and occupancies. Revenue rose 3% to S$84.1 million, while net property income grew 6% to S$63.8 million. The group's CEO said the company is intensifying leasing efforts to retain tenants amid headwinds in the Singapore industrial market. MIT's balance sheet remains healthy, with a weighted average all-in funding cost of 2.5% and a low aggregate leverage ratio of 28.2%.

site_title: Soo Kee launches bullion business and new HQ at Changi Business Park
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Catalist-listed jeweller, launched its bullion business arm SK Bullion and opened its new corporate headquarters in Changi Business Park to celebrate its 25th anniversary. SK Bullion will provide trading, distribution, storage, and recycling services for precious metals, partnering with reputable mints and refineries. The company aims to leverage Singapore's favourable position in the global bullion industry, citing the absence of GST on precious metals investments and strong business infrastructure. The first SK Bullion store is set to open in August, with online services also available.

site_title: China insurers' worst habits go almost unchecked
summary: China's insurance regulator, the China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC), is warning of the industry's high-risk investments, including corporate raiding and large-scale deal-making. Insurers, such as Anbang Insurance, are offering high-yielding short-term products, leading to a mismatch between short-term products and longer-dated assets. The CIRC has taken steps to tighten risk controls, but concerns remain that insurers are creating a "dangerous mismatch" that could lead to financial instability.

site_title: Jinjiang Environment offers 92.42m IPO shares at S$0.90 each
summary: Jinjiang Environment Holding Company Ltd, a Chinese waste-to-energy operator, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for approximately 92.42 million new shares at S$0.90 each. The company aims to raise about S$184.3 million in gross proceeds to fund acquisitions, project investments, and debt repayment. A public offer opened on July 26 and will close on August 1, with shares expected to start trading on August 3.

site_title: Food for thought as ICS tackles big issues
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping's (ICS) 2016 International Shipping Conference will be held in London on September 7, featuring prominent speakers such as Kitack Lim, Ian Parry, and Esben Poulsson. The conference will address key issues including reducing carbon dioxide emissions, the Ballast Water Convention, and the impact of Brexit on the global shipping industry. Other topics include over-capacity in the shipping industry, seafarer supply issues, and tackling corruption. The conference aims to bring together shipowners' representatives to share ideas and test established positions on these contentious issues.

site_title: S'pore may overtake London in fintech amid Brexit fallout
summary: Singapore may surpass London as the global fintech capital due to the "Brexit" fallout, according to an MIT report. The report notes significant government support for fintech innovators in Singapore, dynamic incumbent banks, and access to the Asean region. However, London remains a strong contender, with progressive government policies and a dynamic workforce, and other hubs like New York and Boston are also gaining ground.

site_title: Rate cuts are better than negative rates
summary: Central banks' rate cuts can boost economic growth by encouraging borrowing through lower interest rates. However, this effect is limited by the role of confidence in borrowing. Lower rates can also reduce saving if savers receive lower returns, potentially leading to increased spending. In contrast, saving for specific long-term goals, such as buying a car or holiday, may be delayed due to reduced interest rates. The article concludes that rate cuts are generally more effective than negative rates in stimulating economic growth.

images.alt_text: Reducing interest rates will move money between different groups in society. Lower rates take income from people who have savings and give it to people who have debt.

site_title: Longer-term Abenomics targets recede further out of reach
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies have slipped further out of reach, with the goal of achieving nominal GDP of 600 trillion yen by fiscal 2020 now unachievable. The government has scaled back its short-term targets, including a 0.9% growth forecast for the current fiscal year and a 0.4% inflation forecast. Fiscal consolidation aims have also been stepped back, with a primary deficit of 10.5 trillion yen expected in fiscal 2018. The government is now projecting a primary deficit of around 5.5 trillion yen in fiscal 2020, despite Mr. Abe's pledge to maintain fiscal soundness by 2020.

site_title: Marijuana in edibles getting into Colorado children's hands: study
summary: A study published in JAMA Pediatrics found that marijuana exposure in young children in Colorado has increased 150% since 2014, when recreational marijuana products became legal. The rates of accidental exposure in children, many of them toddlers, have risen, with symptoms including lethargy, agitation, vomiting, and loss of balance. Researchers anticipate that rates of accidental exposure will continue to rise, with the effects being significant and preventable.

site_title: June new-home sales rise at fastest pace since Feb '08
summary: US new-home sales rose 3.5% in June to a 592,000 annualized pace, the fastest since February 2008, according to Commerce Department data. The median forecast was 560,000. Stable employment and low borrowing costs fueled steady gains in the residential real estate market. The median sales price of a new house increased 6.1% to $306,700, and the supply of homes decreased to 4.9 months, the lowest since February last year.

images.alt_text: Purchases of new US single-family homes rose in June to the highest level in more than eight years, indicating a firm housing market.

site_title: S$50m unauthorised investment by Mindef among lapses flagged by AG
summary: The Auditor-General's Office in Singapore has uncovered lapses in financial controls and governance of public funds, resulting in the loss of government revenue and raising concerns about governance practices. The report found that the Defence Ministry made a $50.26 million unauthorized investment without proper approval, and the Housing and Development Board failed to collect tolls at checkpoints, resulting in an under-collection of $13.93 million. Poor governance over public funds was also flagged, including Nanyang Polytechnic's dealings with a subsidiary and the Education Ministry's failure to monitor and enforce scholarship bonds.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: S$100m fund set aside to boost quality and standards ecosystem (Amended)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a budget of up to S$100 million to enhance Singapore's quality and standards (Q&S) ecosystem over the next five years. The fund will support small and medium-sized enterprises in standards adoption projects and spur innovation, playing a key role in the country's innovation-driven economy. Q&S will support market access and drive innovation, with Singapore participating in global standards conversations and developing new standards in emerging industries.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Treasuries glut swells to US$10t as deficits loom
summary: The US Treasury's budget deficit has surged to $10 trillion, prompting concerns among bond investors. Despite a peak of $1.4 trillion in 2009, the deficit has decreased due to government spending cuts and tax receipts. However, a sluggish economy has led to a six-year low in revenue growth, increasing borrowing needs. As a result, the US will likely sell more Treasuries to bridge the funding gap, putting pressure on investors. This development raises alarm among pundits, who cite negative yields, political risk, and the Federal Reserve as additional concerns.

site_title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child story already a US best-seller
summary: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, the eighth story in the series, has become the most pre-ordered book since 2007 in the US, surpassing Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. The script, published July 31, follows a grown-up Harry Potter 19 years after the events of the original series. It has been sold out through May 2017 and is expected to be the US company Barnes & Noble's biggest seller of 2016. The book's success is attributed to public demand, with midnight parties planned in stores across the nation.

site_title: Consumer-linked stocks help STI inch up
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) inched up 0.1% on Tuesday, driven by consumer-linked stocks such as Thai Beverage, Singtel, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and ComfortDelGro. The blue-chip index was led by these stocks, which accounted for 68% of total value traded, rather than banks. The market is awaiting the FOMC meeting and the BOJ's policy meeting, with investors expected to stay on the sidelines. A potential Donald Trump presidency is also drawing attention, with analysts predicting a negative impact on the region's growth outlook.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's DPU up 1% in Q1
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.03 Singapore cents in Q1, driven by positive contributions from VivoCity, Mapletree Anson, and PSA Building. The Reit's gross revenue rose 5.2% to S$73.38 million, with net property income increasing by 3.7% to S$56.28 million. MCT is proposing an offering of 727.7 million new units to raise at least S$1.02 billion to fund the acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 1).

site_title: Knocking on India's Smart Cities door
summary: Singapore companies are poised to participate in India's Smart Cities Mission, with over $16 billion worth of projects planned in 33 cities. The mission, launched in 2015, aims to modernize 98 Indian cities, focusing on infrastructure, ICT, and e-governance. With the government providing a framework for transparency and scalability, Singapore companies can explore business opportunities through public-private partnerships and pilot testing. Key cities for Singapore companies to consider include Jaipur, Pune, and Chennai, which align with the country's capabilities and interests. Despite challenges, the Smart Cities Mission offers a significant opportunity for Singapore companies to contribute to India's urban renewal efforts.

images.alt_text: A good start out of the 98 cities would be Jaipur, Pune and Chennai, which align quite well with Singapore's capabilities and interests.

site_title: Solar-powered plane completes historic round-the-world trip
summary: The Solar Impulse 2, a solar-powered plane, completed its historic round-the-world trip, traveling 42,000 km without a drop of fuel to promote renewable energy. The plane landed in Abu Dhabi on July 26, 2016, after a 48-hour flight from Cairo, marking a remarkable achievement in aviation history. Swiss explorer Bertrand Piccard, who led the project, praised the feat, saying it showed that renewable energy can achieve the impossible and that the future is clean. The plane's journey was marked by challenges, including bad weather and illness, but its completion has sparked hope for wider progress in clean energy.

site_title: Wild profit swings stand in way of Wilmar's consumer ambition
summary: Wilmar International's CEO Kuok Khoon Hong warned that extreme profit swings will hinder the company's goal to become a global consumer company. The company has experienced unexpected losses in its oilseeds and grains division, similar to a loss four years ago. Wilmar's earnings will be released on Aug 11, and the company's ability to achieve its consumer ambitions may be impacted by these fluctuations.

site_title: EM stocks turn out to be smart bets in post-Brexit times
summary: Emerging-market (EM) stocks have outperformed developed peers this year, driven by concerns over a hard landing in China and a troubled European Union. Despite geopolitical risks, EM stocks have seen a rebound in commodity prices and a surge in earnings, with 61% of companies reporting quarterly earnings above expectations. Analysts predict a 12% earnings growth for EM companies this year, followed by 14% in 2017, and expect developing stocks to rise 10% over the next year.

site_title: Yen reaches two-week high against euro
summary: The yen reached a two-week high against the euro and rose over 1% against the US dollar on Tuesday, driven by traders' reduced expectations of new stimulus from the Bank of Japan. Economists expect the BOJ to expand asset purchases and cut rates below zero. Japan's government is compiling a spending package worth up to 20 trillion yen, with direct fiscal stimulus potentially lower than expected. The yen's surge is also attributed to decreased pressure on the BOJ to ease monetary policy and market expectations being toned down.

site_title: Yahoo sale a cautionary tale of need to be nimble and innovative
summary: Yahoo's sale to Verizon for $4.8 billion marks the end of a pioneering company that was instrumental in organizing the World Wide Web in the early 1990s. Despite being a pioneer in internet search and online advertising, Yahoo has been playing catch-up with companies like Google and Facebook. The sale highlights the need for companies to stay nimble and innovative in today's fast-evolving technology world, where making big bets and taking risks is crucial. Companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Google have shown that staying ahead of the curve requires a growth mindset, adaptability, and a willingness to confront hubris and make changes when necessary.

site_title: 8Telecom unit set to revolutionise use of LTE networks
summary: Singapore's 8Telecom subsidiary Arete M is developing a technology to revolutionize LTE networks for industrial applications, including unmanned systems and robotics. The company aims to utilize the 1.79GHz-1.80GHz frequency spectrum to build dedicated, enterprise-grade private LTE networks for various industries. Arete M has conducted trials with the IDA and applied for spectrum rights, which could be approved soon. If successful, Arete M plans to showcase the world's first commercial dedicated LTE network and replicate the business model in other countries.

site_title: Hold Blair, Bush accountable for Iraq, Afghan wars
summary: The Chilcot report on the Iraq and Afghanistan wars reveals devastating humanitarian and economic consequences, including over 300,000 civilian deaths, 1.5 million displaced, and $4-6 trillion in costs. The wars led to global instability, financial boom and bust, and rising inequality. The largest portion of the US war bill remains unpaid, with the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs budgets set to increase further. The UK's estimated costs range from £30 billion to £200 billion. Families of British troops are seeking compensation for their loved ones, and politicians are calling for those responsible, including former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and US President George W Bush, to be held accountable.

site_title: McDonald's eyes US$400m for S'pore, Malaysia franchises
summary: McDonald's is planning to sell its 20-year franchise rights in Singapore and Malaysia for at least US$400 million. Suitors are seeking financing, with one potential bidder in talks for US$300 million in funding. The sale is part of McDonald's international turnaround plan, as the company revamps its ownership models in Asia. The chain aims to have 95% of its Asian restaurants under local ownership, with currently around 370 outlets in the two markets. A development licensee model will be used, with local partners helping accelerate growth and innovation.

site_title: Currency trading rises from Tokyo to New York on policy bumps
summary: Currency trading surged across major global centers from Tokyo to New York, rising 5% from October to $2.21 trillion in the UK, $893 billion in North America, and 5.1-6% in Japan and Australia. The surge was attributed to monetary policy whiplash, particularly after the Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve decisions caught traders off guard. The yen strengthened, driven by haven demand and its undervaluation, while dollar-yen trading and currency forwards exposure increased, coinciding with higher price swings and volatility.

site_title: UK borrowing expected to rise materially next year
summary: The UK is expected to borrow nearly £65 billion more than planned in the next couple of years due to the post-Brexit economic uncertainty. Finance minister Philip Hammond has announced a "reset" of government budget policy to ease the shock of the EU vote, leading to a rise in borrowing for the first time since 2010. Economists predict that borrowing this tax year and next will be almost £65 billion above forecast, with some estimating it could be even higher. Hammond plans to consider stimulus measures, with long-term public investment seen as the most effective option.

site_title: Mandai masterplan tweaked to lower impact on environment (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Mandai wildlife and nature destination masterplan has been revised to minimize environmental impact. The relocated Bird Park and new Rainforest Park will be built on a 35-hea plot, with the Rainforest Park in the north to integrate mature trees into its design. The Bird Park will be built on the southern parcel. Other changes include combining educational facilities into a single building, decentralizing entry points, and establishing buffer zones to reduce construction impact on nature reserves. The revised plan aims to achieve low residual impact on the environment.

site_title: Businesses unfazed by hike in EP qualifying pay
summary: Singapore businesses remain unfazed by the recent hike in the qualifying salary for Employment Pass (EP) applications, having anticipated the change. However, associations have expressed concerns that the increase will lead to higher business costs and potentially shift employment to multinationals, affecting smaller businesses and their pay bandwidths.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: India central bank governor defends inflation record, urges independence
summary: India's outgoing Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor, Raghuram Rajan, defended his record in curbing inflation and cleaning up bad debt at banks, urging the government to protect the central bank's independence. Rajan rejected criticism that keeping interest rates high contributed to his decision to leave, citing the need for central banks to make the case for their policies. He warned that cutting rates aggressively would lead to losing control of inflation, and expressed caution about cutting rates further.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India's outgoing governor, Raghuram Rajan, on Tuesday staunchly defended his record in curbing inflation and cleaning up bad debt at banks, and he called on the government to protect the central bank's independence.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS is expected to report a net profit of S$1,011 million in Q2 2016, down 16% from Q1 2016, with stable net interest margin and year-on-year growth in fees. The bank's digital transformation is expected to improve customer experience and fend off fintechs. CNMC Goldmine Holdings is expected to benefit from the acquisition of 51% of Pulai Mining Sdn Bhd, with further upside from operational synergies and lower execution risk.

site_title: Wanda boss heads for record M&A year with US$16b in deals
summary: Wang Jianlin, a Chinese billionaire, is on track for a record year of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) with over $16 billion in deals. His company, AMC Entertainment Holdings, has raised its offer for Carmike Cinemas Inc, and he is also seeking to buy Paramount Pictures and expand his entertainment empire. This push is driven by China's shift to a consumption-driven economy and a growing middle class, aiming to create a $200 billion market capitalization and $100 billion annual sales by the end of the decade.

site_title: India earmarks 80b rupees to accelerate LPG adoption
summary: India's government has earmarked 80 billion rupees to accelerate the adoption of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) by providing free connections to women from families living below the poverty line. The goal is to increase penetration to 80% over three years, aiming to reduce premature deaths from household air pollution. However, experts warn that inadequate infrastructure and land acquisition issues may hinder the push, requiring investments of 100 billion rupees to build new plants and expand existing ones.

site_title: BlackRock: Brace for much lower returns over the next five years
summary: BlackRock predicts investors will struggle to achieve double-digit returns over the next five years, with only private equity and emerging-market equities expected to exceed 6%. Most fixed income assets, including US Treasuries, are forecast to lose 1% annually. Only 10% of global fixed income securities are expected to have returns above 3%. Emerging-market debt is seen as a riskier but potentially more lucrative option, while gold could provide diversification benefits.

images.alt_text: Blackrock foresees only private equity and emerging-market equities cracking 6 per cent, annualised, over a five-year frame.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands Q2 earnings dip 1.7% to US$357m
summary: Marina Bay Sands reported a 1.7% dip in Q2 earnings to US$357 million, despite lower table game revenue and softer gaming volumes in Singapore. Growth in slot revenues and resilience in room rates and mall revenues contributed to the adjusted property ebitda figure. The company's hotel occupancy increased, but average daily rates dropped, leading to a marginally higher revenue per available room. Las Vegas Sands chairman Sheldon Adelson expressed optimism about the company's future, despite missing analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Sands saw its Q2 profit for the three months ended June 30 slip 1.7 per cent year on year to US$357 million as earnings were impacted by lower table game revenue.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: New York's first zoning resolution turns 100
summary: New York City's first Zoning Resolution, enacted on July 25, 1916, aimed to regulate building height, size, and arrangement to address issues of light, air, and fire safety. The law, drafted by George McAneny and Edward Bassett, established zoning zones with specific height restrictions, such as a 1:1 ratio between building height and street width. The resolution was a pioneering planning document that checked the influence of development on residential areas and business districts, and it remains an important milestone in New York City's urban planning history.

site_title: Slightly higher oil prices in H2 as oversupply eases: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has raised its forecast for crude oil prices to $43 per barrel in 2016 due to supply outages and robust demand in the second quarter. However, the bank expects prices of other commodities, such as gold and other metals, to decline this year due to elevated supplies and weak growth prospects.

images.alt_text: The World Bank has again raised its forecast for oil prices in coming months, although only modestly compared with the dramatic recovery seen in the early part of this year.

site_title: S'pore industrial output dips 0.3% in June as biomed contracts
summary: Singapore's industrial output contracted 0.3% in June, despite a 19.7% increase in the electronics cluster, driven by semiconductor output growth. Economists attributed the mixed result to Brexit uncertainty and weak biomedical output, which fell 10.2% year-on-year. The electronics cluster's growth is seen as a sign of a recovering US semiconductor sector, but economists remain cautious due to the Brexit impact on global growth prospects.

site_title: No shit, there's a museum for that
summary: A museum dedicated to excrement, the National Poo Museum, has opened in southern England at the Isle of Wight Zoo. The exhibit, created by a group of artists, features 20 examples of faeces from various animals suspended in clear resin and illuminated by touch. The museum was born out of a fascination with the public's reaction to animal droppings, which sparked intrigue rather than disgust. The exhibit will be open until the end of the summer and will then go on tour, providing a unique and interactive experience for visitors.

site_title: Indonesia president expected to announce cabinet reshuffle on Wed: sources
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is expected to announce his second cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday, according to sources. The reshuffle comes nearly a year after Widodo replaced key members of his economics team. The identities of the ministers to be replaced have not been disclosed, and the announcement is set for Wednesday, following a meeting between Widodo and cabinet ministers late on Tuesday.

site_title: VW plans new fix proposal for 3.0 litre vehicles: Justice Dept
summary: Volkswagen plans to submit a new proposal to fix 85,000 polluting 3.0 litre vehicles, after regulators rejected an earlier plan. The German automaker is meeting with regulators and aims to offer a new fix proposal in August. A US$10.033 billion proposed settlement with owners, including a $5,100 compensation for each vehicle, is still under consideration by US District Judge Charles Breyer, who will review the new proposal at an August 25 court hearing.

site_title: Mainland Chinese underpin HK luxury rents: Savills
summary: Mainland Chinese are driving up luxury rents in Hong Kong due to slashed expatriate housing budgets in the financial industry. Vacancies remain low, with popular budgets ranging from HK$40,000 to HK$100,000 per month. This shift is attributed to mainlanders seeking high-end apartments, typically wealthy professionals or business owners. Housing allowances for Hong Kong-based finance and banking expats have decreased by 40% since 2012, leading to increased demand from mainlanders.

site_title: Yoma posts Q1 profit fall; hopeful of progress in Myanmar
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, which operates KFC and real estate businesses in Myanmar, posted a 28.6% drop in net profit for the first quarter due to lower gross profit and weaker revenue. Despite the decline, the company remains optimistic about progress in Myanmar, citing the new government's efforts to tackle economic development and national reconciliation. Yoma has signed a new master lease for its Landmark Development in Yangon, with works expected to begin by the end of the year.

site_title: Sun Hung Kai slices margins to push sales, beats target
summary: Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, Hong Kong's largest developer, beat its residential sales target in the first half of the year, selling 1,438 units worth HK$18.7 billion. However, the company sacrificed profit margins, which halved to 20% from 40% in the same period. This was achieved through discounts, tax rebates, and mortgages as high as 120%. The company's shares rose 1% to HK$110.90, despite overall property volumes declining 35% in the six months ended June.

site_title: Swiber's reply to queries draws flak from critics
summary: Swiber Holdings' response to Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries on recent disclosures and a BT report has sparked criticism. The company stated its newbuild heavylift vessel, Kaizen 4000, was intended for a $21 million contract that was unilaterally terminated by the client. This was the first time Swiber disclosed the contract value, previously announced in an SGX filing. Critics, including NUS Business School's associate professor Mak Yuen Teen, question the timeliness of these disclosures.

site_title: Museum sketches bright future for art in Indonesia
summary: A new museum, the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art in Nusantara (MACAN), is set to open in Indonesia, promising to boost the country's art scene. Funded by businessman Haryanto Adikoesoemo, the 4,000 square meter venue will feature a collection of over 800 pieces by Indonesian, Asian, and Western artists. The museum will also include an indoor sculpture garden and a special education zone, aiming to create a platform for cultural exchanges and emerging artists. With Thomas Berghuis as director, MACAN is expected to address Indonesia's lack of high-quality art museums and provide opportunities for young professionals in the arts.

site_title: Negative interest rates force Japan pension fund to adopt riskier investment strategy
summary: Japan's National Federation of Mutual Aid Association for Municipal Personnel is considering adopting a riskier investment strategy due to negative interest rates, which have pushed the Nomura-BPI index yield below zero. The pension fund, managing about 11 trillion yen, may buy more regional government bonds and state-backed organisations' debt to boost returns. The Bank of Japan's negative-rate policy has led to headaches for fund managers, prompting some to consider deviating from benchmark allocations and measuring performance based on total returns.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: PARKWAY Life Reit reported a 10.2% fall in distribution per unit for the second quarter due to the absence of a one-off distribution of divestment gain. StarHub is considering selling its Qatari-owned shareholding, with HSBC Holdings working to gauge potential interest. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: BlackBerry unveils second, cheaper, Android device
summary: BlackBerry unveiled the DTEK50, its second Android device, priced at $299 in the US, Canada, and Europe. The device aims to sell better than its predecessor, the Priv, which was criticized for its high price. The Priv's price was lowered earlier, and BlackBerry has also discontinued its Classic handset. A third Android device is expected from the company soon. This move is part of BlackBerry's strategy to make its devices more accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: Americans worry about 'super-human' technologies: poll
summary: A poll by the Pew Research Center found that Americans are more concerned than enthusiastic about emerging technologies that could enhance human capabilities, such as gene-editing, brain implants, and synthetic blood. 68% of respondents expressed worry about gene-editing, 69% about brain implants, and 63% about synthetic blood. Only about one-third of respondents expressed enthusiasm for brain and blood enhancements. Many Americans fear these technologies could exacerbate social divides and are uncertain about their availability.

site_title: Scientists shine a light on an ancient organism that died 4b years ago
summary: Scientists have identified an ancient organism that died 4 billion years ago, shedding light on the origins of life on Earth. The discovery was first proposed by Charles Darwin in his 1859 book On the Origin of Species, suggesting that all life descended from a single primordial form. While the discovery confirms the existence of an ancient ancestor, it does not answer the question of whether it was the first life on Earth or simply a lucky occurrence. The findings provide new insights into the early history of life on our planet.

site_title: Sustainability reporting: going beyond basics in deliberations, decisions
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced sustainability reporting guidelines that will take effect for financial years ending on or after December 31, 2017, on a "comply or explain" basis. The guidelines highlight five primary components: material environment, social and governance factors, policies and practices, targets, and a board statement. The requirements strike a balance between reporting goals and administrative burden, offering flexibility in areas such as verification of material ESG factors and time allowance for reporting. The guidelines aim to promote economic sustainability in Singapore, aligning with international benchmarks and increasing stakeholder expectations for businesses to address social and environmental concerns.

site_title: Overseas buyers of Vancouver homes face additional tax
summary: Canada plans to tax overseas investors buying homes in Vancouver, with a 15% additional property-transfer tax starting August 2. The tax applies to foreign nationals and overseas corporations, affecting a C$1 billion influx of foreign money in the area. The tax aims to slow price gains in the city, which saw C$1 billion invested in residential property in five weeks. The city of Vancouver can also impose a new tax on empty homes, while the province is amending legislation to end real estate industry self-regulation.

site_title: S$100m budget to enhance Singapore's quality and standards ecosystem: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced a S$100 million budget over five years to enhance Singapore's Quality & Standards (Q&S) ecosystem, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises through standards adoption projects. This initiative aims to improve the country's quality and standards ecosystem, with the goal of promoting a more competitive and innovative business environment.

images.alt_text: THE government will set aside a budget of S$100 million over the next five years to enhance Singapore's Quality & Standards (Q&S) ecosystem.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Taiwan to launch controversial probe into party assets
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen is launching a probe into the assets of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party, citing concerns over its vast wealth and alleged ill-gotten gains. The move comes after Tsai took power in May, marking a shift away from China. The KMT, considered one of the richest parties in the world, has faced questions about its origins and wealth. Critics accuse the party of stealing from the people and amassing fortunes through business links. The probe is seen as a major blow to the KMT and deepens divisions between Taiwan's main parties.

site_title: Malaysia to implement B10 biodiesel mandate later in 2016, not in July
summary: Malaysia has delayed its implementation of a B10 biodiesel mandate, initially expected in July, but still aims to raise the minimum bio-content to 10% this year. Talks with oil companies are ongoing, and no further details on the implementation timeline are available. The delay may impact benchmark palm oil futures, which reached 10-month lows earlier this month. The B10 programme aims to increase demand for palm oil and mop up more palm oil for blending purposes.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's plans for a higher biodiesel mandate for the transport sector will not be implemented in July as initially expected, although the country said it remained committed to raise the minimum bio-content to 10 per cent this year.

site_title: US consumer confidence steady in July
summary: US consumer confidence remained steady in July at 97.3, above the 91.0 level from last year, but below the 12-month high of 101.3. The increase in consumer views of the current economy situation contributed to the stable confidence level, despite global concerns over Britain's vote to leave the EU.

site_title: UK government to open 3 new offices in US to boost trade: minister
summary: The UK government plans to open three new offices in the US, in Minneapolis, Raleigh, and San Diego, to boost trade and economic ties following Brexit. The offices will promote British business and tap into the cities' established research and development institutions. This move is part of the UK's "open and outward-looking" economy vision, aiming to grow trade and investment in key markets worldwide.

site_title: Casio enters luxury watch market
summary: Casio has entered the luxury watch market with the launch of a limited-edition G-Shock MR-G timepiece, the MRG-G1000HT, to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the MR-G series. The watch retails for S$8,888 and signals Casio's expansion into the premium timepiece market. The company aims to differentiate its watches through cutting-edge technology and marketing strategy, while maintaining its trademark durability and traditional Japanese craftsmanship. A limited run of 300 watches will be sold worldwide.

images.alt_text: A limited run of 300 pieces of MRG-G1000HT will be sold worldwide; in Singapore, the watch retails for S$8,888.

site_title: Cogent granted extension of master tenancy at The Grandstand to 2020
summary: Cogent Holdings has been granted an extension of its master tenancy at The Grandstand in Singapore until December 31, 2020, from March 1, 2018. The current tenancy was set to expire on February 28, 2018. The Singapore Land Authority agreed to the extension, which will allow the company to continue operating at the venue.

site_title: US new home sales rise to near 8-1/2-year high in June
summary: US single-family home sales rose 3.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 592,000 units in June, the highest level in nearly 8-1/2 years. This marks a 25.4% increase from the same period last year. The housing market is gaining momentum, with home resales reaching a near 9-1/2-year high in June and single-family housing starts increasing solidly in June. The sales boost is attributed to tightening labor market conditions and low mortgage rates, as well as a persistent shortage of previously owned houses available for sale.

site_title: Swiss to pass information on HSBC accounts to US tax agency
summary: Switzerland has agreed to share information about HSBC accounts held by US citizens with the US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) as part of a US investigation into tax evasion. HSBC's Swiss unit has paid tens of millions of dollars in fines for substandard compliance, and the Swiss government will notify account holders and allow them to lodge a legal appeal if they object to having their information sent to the US. The move follows an IRS request for assistance on HSBC accounts held by Swiss-registered "domiciliary companies" with US beneficial owners between 2002 and 2014.

site_title: 1MDB advises caution on financial statements
summary: 1MDB, a Malaysian development fund, advises caution on its 2013 and 2014 financial statements due to US prosecutors' allegations of $3.5 billion misappropriation. The company's auditor, Deloitte LLP, is resigning and seeking a replacement. 1MDB denies wrongdoing, but as a precaution, its directors recommend not relying on the audited financial statements until a court's final determination. The allegations are part of international investigations into alleged corruption and money laundering by public officials in several countries, including the US, Singapore, Switzerland, and Luxembourg.

site_title: Bank of England to cut key rate Aug 4, hold off on QE for now: Reuters poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to cut benchmark borrowing costs on August 4, with a slim majority of economists predicting no restart of its asset purchase programme. The decision comes after the Brexit referendum in June, which led to market volatility and calls for monetary policy easing. The Monetary Policy Committee members' minutes from the June meeting showed a majority believed looser policy was likely needed at the August meeting. The move aims to stabilize the economy amidst uncertainty.

site_title: Collaboration, education key to Singapore's 'Smart Nation' future
summary: Singapore's focus on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is crucial for its "Smart Nation" future, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The country has seen rapid technological advancements, with industry giants and startups benefiting from increased research investments and patents. However, a lack of highly skilled STEM workers is a significant threat, with 40% of Singaporean companies citing this as a major concern. To address this, the government, industry, and educators must collaborate to cultivate a society that understands and embraces new technologies, involve STEM businesses in education, and encourage diversity of talent.

images.alt_text: There is a growing understanding of science and technology among the new generation. A recent OECD study reports that younger Singaporeans have an above-average proficiency in technology-rich environments.

site_title: US stocks flat ahead of Fed meeting, Apple earnings
summary: US stocks remained flat on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's two-day policy meeting and Apple's earnings release. Apple shares fell 0.3% after its first decline in sales in 13 years. Analysts expect the Fed to keep interest rates low, but some predict a signal of potential rate hikes later in the year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all rose less than 0.1%.

site_title: EU privacy watchdogs keep open mind on new US data pact
summary: EU privacy watchdogs will allow the new EU-US Privacy Shield framework to run for at least a year without legal challenge. The new pact, which replaced the struck-down Safe Harbour framework, allows companies to transfer personal data from the EU to the US. Regulators will review the framework annually and assess the legality of alternative mechanisms used by companies in the meantime. EU data protection authorities had demanded improvements to the Privacy Shield, and regulators will investigate any complaints from individuals about the framework's functioning on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Brooklyn developer Leser Group taps Israeli market for 125m shekel bond issue
summary: Brooklyn developer Leser Group Ltd is issuing 125 million shekels (S$44.1 million) of bonds in Israel, yielding 6.6% after receiving double the expected demand from institutional investors. The move comes as the market reopened after Canadian developer Urbancorp's default in April, and US firms have raised at least $2.8 billion in Israel since 2008 due to cheaper financing costs. Leser's chairman, Abraham Leser, is well-known to Israeli investors, making it easier for the company to access the market.

site_title: London mayor seeks more powers to protect post-Brexit city
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan commissioned a study to draw up a list of devolution demands to protect the city's economy after Brexit. The vote threatens to send Britain's economy into recession, impacting London's world-leading financial services industry. Khan wants more policy tools to steer the capital's economy effectively, citing a previous study that recommended devolving property taxes and allowing greater infrastructure investment. Khan has held talks with finance minister Philip Hammond, who is open to further devolution for London, and an academic believes devolution would be beneficial for the city and relieve pressure on the UK government.

site_title: US says looking at more counter-terrorism cooperation with China
summary: The US is exploring ways to increase counter-terrorism cooperation with China, including information exchanges and stability efforts in Iraq. This comes after a US State Department report criticized China's lack of transparency on terrorism incidents. China has urged Western nations to help combat Islamist extremists in its Xinjiang region, but has faced reluctance due to concerns over human rights abuses. US National Security Adviser Susan Rice discussed the issue with Chinese officials, recognizing the threat of international terrorism and the need for cooperation.

site_title: Swiss get "largely compliant" rating for tax assistance: finance ministry
summary: Switzerland has received an "largely compliant" rating from an international review of its tax information sharing with other countries. This marks a crucial recognition of the country's efforts to shed its reputation as a haven for tax evasion. Switzerland is now on the same level as countries like Singapore, Liechtenstein, and the US in terms of tax transparency, with its financial centre being the world's largest for managing offshore wealth.

site_title: Better margins, higher revenue boost Sheng Siong's Q2 results
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singapore supermarket operator, reported a 11.3% increase in net profit to S$15.17 million in its second quarter ended June 30, 2016, driven by higher revenue and improved margins. Revenue rose 5.5% to S$188.76 million, with gross margins increasing to 26.1% due to suppliers' rebates and cost reductions. The company opened three new stores and saw same-store sales rise 1.3%. Earnings per share and dividend per share also increased.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, former banker sued over Malaysian bank takeover
summary: Goldman Sachs and former banker Tim Leissner were sued by private equity fund Primus Pacific Partners 1 LP for allegedly hiding conflicts of interest while advising Malaysian bank EON Capital Bhd. The takeover, completed in May 2011, was valued at US$1.7 billion. The fund claims the duo betrayed their duties to curry favor with Malaysia's prime minister. This is the latest in a series of regulatory issues for Goldman Sachs, which has faced criticism for its role in the 1MDB scandal. The lawsuit seeks damages for breach of fiduciary duty.

site_title: Elderly priest killed in French church, attack claimed by Islamic State
summary: An elderly priest, Father Jacques Hamel, was killed with a knife in a church attack in Saint-Etienne-du-Rouvray, France, on Tuesday. The attackers, linked to Islamic State, also took five hostages, with one seriously wounded. Both attackers were shot dead by French police. French President Francois Hollande described the attack as a "dreadful terrorist attack" and pledged to use all means to combat the militant group. The attack is the latest in a string of deadly assaults in Europe, with many linked to Islamist militants and IS.

site_title: Strong will on both sides to preserve common travel between UK and Ireland: May
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated that there is a strong will to preserve the common travel area between the UK and Ireland following the Brexit vote. May emphasized the importance of maintaining the peace process in Northern Ireland and securing a deal in the interests of both countries. She also acknowledged the long-standing benefit of the common travel area, which predated the UK's EU membership.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,933.44 on Tuesday, ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting. However, the broader market saw a net loss of 42 stocks, with 209 losing value compared to 167 gaining. Trading volume was 1.11 billion shares worth S$1.03 billion. The market awaits the FOMC meeting on July 26-27 and the release of Singapore's GDP data.

site_title: China-Philippines should 'turn page' on sea row: Kerry
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry urged the Philippines and China to "turn the page" and engage in talks over the South China Sea, following a tribunal's invalidation of Beijing's claims to the strategic waterway. Kerry's call comes after Beijing refused to recognize the UN-backed ruling, and relations between the two countries have been strained. Kerry's visit to Manila aims to facilitate dialogue and negotiations, and follows a request from his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi to move away from public tensions.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to raise US$775m in new unit offering: IFR
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) plans to raise up to US$775 million through a private placement and preferential offering, issuing 364.9 million and 362.8 million new units respectively. The funds will be used to finance the purchase of a business park in Singapore valued at S$1.78 billion. The trust will offer units at an indicative price range of S$1.41 to S$1.45 and S$1.39 to S$1.43 for existing unit holders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,661.42, down 6.84 points, with 1.4 billion lots valued at RM1.56 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 294 to 448. The article does not mention any specific events or factors that influenced the market's decline.

site_title: Taiwan to launch controversial party assets probe
summary: Taiwan's government plans to launch an investigation into the ill-gotten assets of political parties, a move opposed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as persecution. The investigation comes after Beijing-sceptic President Tsai Ing-wen took power in May, marking a shift in relations with China. The move is likely to deepen divisions between Taiwan's main parties and further strain ties with Beijing.

site_title: Increase in US home prices falls short of expectations
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.2% in May from the prior year, falling short of the expected 5.5% increase. This marks the first decline in home prices since January. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller composite index retreated from the previous month's 5.4% gain. Despite this, housing is considered "doing quite well" according to David Blitzer, managing director and chairman of the index committee. The decline in home prices may be attributed to various factors, but overall, the housing market remains strong.

images.alt_text: US single-family home prices rose less than expected on an annual basis in May, and were down from the prior month, a survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end up as casino plays surge
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.62% on Tuesday, driven by a surge in casino shares, with the Hang Seng Index ending at 22,129.73. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also advanced, rising 1.14% and 1.25% respectively. The rally came as investors await key central bank meetings in the US and Japan, despite uncertainty over tariffs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Auditor-General's Office reported 'inadequate financial controls' in several government agencies, including the Housing and Development Board (HDB) and Land Transport Authority (LTA), resulting in lost revenue to the Government. The Ministry of Manpower raised the base salary of Employment Pass to S$3,600 from January 1, 2017. Ooredoo is considering selling its stake in StarHub, while McDonald's plans to sell its Malaysia and Singapore franchises for at least US$400 million. Singapore shares closed 0.1% higher, and the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting is expected to impact the market.

site_title: Britain's RBS warns customers of possible charges on deposits
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has warned over 1.3 million business customers that they may face charges on deposits if interest rates drop below zero, potentially becoming the first British bank to introduce negative interest rates. The Bank of England is set to cut interest rates to a record low next week, prompting RBS to issue the warning. The bank has no immediate plans to impose such charges but could take action if the base rate enters negative territory, following a trend seen in six other central banks worldwide.

site_title: BBR Holdings wins S$57.6m contract for modular housing
summary: BBR Holdings has secured a S$57.6 million contract to design, fabricate, deliver, and install modular housing for four blocks along Upper Aljunied Road in Singapore. The 18-month project will be carried out by BBR's subsidiary, Moderna Homes. There is no material impact on the company's financial year ending December 31, 2016, and none of the directors or substantial shareholders have an interest in the contract. The contract was detailed in a filing to the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday evening.

site_title: China wind power increases along with turbines standing still
summary: China's wind power output rose 8.5% to 140 gigawatts in the first six months of 2016, but idle turbines increased by the same amount, averaging 917 hours of generation. This has led to a focus on the efficiency of investments and the grid's ability to absorb renewable power. Despite having double the installed wind capacity of the US, China is producing less electricity from turbines. The National Energy Administration is studying ways to cut idle capacity in renewables over the next five to 10 years.

site_title: Two knifemen take several hostages in French church: police sources
summary: Two men armed with knives took several people hostage in a church in France's northern Normandy region on Tuesday. The hostages included a priest, two nuns, and two worshippers. Police sources reported that between four and six people were being held by the assailants, while live TV images showed police blocking off roads and paramedics attending to the scene. The situation remains unresolved, with authorities working to secure the hostages.

site_title: AB InBev sweetens its offer for SABMiller to £79b
