The extension is part of a broader plan to link the airport to the Cross Island Line (CRL) and the proposed Singapore terminus of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail.

site_title: New Zealand shares hit new highs, Australia joins rally
summary: New Zealand shares reached new highs, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 33.5 points to 5522.3, driven by positive overseas leads and expectations of monetary easing. Australian shares also gained, while gold miners weighed on the index. Key gainers included Cochlear Ltd, CSL Ltd, and Xero, while New Zealand Refining was the biggest loser. The benchmark has gained 0.61% in morning trade and has traded in positive territory for 10 of the past 11 sessions.

site_title: Hot stock: SMRT resumes trading 8% up after Temasek's offer
summary: SMRT Corp shares rose 8% on Thursday after Temasek Holdings' proposed S$1.2 billion buyout of the transport operator. The counter closed at S$1.645, up 10 Singapore cents or 6.5% from its last traded price of S$1.545. The takeover offer values SMRT at S$2.57 billion, representing an 8.7% premium over its last traded price.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: No closure in sight, MH370 investigators brace for unthinkable
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in 2014 with 239 people on board, remains unrecovered after a two-year search in the southern Indian Ocean. Despite scouring an area roughly the size of Delaware, investigators have found no wreckage. Scientists now question the assumption that the plane ran out of fuel and spiralled into the ocean, suggesting someone may have controlled the aircraft's glide into the water. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau has narrowed the search area to 120,000 square kilometers, and transport ministers are set to meet to assess the A$180 million operation, with no plans to extend the search beyond this area.

site_title: Vickers raises S$86m in first close of what is set to be largest VC fund in S'pore (Amended)
summary: Vickers Venture Partners, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, has raised S$86 million in its first close of the fifth Vickers Venture Fund, with a target size of S$340 million. This fund is set to be the largest raised by a Singapore-based VC firm. Existing investors, including global banks and family offices, are reviewing the fund. Vickers will start investing from the fund even as it completes its fund-raising process over the next 12 months.

site_title: Rich countries often fail to bolster well-being: Boston Consulting
summary: A report by the Boston Consulting Group finds that many wealthy countries are failing to convert economic growth into improved well-being for their citizens. Despite global economic growth trending downward, countries like Ethiopia and Norway excel in converting growth into well-being. Wealthy nations like Switzerland, Sweden, and Singapore also perform well, while emerging markets in Asia and Africa rise to the top. The report highlights the importance of financial inclusion, governance, and environmental regulations in improving well-being.

site_title: US chases penthouses and Beverly Hills mansions in 1MDB lawsuit
summary: The US government is seeking to seize over $1 billion in assets, including Manhattan and Beverly Hills properties, as part of an investigation into the alleged misappropriation of $3.5 billion from Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) fund. The assets linked to alleged corrupt officials, including Riza Aziz and Jho Low, include a 64-ft-long penthouse, a mansion in Beverly Hills with a pyramid in the indoor pool, and a private jet. The US Justice Department alleges that money was diverted through shell companies, checks, wire transfers, and accounts with major banks.

images.alt_text: The US government is trying to seize 11 pieces of real estate as part of an investigation into the alleged misappropriation of US$3.5 billion (S$4.7 billion) from Malaysian state fund, 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), according to a court filing on Wednesday by the US Justice Department.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SMRT, Olam, Vard, Keppel T&T
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings proposes a S$1.2 billion buyout of rail operator SMRT at S$1.68 per share, valuing the company at S$2.57 billion. Olam International issues US$500 million in subordinated perpetual securities, while Vard Holdings reports a net loss of 53 million kroner due to restructuring costs. Keppel Telecommunications and Transportation (Keppel T&T) posts an 18.5% rise in net profit to S$18.81 million for the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ted Cruz booed for failing to endorse Donald Trump
summary: Ted Cruz was booed at the Republican convention in Cleveland after refusing to endorse Donald Trump, despite being asked to do so. Cruz's speech, in which he advocated for leaders who "stand for principle" and "cast aside anger for love," was met with jeers and yells of anger from the crowd. Trump later entered the arena, forcing Cruz to wave and exit before completing his remarks. The incident marked a dramatic twist in the tumultuous relationship between the two men, who clashed in a bitter primary campaign.

site_title: Los Angeles airport approves Delta terminal plan
summary: Delta Air Lines' $1.9 billion plan to upgrade its Los Angeles International Airport terminals has been approved by the airport's Board of Airport Commissioners. The carrier will relocate from terminals 5 and 6 to terminals 2 and 3 over the next seven years. Delta will invest $350 million in the project, connecting the terminals and improving passenger experience.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines Inc said its US$1.9 billion plan to upgrade its terminals at Los Angeles International Airport were approved by the airport on Wednesday.

site_title: China eyes eight cruise ships to serve South China Sea
summary: China plans to launch cruises to the South China Sea over the next five years, with up to eight ships serving the disputed waters. A joint venture will buy and build ships, and four cruise liner docks will be constructed in Sanya, China. The ships will visit the Crescent group of islands, and the company is considering a cruise around the South China Sea. The move aims to promote tourism to the area, but it remains unclear if foreigners will be allowed on these cruises or if they will be able to visit China's holdings in the South China Sea.

site_title: Oil prices rebound on US stockpiles data
summary: US oil prices rebounded from two-month lows on Wednesday after the US Department of Energy reported a 2.3 million barrel drop in crude inventories, offsetting a surprise rise in gasoline inventories. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for August delivery rose 29 US cents to $44.94 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The inventory data countered bearish market sentiment amid concerns over US President Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries.

site_title: Protesters clash with police outside Republican convention
summary: Protesters clashed with police outside the Republican convention in Cleveland, Ohio, on Wednesday after a group attempted to burn an American flag. The protesters, affiliated with the Revolution Club, were quickly dispersed by police in riot gear, with 17 people arrested, including two charged with felonies. Two officers suffered minor injuries. The incident occurred before Vice President Mike Pence's speech, and the city has been largely peaceful despite recent security concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares get tech boost as SAP and ASML surge on results
summary: European shares advanced on Wednesday, driven by a surge in technology stocks. SAP and ASML reported forecast-beating quarterly results, with SAP's operating profit rising 9% and ASML advancing 3%. The STOXX Europe 600 Technology index rose 3.2%, contributing to a 1% gain for the pan-European STOXX 600 index. However, mining companies were hit, with Anglo American and BHP Billiton sliding 4.8% and 2.3%, respectively.

site_title: Japan preparing US$190b stimulus, govt spending less than half that: sources
summary: Japan is preparing a US$190 billion economic stimulus package, with a headline figure of 20 trillion yen (S$250 billion), to revive its flagging economy. Actual government spending is expected to be less than half that amount, with direct spending estimated at over 3 trillion yen. The package, announced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will include measures to support the economy, such as speeding up the completion of maglev train networks. Negotiations between parties in Abe's ruling coalition may lead to an expansion of the package, which is set to be approved by the cabinet on August 2.

images.alt_text: The Japanese government is preparing a package of economic stimulus measures totalling US$190 billion or more, though actual government spending is likely to be less than half that amount, sources involved in the process said on Thursday.

site_title: Lower revenue, restructuring costs drag down Vard's Q2 results
summary: Vard Holdings reported a net loss of 53 million kroner (S$8.46 million) for Q2 2016 due to lower revenue and restructuring costs. Revenue declined 11% year-over-year to 2.22 billion kroner, primarily affected by European yards and Vard Niteroi in Brazil. The company incurred 38 million kroner in restructuring costs, including statutory payments and termination benefits. This led to an operating loss of 78 million kroner and a net loss of 16 million kroner for the half-year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: French lawmakers vote to extend state of emergency
summary: French lawmakers voted to extend the state of emergency for six months after a truck driver killed 84 people in a Nice attack, France's third major attack in 18 months. The state of emergency, which was initially set to expire on July 26, will now run until January. The government has proposed new security measures, including a National Guard, and has called for volunteers in the reserve forces to bolster security. The extension was approved by 489 to 26 in the lower house of parliament and 309 to 26 in the upper house.

site_title: Merkel accepts Britain's decision to delay triggering Brexit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and British Prime Minister Theresa May agreed that Britain needs time to prepare for EU exit negotiations, with no invocation of Article 50 before the end of 2016. May stated her government would not seek to leave the EU before the end of 2016 to plan a "sensible and orderly departure." Merkel emphasized the importance of Britain having a well-defined position before negotiations begin.

site_title: Yen falls but euro steady vs US dollar ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The Japanese yen fell 0.7% to 106.87 against the US dollar, while the euro held steady at 117.72 yen, ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting. The yen has lost 6% against the US dollar since July 8 due to Japan's weak economy. The euro-US dollar rate remained steady at 1.1016, with speculation that ECB chief Mario Draghi may hint at more stimulus action.

site_title: Goldman posts higher Q2 profit on cost cuts, legal provision
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 78% increase in second-quarter profit, beating analyst expectations, driven by cost cuts and higher revenue in fixed-income markets. The bank's cost-cutting plan, which includes staff reductions and severance expenses, will save US$700 million annually. Revenue declined 13% across most businesses, but fixed-income trading rose 20% and debt underwriting jumped 20%. Goldman's shares rose 0.3% in early trading, despite falling 9% this year.

site_title: US: Microsoft helps Wall Street to another day of record highs
summary: US stocks reached new records on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Dow industrials gaining fresh highs, as Microsoft's strong cloud computing results boosted the indexes. The tech sector led the gains, with six of the 10 major S&P sectors closing higher. Despite concerns over global instability, investors are pouring into US markets, and second-quarter earnings are now expected to fall 3.8%, less than initial estimates. The Dow Jones rose 36.02 points to 18,595.03, and the S&P 500 gained 9.24 points to 2,173.02.

site_title: US dollar hits 4-month high as markets raise bets on Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high against a basket of currencies, driven by expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Investors see a greater than 50% chance of a rate hike by the Fed's December meeting, according to FedWatch tool. Strong US labour market and inflation readings have boosted bets on rate hikes, contributing to the dollar's surge.

site_title: Singapore food producers pool resources to go regional
summary: Singapore food producers are partnering with the government to increase their regional presence. The Working In Partnership (WIP) programme, launched by IE Singapore and the Singapore Manufacturing Federation, aims to pool resources and reduce costs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The programme has already helped 80 firms export 800 products to Myanmar and Thailand, with plans to expand to the Philippines and introduce a fourth partner by end-2016. This collaboration is expected to improve retail prices and benefit consumers, while also helping SMEs tap into new markets.

site_title: Update: US maps 1MDB fraud trail from Kuala Lumpur to Hollywood
summary: US prosecutors allege a $3.5 billion money laundering scheme from Malaysia's 1MDB fund, involving shell companies, international banks, and Hollywood, including financing the film "The Wolf of Wall Street." The investigation targets Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak and his associates, including stepson Riza Aziz. The Justice Department seeks to seize over $1 billion in assets linked to the scheme. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and other banks were used to launder money, with some employees unaware of the wrongdoing. The probe is part of a global investigation into alleged corruption and money laundering by public officials.

site_title: Malaysia to cooperate with 'lawful investigations' after US files 1MDB suit
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's spokesman announced the country will cooperate with any lawful investigation into US lawsuits linked to the 1MDB scandal. The US Justice Department filed lawsuits to seize over $1 billion in assets allegedly tied to an international money laundering scheme. Najib's spokesman stated that if wrongdoing is proven, the law will be enforced without exception. This move comes after US prosecutors sued to seize assets linked to the scandal-ridden state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad.

site_title: No takers for SunEdison though it has 100 offers for specific assets
summary: SunEdison, a US-based renewable energy developer, is undergoing a piecemeal sale of its assets following its Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Despite 100 offers for specific assets, the company has yet to receive a bid for its entire business. Assets include wind and solar farms across five continents, with over 50 projects available, totaling more than five GW of capacity. Potential buyers are cherry-picking assets or pursuing low-ball bids for speculative ones, with some assets being operational while others are barely developed.

site_title: Track record
summary: SMRT's Temasek-backed expansion plans have been met with a mixed response. The company's public transport network is part of a larger push to improve Singapore's public transport system. Meanwhile, other companies, such as Tesla, are expanding their services in new markets, including India and the US. FedEx has partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries, while Delta Air Lines has reported an upbeat outlook on travel demand. These developments suggest a growing focus on innovation and expansion in the transport and logistics industries.

site_title: A one-stop service partner in tech and business solutions
summary: ZONE Telecom, a Singapore-based company, has expanded its services beyond voice to offer a range of internet and cloud solutions for businesses. The company aims to provide a one-stop service for SMEs, offering high-quality voice, fibre broadband, secured data connectivity, and scalable cloud services. ZONE's new cloud computing offerings have gained traction, allowing businesses to access computing resources and applications on the web, without the need for expensive servers and IT professionals. The company has partnered with Microsoft and Alibaba Cloud, and plans to expand its business into the region, focusing on cloud services and cost-effective solutions for SMEs.

images.alt_text: Managing director Peter Ong (front) with his diverse team of dedicated staff at ZONE Telecom.

site_title: Wall St's strength spills over to local market
summary: The Straits Times Index rose nearly one percent to 2,945.74 on Wednesday, driven by gains in Singtel, Thai Beverage, and banks. Despite the market's strong showing, the broader market did not follow, recording an advance-decline score of 238-150 excluding warrants. Wall Street's sixth consecutive all-time high on Tuesday may have contributed to the elevated sentiment. Analysts have reduced their earnings estimates for Wilmar International due to its expected Q2 loss, but maintained a "hold" on the stock.

site_title: Universal bets big on Manila casino
summary: Universal Entertainment Corp chairman Kazuo Okada plans to build a US$4 billion casino resort in Manila, set to open in November, aiming to challenge Macau and other Asian destinations. The project, featuring a 100-metre dancing water fountain, will promote Manila as a gaming hub and cost US$3 billion in its first phase. The investment is expected to boost the Philippines' gaming and tourist revenue, following a shift of high-stakes Chinese gamblers away from Macau amid government crackdowns.

site_title: Foreign cash reviving home building in Spain
summary: Foreign investment is reviving Spain's home building market, with a surge in building permits and construction activity. Despite the country's economic recovery, a lack of government and political instability have not deterred foreign investors, who are attracted to Spain's relatively low property prices. The market is seeing a resurgence in luxury apartments and city housing, with prices ranging from under €2 million to €8 million. Experts predict annual demand of 180,000 units over the next 10 years, driven by foreign investment and the economic recovery.

site_title: Who would make America safe?
summary: The US presidential campaign has exacerbated the racial divide, making Americans less safe. The ongoing slow economic recovery and conventional wars in the Middle East have fueled national anxiety. Recent police shootings of black men and retaliatory anti-police violence have heightened tensions. Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are exploiting these anxieties, with Trump promising to restore law and order and Clinton emphasizing her ability to bring the nation together. However, some experts warn that the brutal campaign could exacerbate racial divisions, making America less safe, and neither candidate has proposed a coherent plan to defeat terrorism.

site_title: US$7K-a-month China blogger loses it all with just one post
summary: A Chinese blogger, Laura Lian, lost her $7,000-a-month income after posting a satirical article mocking Chinese men's hairstyles, including former president Jiang Zemin's hairstyle. Her blog, Shameless China, was shut down by internet authorities without warning, resulting in her losing her career and investor backing.

site_title: US$ hits 4-month high on rate hike expectations
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high against a basket of currencies due to strong US data and expectations of a potential Federal Reserve rate hike before the end of the year. Commerce Department data showed US housing starts surged 4.8%, indicating a strong economy. This boosted the dollar's value, with it reaching a high against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Top HSBC executive arrested in US over forex trades
summary: HSBC executive Mark Johnson, head of global foreign exchange cash trading, was arrested in New York on Tuesday night over a US$8 million fraudulent foreign exchange trading scheme. Johnson was released on a $1 million bond. The scheme targeted a bank client, netting the bank $8 million.

images.alt_text: Mark Johnson, global head of foreign exchange cash trading in London HSBC Holdings Plc, leaves federal district court in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on July 20. US prosecutors announced charges Wednesday against two top HSBC executives over a fraudulent foreign exchange trading scheme that netted some US$8 million at the expense of a bank client.

site_title: Recent market rebound from Brexit-linked losses premature and risky: IIF
summary: Stock and bond markets have recovered from Brexit-linked losses, but the Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns that this rebound may be premature and risky, as corporate earnings prospects are modest at best. The IIF suggests that the market's confidence in the economy is not justified by fundamentals, and that the dramatic price recovery is mainly due to central bank liquidity injections. The IIF expects a potential correction if not validated by stronger economic performance, and notes that interest rates and yield curves imply weak growth and subdued inflation ahead.

site_title: Even with Brexit vote, UK-Asia trade could grow in both directions
summary: The UK-Asia trade is expected to grow despite the Brexit vote, with the UK being a significant investor in Singapore and a major purchaser of manufactured goods from Asia. China is set to become the UK's largest single source of imports by 2030, while imports from Vietnam, Bangladesh, and India are expected to grow at an 8% annual rate. The UK's expertise in services, particularly in finance and professional services, also presents opportunities for growth in the region. The International Festival for Business in Liverpool highlights the potential for closer ties between the UK and Asia, with both regions recognizing the benefits of increased trade and investment.

site_title: Fighting fit
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are prioritizing employee training and upskilling to stay competitive in a rapidly changing world. Companies like Galmon, a distributor of mobile elevating work platforms, and Leacov Singapore, a professional security training provider, have established training academies and offer Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) courses to enhance their staff's skills. OCBC Bank has also committed to providing ready funding for SMEs through its Business Venture Loan and Working Capital Loan programs, supporting their growth and cash flow needs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Drone-mounted flame thrower case may test FAA authority
summary: A US judge ruled that the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has the authority to oversee unmanned aircraft, dismissing the arguments of a father and son who posted videos of drones firing a handgun and incinerating a turkey with a flame-thrower. The FAA is investigating whether the flights violated aviation safety regulations. The decision may determine the government's ability to regulate drones, which could impact industries such as railroads and utilities, as well as individuals' privacy concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International, a Singapore-based agribusiness company, expects to report a net loss of around US$230 million in Q2 2016 due to challenging operating conditions. The company's earnings are expected to be significantly lower in H1 2016, but it still expects to be profitable. This downgrade has reduced the fair value of the stock from S$3.34 to S$3.05. Analysts Citi Research maintain a "buy" rating despite the negative development, citing the company's diversified model and progress in its consumer unit.

site_title: What's fuelling Bt Sembawang rally?
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates, a 105-year-old Singaporean residential property developer, has seen its stock price surge to a one-year high after the company revealed it may have unlocked value from its legacy agricultural land. The stock price has risen 10% in less than a week, with trading volumes exceeding 300,000 shares in the past three days. The company's dividend of 33 cents a share and potential mergers and acquisitions speculation are also contributing factors. However, investors are cautious, as the bulk of the firm's value remains unrealized, and the company's unsold properties may lead to losses.

site_title: Netflix's subscriber numbers fall short of its own forecasts
summary: Netflix reported 1.68 million new subscribers in Q2 2016, short of its forecast, due to higher prices for older customers leading to cancellations. The company added 1.52 million international subscribers and 160,000 in the US, reaching a total of 83.2 million subscribers. Despite gains in sales and profit, investors focus on user growth, particularly from international markets. Netflix expects to add 2.3 million new customers, including 300,000 in the US, but shares fell 17% due to the miss.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SPH appoints Ng Yat Chung as an independent director, effective August 1. Ng, 54, is current executive director of NOL and chairman of the Singapore Institute of Technology's board of trustees. ST Engineering secures S$650 million in contracts for electronics and information communications technologies. Huan Hsin Holdings plans to sell its China subsidiary for $55.9 million to increase working capital and repay debt.

site_title: Canadian developers start building only after getting high sales
summary: Canadian developers are now building condominium projects only after reaching a 70% sales threshold, according to the Canadian Mortgage & Housing Corp. This approach aims to mitigate speculative building and reduce risks. Previously, construction began before reaching this threshold, contributing to the 1980s housing bubble. The move follows strong price gains in Toronto, with the average home price rising 51% in the last five years. Lenders typically require a 60-80% sales target before providing financing for a project. This shift is seen as a response to policymakers' warnings about unsustainable price gains.

site_title: Young professionals should go for leadership development programmes for a quicker transition to a bright future
summary: Young professionals seeking career advancement, international exposure, and early leadership opportunities should consider the logistics industry, particularly in Singapore, which is a key logistics hub in Asia. The industry is driving innovation with technology advancements, and companies are investing in predictive analytics and optimised supply chains. Leadership development programmes, such as those offered by the Economic Development Board and DHL, can provide young professionals with skills and exposure to succeed in the industry and assume leadership positions.

site_title: Thai junta offers million baht raffle to bring tax returns online
summary: Thailand's junta has launched a nationwide e-payment scheme to bring the massive informal economy into the books and boost tax revenues. The scheme, which will offer a monthly lucky draw of cash awards, aims to add 100 billion baht (S$3.9 billion) to the government's tax revenue annually. The move is part of a broader effort to combat tax evasion, which is estimated to cost Thailand 30% of VAT revenue. The scheme is expected to save banks and businesses 75 billion baht annually, with the goal of expanding the tax base and preventing tax avoidance.

site_title: Ascott Reit keeps faith with London
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 2% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, reaching 2.13 Singapore cents. The Reit remains confident in London's status as a key global city despite the Brexit vote, citing stable income from its London properties and a long-term view of the markets. Ascott Reit plans to seek accretive acquisitions in gateway cities, targeting an asset size of S$6 billion by 2017, and expects an increase in leisure travelers to London.

site_title: Heathrow Airport investors ready to fund new runway
summary: Heathrow Airport investors are ready to fund a new runway with a £16 billion investment, according to a letter to UK Prime Minister Theresa May. The investment, from shareholders including the Universities Superannuation Scheme and Qatar Holding, would be used to build a new runway, with a cost slightly lower than the government's estimated £18 billion. Transport Minister Chris Grayling has vowed to make a decision on the airport's expansion by the coming weeks, with some reports suggesting a potential decision by September.

site_title: Ensuring the safest way to the top
summary: Galmon, a Singapore-based distributor of mobile elevating work platforms (MEWP), has maintained a zero-fatality record since its inception in 1982. Founder and CEO Desmond Ong attributes this to the company's emphasis on safety and education. To support this, Galmon established a training academy in 2011 and became an approved training provider for MEWPs. The company's investment in work-at-heights safety has earned it prestigious awards, including the bizSAFE Enterprise Exemplary Award and the Singapore Prestige Brand Award. Ong stresses that education and prudent spending will be crucial for the company's survival in the face of uncertain global economic conditions.

site_title: United's Q2 profit exceeds analysts' estimates on cost reductions
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc. reported a Q2 profit of US$2.61 per share, exceeding analyst estimates, despite weak fares. Lower fuel and operating costs offset the decline in passenger revenue, which dropped 6.6% in the quarter. The airline now expects full-year capacity growth of no more than 1.5%, down from a previous 2% plan. United joins American Airlines and Delta Air Lines in cutting capacity to curb an overabundance of flights and seats, aiming to boost unit revenues in the fall.

site_title: RSPO suspension batters IOI Corp shares
summary: IOI Corp's palm oil sustainability certification was suspended by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in April following complaints against its Indonesian subsidiaries. The suspension has led to a 5% decline in the company's share price, with US agribusiness conglomerate Cargill halting palm oil purchases. IOI Corp is a founding member of RSPO, but its license remains withheld. The company faces additional challenges, including depressed crude palm oil prices and large US dollar debts. Analysts predict a prolonged suspension could harm earnings and customer relationships, with IOI Corp's stock currently valued at RM3.60.

site_title: Procurri ends 19.6% below IPO price on SGX debut
summary: Procurri Corporation, a data centre equipment provider, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with its shares opening at 54 Singapore cents and closing at 45 cents, 19.6% below its IPO price of 56 cents. The company aims to raise its corporate profile and tap into growth prospects globally. The listing brings the total number of SGX-listed technology companies to 80, with a combined market capitalisation of S$84 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Technology firm Procurri Corporation made its debut on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Wednesday, slumping 19.6 per cent below its initial public offering (IPO) price of 56 Singapore cents.

site_title: A promise to deliver
summary: Leco Auto, a 41-year-old parallel importer of new cars in Singapore, has built a reputation for delivering on its commitments to customers. The company directly imports popular Toyota and Honda models from Japan, offering cheaper and different models compared to authorized distributors. With a focus on customer service, Leco sells around 500 new cars annually and has retained customers through word-of-mouth referrals. Founder Ng Hoy Keng emphasizes the importance of integrity, service, and delivering on promises to build customer trust and loyalty.

images.alt_text: 'We compete on our brand, our integrity. Our service must be good. To do business, we must dare to make money, dare to lose money.' - Leco founder and chairman Ng Hoy Keng (left) with his son, Cobin Ng

site_title: Temasek offers S$1.68 a share to take SMRT private in S$1.2b deal
summary: Temasek Holdings has proposed a S$1.2 billion buyout of SMRT Corp to take the transport operator private, valuing it at S$2.57 billion. The deal, pegged at S$1.68 cash per share, is an 8.7% premium over SMRT's last-traded price. The move aims to allow SMRT to focus on quality service without the pressures of being listed, as it transitions to a new rail model. Temasek will acquire 54% of SMRT's shares, with the remaining 46% held by minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: PDPC calls on firms to better protect data
summary: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) in Singapore has called on organizations to improve data protection, following the discovery of unshredded documents from United Overseas Bank (UOB) in a trashbag. The incident, which was investigated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), highlights the need for proper disposal of physical media containing personal data. The PDPC advises against leaving such documents unattended and recommends regular maintenance of shredders to prevent less secure methods of disposal. Businesses can be fined up to S$1 million per breach under the Personal Data Protection Act.

site_title: Profit warning sends Wilmar stock reeling
summary: Wilmar International issued a profit warning, expecting a net loss of US$230 million for the second quarter ended June 30, 2016, due to challenging operating conditions in its oilseeds and grains, sugar manufacturing, and volatile raw material markets. The stock fell 11.6% as analysts downgraded their forecasts, citing significant losses in the oilseeds and grains segment, and reduced earnings expectations for FY16 and FY17. Despite the near-term volatility, analysts expect Wilmar's management to maintain its long-term strategy of improving efficiency and growing its downstream business.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Volkswagen scandal reaches all the way to the top, lawsuits say
summary: Three US attorneys-general have challenged Volkswagen's defense of its emissions deception, accusing the company of orchestrating a decade-long fraud involving dozens of engineers and managers, including CEO Matthias Mueller. The lawsuits claim that Mueller was aware of a 2006 decision to cheat emissions tests on Audi vehicles, contradicting Volkswagen's portrayal of the deception. The suits, filed by New York, Maryland, and Massachusetts, depict a "willful and systematic scheme of cheating" and seek to hold the company accountable for its actions, which could have significant financial and reputational consequences.

site_title: Two new Keppel Capital funds hope to raise US$1.5b
summary: Keppel Corp's asset management arm, Keppel Capital, has set up two closed-end private equity funds to raise a combined US$1.5 billion, just a month after its establishment. The funds will be used to invest in various industries, and their launch is seen as a significant step forward for the new unit.

site_title: Like all good things, the HSR will be worth the wait
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have announced that the high-speed rail (HSR) connecting the two cities will begin operations in 2026, after a decade-long planning process. The 350km-long rail link is expected to revolutionize travel between the two neighbors, with a journey time of 90 minutes. The project, which involves both public and private sectors, is expected to cost billions of dollars. While delays and complexities are expected, leaders believe the HSR will be a "game-changer" for regional connectivity and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Microsoft earnings cushioned by cloud business
summary: Microsoft's cloud business Azure saw revenue more than double in the quarter, with revenue from Azure rising over 100% and Office 365 revenue increasing 54% from commercial customers and 19% from consumers. The company's net income rebounded to $3.12 billion, up from a loss of $3.2 billion in the same period last year. Microsoft's smartphone business continues to struggle, with phone revenue declining 71% and the company laying off thousands of employees. Despite this, the company's Windows revenue from PCs sold for the professional market rose 2%, and its shares jumped 4% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Weaker China consumer spending seen as income gains moderate
summary: China's household income growth slowed to 6.5% in the first half of the year, down from 7.6% a year earlier. This may lead to policymakers stepping in to curb pay gains to keep manufacturing competitive. Consumer spending, which accounted for 73% of China's economic growth in the first half, is expected to soften further. The government aims to maintain a 6.5% GDP growth rate through 2020, but slower household income growth may threaten this goal.

site_title: Leading the transformation and innovation race
summary: Imperium Solutions, a 14-year-old IT solutions company, is leveraging cutting-edge technology to stay ahead in the industry. In 2013, the company shifted its focus to disruptive technology, particularly in big data, security, and cloud spaces. By combining solutions from various sources, Imperium Solutions creates customized solutions for its customers. The company is particularly excited about the Internet of Things, which requires data translation between humans and machines. With its unique approach, Imperium Solutions aims to team up with unicorns to further enhance its offerings and stay at the forefront of the IT solutions space.

site_title: Hyperloop sues co-founder who accused it of nepotism
summary: Hyperloop Technologies Inc filed a $250 million countersuit against co-founder Brogan BamBrogan and three other former employees who accused the company of nepotism and mismanagement. The lawsuit claims the group staged a failed coup to take over Hyperloop One and conspired to start their own competing company. BamBrogan and his colleagues alleged they faced demotion and were fired after raising concerns about mismanagement. Hyperloop counters that BamBrogan displayed erratic behavior and engaged in gross misconduct.

site_title: An artist's dream turned gold
summary: CNMC Goldmine, a Singapore-based gold mining company, was founded by artist Lin Xiang Xiong as a means to maintain artistic freedom. Initially, Lin worked as a designer and contractor before importing Italian tiles. After financial stability, he shifted focus to gold mining, which has since become the company's primary source of income. With a steady production, CNMC aims to expand further across Malaysia and the region.

site_title: China's migrant enclaves make way for the new
summary: In China's Shenzhen city, the urban village of Baishizhou is slated for demolition to make way for new residential and commercial districts. Home to 150,000 people, Baishizhou has been a haven for migrant workers and immigrants, offering cheap housing and low rents. Despite the threat of demolition, residents continue to operate businesses and live in the area, which is valued for its potential for commercial redevelopment. The demolition plans have been in the works since 2005, with some delays and negotiations with residents, but the fate of Baishizhou remains uncertain.

site_title: Keppel unit bags S$100m contracts
summary: Keppel Singmarine, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, has won S$100 million contracts from Jan De Nul Group to build three trailing suction hopper dredgers. The dredgers will be built in Keppel Nantong Shipyard and will be used for coastal restoration and land reclamation work worldwide. Completion is expected in the second half of 2018, with the third dredger to be completed within six months if an option is exercised. The contracts are not expected to impact Keppel's financial performance.

site_title: Coldwell Banker adds 7 franchisees
summary: US real estate franchisor Coldwell Banker has signed seven new franchisees in Singapore, bringing the total to 11 and 66 salespeople. The group aims to form a bigger platform for economies of scale in training and activities, tapping resources, technology, and brand recognition from ERA Realty Network, with which Coldwell Banker is under Northstar. The partnership will raise the collective expertise and profile of the industry, with a focus on training to enhance the existing agencies' business skills.

site_title: Government-accredited training school aims big
summary: Leacov Singapore, a professional security training company, has experienced rapid growth and attracted interest from subsidiaries of three public-listed companies. Founder Simon Ng aims to expand the firm into an institute for learning and discovering, offering advanced diplomas and degrees, with branches overseas. His vision includes enrichment programs for kids, tuition, coaching, and well-being training for various age groups, from young adults to retirees. Ng is assessing potential acquisition offers, but plans to maintain the company's independence to achieve his ambitious goals.

images.alt_text: 'So to my customers, staff and students, I adopt a humble attitude and encourage my trainers to do so.' - Leacov founder Simon Ng

site_title: IOC delays Russia-ban ruling until after court's decision
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has barred Russia's Sports Minister Vitaly Mutko from the Rio Games and withdrawn backing for international events in Russia due to a state-run doping programme. However, a complete ban on Russia was delayed until after a court case on Thursday. The IOC also ordered a disciplinary commission to investigate the ministry's role in a "state-dictated failsafe system" of drug cheating, which included swapping dirty urine samples. The decision excludes Mutko from Rio accreditation and suspends five top deputies, including his deputy, who is accused of running the cheating scheme.

site_title: Wheelock sells HK Peak mansion for HK$630m
summary: Wheelock Properties sold its third luxury home in Hong Kong's Peak neighborhood for HK$630 million (S$110.4 million), a 10.5% discount from the first villa sold earlier this year. The sale reflects a downturn in the housing market, with secondary residential housing prices dropping 12% from their peak. The developer, offering discounts and mortgages of up to 120% of a home's value, aims to boost sales in the ultra-luxury segment. The sale price works out to HK$78,000 per square foot.

site_title: Singapore: from planned chaos to a distinctive city
summary: Singapore has established itself as a model for urban planning and development, hosting high-level meetings such as the Singapore International Water Week and World Cities Summit. The city-state's successful redevelopment experience showcases the importance of political will, public support, and innovation in creating a liveable and sustainable environment. Singapore aims to be a thought leader in urban planning and sustainability, with a focus on contributing to its future economy through urban development and infrastructure. This experience serves as a valuable resource for other cities navigating their own urbanization and human development journeys.

images.alt_text: As it seeks its place in the league of global cities, Singapore will need to look beyond the hardware and focus more on what it is that makes the city distinctive and one with distinction for liveability and sustainability.

site_title: Raffles Medical plans to spend S$1b over next three years on expansion in Asia
summary: Raffles Medical Group plans to spend S$1 billion over three years to expand its healthcare presence in Asia, with a focus on China, where an ageing population and government reforms are expected to boost demand for medical care. The group, led by chairman Loo Choon Yong, aims to set up new hospitals and clinics, with projected investment until 2019, and expects organic sales growth of 11% in the next few years. The expansion will be funded through cash from existing operations and may include debt.

site_title: LAUD Architects - Eyeing the world stage
summary: LAUD Architects, a Singapore-based firm, is expanding its global presence while maintaining design excellence. With 10-15% of projects in overseas markets, LAUD has secured projects in China, Vietnam, and India. The firm attributes its success to its ability to balance large commercial projects with small, boutique feel. Design remains the cornerstone of LAUD, with the firm winning several awards for its innovative projects, including the President's Design Award and World Architecture Festival recognition. LAUD also prioritizes sustainability, technology, and community design, with a focus on "contemporary tropicality" and "Social Interaction and the Sense of Community."

site_title: US neighbourhoods hit by foreclosure crisis at a crossroads
summary: Cleveland's Slavic Village neighbourhood, once a symbol of the US foreclosure crisis, is at a crossroads. Local officials and non-profit groups are deciding whether to save or tear down the area, which has struggled with high foreclosure rates and low home prices. An experiment in urban renewal, the Slavic Village Recovery Project, has bought and renovated 34 homes, selling them for modest profits to plough back into more neighbourhood homes. However, experts argue that some homes may not be worth saving, citing factors like age and location.

site_title: BCA opens SkyLab to lift green building technology research
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has officially opened the SkyLab, a facility that advances research and testing of innovative energy-efficient building technologies. The S$62 million Academic Tower, where the SkyLab is located, features a rotatable lab and extensive instrumentation for energy efficiency tests. The BCA aims to host six to eight projects a year, with over 20 organizations already in discussions for experiments on air-conditioning systems, daylighting, and cool-surface technologies. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of the SkyLab in Singapore's drive for environmental sustainability and improving construction industry productivity and safety.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: JV contributions help CCT lift DPU for second quarter
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.20 Singapore cents for the second quarter of FY2016, a slight increase from 2.19 cents a year ago. Despite lower net property income, the trust's portfolio occupancy rate of 97.2% remained higher than the market rate of 95.1%. CCT's distributable income was 2.2% higher at S$129.93 million for the first half of FY16.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US moves to seize US$1b in assets linked to Malaysia's 1MDB
summary: The US Justice Department is moving to seize over $1 billion in assets linked to Malaysia's 1MDB state investment fund, associated with an international conspiracy to launder funds misappropriated from the fund. The assets, which may include properties, are linked to Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and are part of a global effort to track down missing funds. The seizure effort comes amid a scandal surrounding the embezzlement of billions of dollars from 1MDB, which has battered Najib's government. Switzerland and Singapore have also frozen millions of dollars in assets on suspicion of 1MDB-related embezzlement.

site_title: Growing at a steady pace
summary: Yue Hwa Chinese Products, a Hong Kong-based retailer specializing in Chinese goods, is expanding its e-commerce and sourcing quality products in Singapore. The company, controlled by the Yu family, aims for steady profits and has avoided aggressive market share growth. After a shaky start in Singapore in the 1990s, Yue Hwa persevered and has since grown steadily, with its branding and operations systems being revamped. The company is now looking to professionalize its staff and expand into new markets, including Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia.

site_title: US: Microsoft lifts Dow, S&P to records, before oil limits gains
summary: The US stock market, including the Dow and S&P 500, reached fresh records on Wednesday, driven by Microsoft's strong earnings results. However, gains were limited by a drop in energy stocks as oil prices fell. The technology index rose 1.05%, while the energy index fell 1.07%. Investors remain cautious amid geopolitical concerns and uncertainty about corporate earnings and economic activity.

site_title: Empowering staff to drive productivity and growth
summary: Goldbell Group, a Singapore-based company, prioritizes employee development and customer relationships. The company invests approximately S$100 million in after-sales services and has a strong relationship with its manufacturers and principals. Goldbell's corporate mission is to "anticipate needs and surpass expectations" with "the Goldbell Touch". The company has a strong CSR program, including the Goldbell Foundation, which provides funding and support to organizations and individuals in need. With plans to expand its business lines and services, Goldbell aims to become a "total business solution partner" for its customers.

site_title: China Film plans biggest IPO in country's entertainment industry
summary: China Film Co, the nation's largest movie distributor, plans a 4.09 billion yuan (US$831.5 million) IPO on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, marking the biggest IPO in China's entertainment industry. The company will offer 467 million shares, with proceeds used for movie production and cinema investments. This sale aims to fuel expansion in China's estimated US$180 billion media and entertainment industry, while competing with Dalian Wanda Group Co. and other companies. China Film's profit increased 76% to 868 million yuan last year, and the company plans to produce 53 movies and 14 TV dramas in the next three years.

site_title: Google funds culture, education programmes to remake its image
summary: Google has launched a multi-million dollar campaign to remake its image in Europe, focusing on cultural and educational programs to counter regulatory woes. The company has invested around $450 million since 2015 in digital skills training, museum exhibitions, and other initiatives, aiming to change the perceptions of Europeans and policymakers. Google's efforts include sponsoring digital skills training, YouTube concerts, and museum exhibitions, as well as funding European publishers to help them adapt to the digital world. The campaign is seen as a "soft lobbying" effort to win over local sceptics who worry about Google's dominance in the digital market.

site_title: Push for new laws to make S'pore a debt workout centre
summary: Singapore plans to introduce amendments to its Companies Act by early 2017 to strengthen its insolvency laws, positioning the country as an international centre for debt restructuring. The move comes amid high corporate defaults globally, with 40 defaults in 2016, and will allow debtors to propose a plan of reorganisation to pay creditors over time. The new laws will include provisions similar to US Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection laws, generating work for lawyers, accountants, and financiers.

site_title: Japan's securities industry moves to tackle material information leaks
summary: Japan's securities industry has introduced new guidelines to tackle material information leaks, aiming to ensure fair access to market-sensitive information. Analysts will be banned from gathering unpublished corporate information, and brokerages must vet gathered data to prevent undisclosed material information from being passed to clients. The new guidelines, set to take effect as early as October, will not introduce new punishments for breaking the rules, instead relying on existing penalties. This move aims to address concerns over investors' access to non-public material information and improve corporate governance in Japan.

site_title: Temasek proposes S$1.2b buyout of SMRT at S$1.68 per share
summary: Temasek Holdings' unit Belford Investments has proposed a S$1.68 per-share buyout of SMRT Corp, valuing the firm at S$2.57 billion. The acquisition would cost nearly S$1.2 billion, with Temasek already owning 54% of SMRT. The deal will be executed through a scheme of arrangement.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: What's driving the privatisation?
summary: Singapore's state-owned train operator SMRT is being privatized by Temasek with a S$1.2 billion takeover offer, raising questions about the motive behind the move. The privatization comes after the Land Transport Authority announced plans to take over SMRT's rail assets for almost S$1 billion, sparking debate over whether it's a bailout or an attempt to rein in public discourse on SMRT's problems. Critics argue that SMRT's focus on short-term profits has led to long-term reliability issues, and the privatization may lead to improved management and innovation.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q2 DPU down 7.1%, due to enlarged units base
summary: Cache Logistics Trust posted a Q2 DPU of 1.989 Singapore cents, down 7.1% from the previous year. The decline was partly due to an enlarged units base. Net property income and income available for distribution rose 21.9% and 6.2% year-over-year, respectively. The company signed over 125,000 sq ft of leases in Q2 and secured 577,000 sq ft for the year. Portfolio occupancy improved to 95.8% as of June 30, with a weighted average lease to expiry of 4.1 years.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: SPH appoints NOL's ex-CEO Ng as independent director
summary: SPH appoints Ng Yat Chung, former NOL CEO, as an independent director, bringing expertise to the board risk committee. Ng joins the board after a career in the Singapore government, including as Chief of Defence Force and executive director of NOL. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to maintain SPH's leadership in the media sector. The move is also expected to help the company navigate the rapidly evolving media landscape.

site_title: COE premiums rise ahead of reduced quota from August
summary: COE premiums in Singapore increased ahead of a reduced quota from August, with Category A rising to S$53,000, Cat B to S$57,508, and Cat E to S$57,501. The August-to-October quota will have 10% fewer COEs in all categories, with Cat A down 9.4%, Cat B 8.6%, and Cat E 16.6%. The increase in premiums is attributed to dealers encouraging buyers to purchase cars before the reduced quota, with some dealers reporting increased showroom traffic.

site_title: Oil investors may get another shot at cheap barrels
summary: Oil investors may have another chance to buy crude at low prices as prices are expected to slip before recovering more steadily, analysts say. Crude prices rose 70% to $46 a barrel since January's 12-year lows, but investors are hesitant to push prices beyond $50 due to uncertainty over global economic growth and supply. Analysts predict oil prices could fall below $40 a barrel due to Brexit's impact on global markets and concerns over growth in China. To encourage production cuts, analysts believe oil prices should trade below $45 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil investors who missed the chance to buy crude at multi-year lows earlier this year might get another shot at securing a bargain, as prices are likely to slip in the near term before recovering more steadily, analysts said.

site_title: Britain relinquishes rotating EU presidency in 2017
summary: Britain has relinquished its planned EU presidency in 2017 following the Brexit vote, with Prime Minister Theresa May informing European Council president Donald Tusk of her decision in a phone call. The UK was set to take the rotating presidency from July 1 to December 31, 2017, but will instead prioritize EU exit negotiations. EU ambassadors will meet to decide on a replacement.

site_title: EU should treat Brexit as a wake-up call
summary: The EU should view the UK's Brexit vote as a wake-up call to address its own challenges and improve its institutions, transparency, and content. The remaining 27 EU members must work together to overcome globalisation's tests, build a more democratic Europe, and address issues such as youth unemployment, housing needs, and pensioner poverty. The EU can seize this opportunity to overcome internal divisions and make tangible benefits for citizens, while also addressing concerns about the European Commission's composition and functions.

site_title: SMEs must make greater effort to protect personal data: commission head
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) emphasizes the need for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to improve personal data protection. The PDPC will provide new initiatives, including a Capability Development Grant, to help SMEs enhance their data management capabilities. The commission has also updated guides and guidelines to promote a "trustworthy data ecosystem" and encourage accountability. Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim highlighted the importance of trust and innovation in leveraging data, citing the need for businesses to prioritize data protection to avoid losing customer trust.

site_title: 'Wolf of Wall Street' sued as US seeks 1MDB-tied assets
summary: The US Justice Department is seeking to seize over $1 billion in assets, including real estate, art, and movie proceeds, allegedly linked to the Malaysian 1MDB fund. These assets were acquired using funds diverted for personal benefit, including luxury real estate, artwork, and Las Vegas casino expenses. The government claims 1MDB had no interest in these assets and saw no returns. The assets include proceeds from the "Wolf of Wall Street" movie.

site_title: Minsheng's Lu says stake purchase not a challenge to Anbang
summary: Minsheng Banking Corp vice-chairman Lu Zhiqiang has purchased approximately $1.1 billion of stock, increasing his stake to 4.6%, sparking speculation of a potential battle for ownership with Anbang Insurance Group Co, the bank's largest shareholder. Lu dismissed such concerns, stating he has "a lot of respect" for Anbang and will not act in concert with anyone. Anbang chairman Wu Xiaohui also indicated the company will not fight for control, and founding members of the bank have committed to the stability of China's first private lender.

site_title: In China meeting, G20 has chance to soothe post-Brexit jitters
summary: The G20 finance ministers and central bankers meet in China to address post-Brexit jitters and dwindling global growth options. Brexit fallout and Donald Trump's protectionist campaign themes are expected to dominate the talks. The International Monetary Fund has cut its global growth forecast, and a South Korean finance ministry official says expanded downside risks to global economic growth will be discussed. The G20 is also expected to focus on currencies and monetary policy, with China's economy seen as a key topic, despite easing concerns about the country's health.

site_title: HKEX to put planned LME-HK clearing link on hold due to Brexit: CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) has put on hold its planned commodities clearing link with the London Metal Exchange (LME) due to uncertainty created by the UK's vote to leave the European Union. The project, designed to clear and settle LME trades in Hong Kong, will be put on hold until regulatory policies in the UK and Europe are clearer. This decision does not affect other HKEX projects.

site_title: Hedge funds turn bullish as China weathers slower growth, Brexit vote
summary: Hedge funds are turning bullish on Chinese shares, with 76% of China's hedge fund managers planning to add stock holdings this month, a jump from 50% in June. Despite a slowing economy and market shocks from Brexit, China's stock market has "held up well," according to a report by Springs Capital. The fund eked out a 0.7% gain in June and is down 12.5% so far this year. This optimism is partly due to investors having largely priced in risks since a market rout in January, according to Springs Capital.

site_title: Morgan Stanley reports fall in quarterly profit
summary: Morgan Stanley reported a fall in adjusted second-quarter profit, with net income of $1.43 billion (75 US cents per share) compared to $1.69 billion (79 US cents per share) a year earlier. The decline was attributed to a decline in revenue from trading and investment banking, despite cost-cutting efforts. Analysts had expected earnings of 59 US cents per share, and the earnings take into account a rule change that no longer requires Morgan Stanley to reflect changes in its debt value in its earnings.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q2 profit up 18.5% at $18.81m
summary: Keppel T&T, a Singapore-based data centre and logistics provider, reported an 18.5% rise in net profit to $18.81 million for the second quarter, driven by higher contributions from its Data Centre division. Revenue climbed 2.1% to $50.18 million, while operating expenses fell 6.4%. The company attributed the better profit to higher revenue from the Data Centre division, partly offset by lower revenue from the Logistics division.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence falls in July after Brexit vote
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence fell to -7.9 in July, a 0.7-point drop from June, and the lowest level in two years. This marks a downward trend following the June Brexit vote, with the European Union experiencing an even worse drop of 1.8 points to -7.6. The post-Brexit vote decline in consumer confidence is also seen in Germany, where the ZEW economic sentiment index sank to -6.8 points in July.

site_title: US navy chief vows more patrols in South China Sea
summary: US Navy Chief John Richardson vowed to continue patrols in the South China Sea, despite Beijing's anger, after an international tribunal dismissed China's maritime claims. The tribunal's ruling, made last week, stated there was no legal basis for China's claim to nearly all the South China Sea. China rejected the verdict and has continued construction on disputed islands. US warships have sailed within 12 nautical miles of some islands, prompting Beijing to accuse the US of "militarizing" the region. The US will continue to operate in the area according to international law.

site_title: Schaeuble to meet Hammond for bilateral talks at G20 sidelines
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble is set to meet UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond at the G20 meeting in China on Saturday for bilateral talks. The talks are expected to focus on creating conditions for sustainable growth and strengthening economic resilience, with structural reforms as a key priority. Schaeuble will also push for measures to combat global tax evasion, including sharing detailed data on company ownership. The meeting comes amid concerns about the UK's post-Brexit economic outlook.

site_title: Singapore lags Asean in sustainability reporting: study
summary: A recent study by the National University of Singapore Business School and the Asean CSR Network found that Singapore lags behind its regional peers in sustainability reporting, with only 71% of companies practicing it. Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia outperformed Singapore in terms of disclosure quality, with Thailand scoring 56.8 out of a possible 100. The study noted that government-linked companies and state-owned enterprises fared better, and the Singapore Exchange is expected to introduce sustainability reporting on a "comply or explain" basis in 2017.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: EC World Reit prices IPO at 81 cents apiece
summary: EC World Reit has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at 81 Singapore cents per unit, with an annualized yield of 7.1% for the six months to Dec 31 this year. The Reit, backed by Shanghai-based sponsor Forchn Group, aims to expand its operations to the South-east Asian region and list other Reits in the future. The IPO will raise S$629.8 million, with Forchn Group holding a 45% stake. Despite concerns over concentration risks and cross-border risks, chairman Zhang Guobiao defended the yield as one of the highest among recent Reit listings with foreign assets.

site_title: Oil stocks decline, gasoline inventories up
summary: US crude oil stocks fell by 2.3 million barrels in the week to July 14, marking the ninth consecutive week of decline, according to the Energy Information Administration. Gasoline inventories unexpectedly rose by 911,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs increased by 319,000 barrels per day, and distillate stockpiles fell by 214,000 barrels. US crude imports rose by 293,000 barrels per day. The decline in crude stocks was attributed to increased refinery output, with utilization rates rising by 0.9 percentage points.

site_title: 'Drone' money or zaito bonds more likely from the BOJ instead
summary: The Japanese government is considering re-issuing "zaito" bonds, non-repayable only from project revenues, rather than perpetual bonds, to finance infrastructure and stimulate economic activity without adding to its heavy debt burden. This system, used in the past, allows for targeted government spending and investment in specific channels. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may be involved in financing these projects, rather than underwriting IOUs, and the "drone" money concept may be part of a combined infrastructure initiative and consumption spending booster package in September, targeting social sectors.

site_title: European banks may need 470b euros of loss-absorbing funds
summary: European banks need to sell hundreds of billions of euros in loss-absorbing liabilities to meet European Union rules designed to protect taxpayers from the cost of bank failures. The European Banking Authority estimates that banks need 470 billion euros in funds, or 790 billion euros if senior unsecured debt is excluded. The requirement is similar to the global total loss-absorbing capacity standard set by the Financial Stability Board. EU lawmakers aim to share losses with senior creditors and are working to harmonize efforts to include senior bonds in the minimum requirement for eligible liabilities.

site_title: TTJ unable to secure tenancy renewal for sole dormitory in Jurong
summary: Steel specialist TTJ Holdings has been unable to secure a renewal for its 5,300-worker dormitory at Terusan Lodge in Jurong, with the lease set to expire in January 2017. The Building and Construction Authority declined the application due to redevelopment works affecting the site. This is expected to impact TTJ's financial and operating results for FY2017, although the firm has secured a new three-year tenancy for a 500-worker dormitory at Upper Jurong Road, with less material impact.

site_title: BoE sees no sharp slowing yet even as Brexit boosts uncertainty
summary: The Bank of England reported that UK businesses are not yet showing signs of a sharp economic slowdown, despite the Brexit vote causing uncertainty. Around a third of contacts expected some negative impact over the next year, while most firms remained unaffected by the near-term impact on investment and hiring plans. A separate survey found little change in orders, but demand is expected to weaken over time.

site_title: OCBC offers free wi-fi access at Orchard Road, Sports Hub and bank branches (Amended)
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a free public Wi-Fi service with 700 hotspots at multiple locations, including Orchard Road, the Singapore Sports Hub, and 33 bank branches. The service aims to support the government's push for a "Wireless Singapore" initiative. OCBC expects over 30,000 daily users and hopes to solidify its leading digital position in Singapore.

site_title: Gold is not all that glisters - diamonds act as hedge for the rich
summary: A 14.62-carat blue diamond, the Oppenheimer Blue, was sold at a Christie's auction in Geneva for a world record $57.5 million, surpassing previous records for rare diamonds. The anonymous buyer secured the gem after a tense bidding process that lasted over half an hour. The sale marks the latest in a series of record-breaking diamond auctions, highlighting the allure of diamonds as a hedge for the wealthy.

site_title: Keppel Corp's new asset management arm sets up two PE funds
summary: Keppel Corp's asset management arm, Keppel Capital, has set up two private equity funds with a combined target of US$1.5 billion. The funds, managed by Alpha Investment Partners, received initial capital commitments of US$410 million, with a potential total of US$3.5 billion in assets under management. The funds will focus on data centre investments and Asian property investments, driven by trends such as urbanisation and consumerism. The move aims to grow Keppel's asset management business and expand its capital base through co-investments.

site_title: Huan Hsin to sell indirectly owned China subsidiary for 274.4m yuan
summary: Huan Hsin Holdings plans to sell its indirectly owned China subsidiary, Shanghai Huan Yi Technology Co, for 274.4 million yuan (S$55.8 million) to increase working capital and repay debt. Link JV Holdings, an unrelated party, will buy the company's shares. The sale includes land use rights to an 80,284 square meter industrial land parcel in Shanghai, valued at 229 million yuan. The buyer will deposit 25.5 million yuan in an escrow account and pay the remaining 204.8 million yuan at closing.

site_title: FLASH: Temasek Holdings has proposed to buy out SMRT Corp at S$1.68 per share in a deal worth S$1.18 billion
summary: Temasek Holdings has proposed a S$1.18 billion buyout of SMRT Corp at S$1.68 per share. The deal, if accepted, would see Temasek Holdings acquire 100% of SMRT Corp's outstanding shares. The proposed deal marks a significant move by Temasek Holdings to expand its presence in the public transport sector in Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia bans police, troops from playing Pokemon Go
summary: Indonesia has ordered police not to play Pokémon Go while on duty, with the government warning the game poses a security threat due to its potential for spying. The country's Defence Minister has also announced plans to ban military personnel from playing the game during work hours. Concerns include the game's ability to send data to other countries and the potential for officers to become addicted, compromising their duties. The bans follow incidents of Pokémon Go-related crimes and disruptions in cities worldwide.

site_title: Theresa May takes centre stage in British parliament's box-office show
summary: Theresa May, Britain's new prime minister, faced her first parliamentary grilling, taunting the opposition over women's rights. She highlighted her party's role in making her the country's second female leader after Margaret Thatcher. May, appointed a week ago, must unite the Conservative party and negotiate Britain's exit from the European Union. She made her most closely watched debut, leading Prime Minister's Questions in the combative centrepiece of the British political week.

images.alt_text: Theresa May used her first parliamentary grilling as Britain's new prime minister on Wednesday to taunt the opposition over women's rights, pointing out that it was her party that had made her the country's second female leader after Margaret Thatcher.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks back to winning ways with sharp gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a seventh consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 0.97% to 21,882.48, following another Wall Street record. Traders expect fresh global central bank stimulus, driving gains.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine to build three dredgers at S$100 million
summary: Keppel Singmarine has won contracts to build three trailing suction hopper dredgers worth approximately S$100 million. The first two dredgers are expected to be completed in H2 2018, while the third will be built within six months if Jan De Nul exercises the option. The dredgers will be built to a maximum depth of 27.6 meters and have a hopper capacity of 3,500 cubic meters.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, in line with firm Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 26.2 points or 1% to 2,945.74 on Wednesday, driven by gains in Singtel, Thai Beverage, and banks. Turnover increased to $1.2 billion, despite a decline in Wilmar International's shares, which expected a Q2 loss of $230 million. Wall Street's all-time high may have boosted sentiment. Analysts have reduced their earnings estimates for Wilmar, downgrading it from a "hold" to a "sell" due to the expected loss.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust's DPU for Q2 up 3%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust posted a 3% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) in Q2, reaching 2.16 Singapore cents, up 9% from the previous quarter. The increase was driven by higher gross profit, resulting in a 9% increase in unitholders' distribution to S$35 million.

site_title: Gold falls on firmer equities, dollar after robust US data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,325.91 an ounce after strong US economic data raised expectations of a potential Federal Reserve rate hike before year-end, pushing the dollar to a four-month high. European equities edged higher, while the dollar surged 0.1% against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Seaplane hits bridge in Shanghai, killing five: govt
summary: An amphibious plane owned by Joy General Aviation crashed into a highway bridge in Shanghai, killing five people and injuring five more, according to the city government. The plane was taking off on a flight to Zhejiang province with 10 people on board. The incident occurred shortly after midday in Jinshan district, with the plane's nose on the bridge and its tail in the water.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Wednesday, closing at 1,669.61 after a 0.940-point drop. The index saw 1.93 billion lots valued at RM1.64 billion traded, with 435 gainers and 366 losers.

site_title: ST Engineering's electronics arm wins S$650m contracts in Q2
summary: ST Engineering's electronics arm, Singapore Technologies Electronics (ST Electronics), secured S$650 million worth of contracts in Q2 2016. The contracts include Rail Electronics & Intelligent Transportation (S$210 million), Satellite & Broadband Communications (S$80 million), and Advanced Electronics & Information Communications Technologies Solutions (S$360 million). This brings the total new orders for ST Electronics to S$1.16 billion in the first half of 2016, with a S$152 million rail electronics project and a large public security project among the significant overseas orders.

site_title: Bank of England sees no clear evidence of sharp Brexit slowdown
summary: The Bank of England stated that, despite business uncertainty rising after the June 23 Brexit vote, there is no clear evidence of a sharp slowdown in Britain's economy. Around a third of firms surveyed plan to curb hiring and investment, but a majority do not expect a near-term impact. The central bank's regional agents found little evidence that consumers are spending less, and there is no clear evidence of a general slowing in activity.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government has accepted recommendations to enhance the country's debt-restructuring framework. Temasek Holdings proposed a S$1.2 billion buyout of SMRT Corp at S$1.68 per share. COE premiums rose in the final bidding exercise before a new quota. Raffles Medical Group plans to spend S$1 billion to expand in Asia. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 26.2 points higher, or almost one percent, due to gains in Singtel, Thai Beverage, and banks.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q2 net profit up 18.5% to S$18.8 million
summary: Keppel Telecommunications and Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a 18.5% increase in Q2 net profit to S$18.81 million, driven by a 2.1% rise in revenue to S$50.18 million. Earnings per share rose 17.2% to 3.4 Singapore cents. The company attributed revenue growth to its data centre division, while logistics division revenue declined. Net profit for the half-year period was up 1.5% to S$32.12 million.

site_title: US prepares to seize assets tied to 1MDB: Wall Street Journal
summary: US federal prosecutors plan to file civil lawsuits to seize assets linked to 1MDB, a Malaysian state fund under investigation for money laundering in several countries. The seizures are expected to include properties and other assets purchased with allegedly misappropriated funds. This action marks the US government's first move in the 1MDB investigation, following a report that identified at least $4.2 billion in irregular transactions by the fund. The move comes amid ongoing investigations and allegations of wrongdoing by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Pound drops to lowest level in a week before UK labour data
summary: The pound dropped to its lowest level in a week against the dollar, reaching $1.3065, before UK labour data is released. The data is expected to show an increase in unemployment claims in June, following a decline in May. Economists say the data should be discounted as it's "pre-Brexit" and doesn't reflect the current state of affairs. The pound is expected to continue to decline, with predictions of a slide to $1.23 in the next three months.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q2 DPU down 7.1%, due to enlarged units base
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a Q2 DPU of 1.989 Singapore cents, down 7.1% from the previous year, due to an enlarged units base. The trust's net property income and income available for distribution rose 21.9% and 6.2% year-over-year to S$22.6 million and S$17.8 million, respectively. The decline in DPU was partly attributed to the absence of a capital distribution from the divestment of Kim Heng Warehouse in Q2 FY2015.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Wheelock sells Hong Kong Peak luxury mansion for HK$630m
summary: Wheelock Properties sold a luxury mansion in Hong Kong's Peak neighborhood for HK$630 million (S$110 million), a 12% discount from its first villa sold earlier this year. The sale price works out to HK$78,000 per square foot. The decline suggests a slowdown in the housing market, with developers offering discounts and mortgages of up to 120% of a home's value. The sale reflects the uniqueness of each unit, with varying garden sizes, pools, and locations.

site_title: Brexit means business as companies turn to consultants for help
summary: Companies in the UK are seeking outside help as they navigate the uncertainty of Brexit, with banks, consultants, and lawyers offering guidance on issues such as immigration, tax, and hiring. Many firms have set up internal teams and hired experts, including Goldman Sachs' former European Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso. The UK's departure from the EU has sparked concerns about pay and hiring, with companies seeking advice on talent, pensions, and employee benefits. As the Brexit conditions remain unclear, companies are turning to experts to prepare for potential changes.
