site_title: Vietnam prime minister warns economy may miss growth target
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc warns that the country may miss its 6.7% growth target for the year due to a crippling drought. The economy needs to expand 7.6% in the second half to reach its goal, which "will be hard to reach," Phuc said. Rising food prices and declining exports in some European markets are also pushing up inflation. The government will intensify measures to boost domestic demand and industries, while monitoring the impact of the UK's EU vote on the money market.

site_title: Japan, US finance ministers to meet ahead of G20 in China: MOF
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso and US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew will hold bilateral talks in Chengdu, China, on Saturday ahead of the G20 finance meeting. They will discuss the impact of Britain's exit from the European Union. The meeting follows previous talks where Aso and Lew had differing views on currency moves. Aso will also meet with his Australian counterpart Scott Morrison on Sunday.

site_title: PM Lee launches S$4.5m Building and Construction Authority research centre
summary: PM Lee launches S$4.5m research centre for building energy efficiency, a 132 sq m revolving laboratory to develop zero-energy buildings that also produce energy. The centre, launched on July 20, aims to bring Singapore closer to achieving this goal.

site_title: European stocks climb at open
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% at 6,725.88 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also saw gains, rising 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: Asia: Stocks edge higher with European futures as lira advances
summary: Asian stocks rose with European equity index futures as positive earnings reports countered concerns about a sluggish global economy. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index reached a three-month high, driven by gains in telecom shares and a strengthening Turkish lira. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index held near a six-week high, supported by rising odds of a US interest-rate increase. Despite concerns about corporate earnings, Goldman Sachs and Microsoft reported quarterly profits that surpassed analysts' estimates, boosting the Dow Jones Industrial Average for an eighth day.

site_title: China financier Sonny Wu said to lead 750m euro AC Milan deal
summary: Chinese financier Sonny Wu is leading a proposed 750 million euro ($1.12 billion) takeover of AC Milan soccer team, with his private equity firm GSR Capital as the main investor. Wu, who has previously led failed attempts to buy Royal Philips assets, is valuing the team at 750 million euros, including debt. This deal would cap Chinese companies' push to acquire soccer assets globally, following Suning Holdings Group's recent investment in Inter Milan. The acquisition has stalled earlier targets, hurting AC Milan's chances of signing new players during the summer transfer season.

images.alt_text: Chinese dealmaker Sonny Wu, whose business holdings span renewable energy and lighting, is leading the proposed takeover of storied Italian soccer team AC Milan, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Coldwell Banker (Singapore) signs seven new franchisees
summary: Coldwell Banker (Singapore) has signed seven new franchisees, bringing the total to 11, with 66 salespersons. The group aims to assist small-scale and growing real estate agencies to form a bigger entity, enabling economies of scale. New franchisees will have access to project sales opportunities, marketing insights, IT solutions, and support from Coldwell Banker's existing stable. The move is part of the company's strategy to help franchisees tap into resources, technology, and brand recognition.

site_title: China to expand railway network to 150,000 km by 2020
summary: China plans to expand its railway network to 150,000 km by 2020, including 30,000 km of high-speed rail, a 24% increase from 2015 and a 58% expansion in high-speed rail. The government will encourage state-owned China Railway Corp to finance its investment through bond issuance. This plan aims to enhance the country's transportation infrastructure and boost economic growth.

site_title: Visa to sponsor refugee athletes in Olympics
summary: Visa Inc has signed sponsorship deals with all ten members of the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) refugee team, becoming their first corporate sponsor. The team, consisting of six men and four women from various countries, will compete in the 2016 Rio Olympics. Visa's chief marketing officer, Chris Curtin, stated that sponsoring refugee athletes ties into the concept of acceptance in the company's Olympic campaign and aligns with the idea of acceptance associated with credit cards. The value of the deals was not disclosed.

site_title: COE premiums rise across the board
summary: COE premiums rose across the board in the final bidding exercise before the start of a new, smaller quota from next month. Category A (cars below 1,600cc/130 hp) increased by S$699 to S$53,000, while Cat B (cars above 1,600cc/130 hp) rose by S$1,419 to S$57,508. Cat E, the open category, jumped by S$1,499 to S$57,501. The August-to-October quota will have 10% fewer COEs due to lower deregistration numbers, with all categories experiencing contractions.

site_title: Apple, UBS tap Taiwan for dollars just as bond party set to cool
summary: Taiwan's bond-market party, which has drawn global issuers like Apple and UBS, is expected to slow down as yields reach unattractive levels. The island's life insurance companies, which account for 80% of non-local-currency debt, are seeking higher yields to balance foreign-exchange hedging costs and potentially higher-yielding assets. Despite this, analysts predict growth will continue, with total issuance expected to expand 20-25% to reach $42 billion, driven by the unique long-duration bond market and companies seeking diversification.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's bond-market party, which has seen the island attract global issuers including Apple Inc and UBS AG to sell US dollar debt, looks to go off the boil.

site_title: AusNet reaches settlement in Yarram Bushfire class action
summary: AusNet Services has settled a class action related to the 2014 Yarram Bushfire in Australia for A$10.5 million, with the company maintaining no negligence. The settlement includes A$5.25 million paid by Gippsland Contracting. The bushfire, which burned over 22,000 hectares, allegedly started when vegetation made contact with a distribution line. The settlement is subject to court approval.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Turkey bans academics from work trips abroad: state media
summary: Turkey's higher education council has banned academics from work trips abroad and urged those overseas to return home by August 5. The move is part of the country's massive post-coup purge targeting supporters of US-based cleric Fethullah Gulen, who Turkey accuses of orchestrating the attempted coup. The council also suspended 15,200 state education employees and demanded the resignation of 1,600 university deans over alleged links to Gulen. The ban and purges aim to root out perceived sympathizers of Gulen, who lives in Pennsylvania but maintains influence in Turkey.

images.alt_text: Turkey's higher education council has banned academics from work trips abroad and urged those overseas to quickly return home, the state-run Anadolu news agency reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks fall as risk-off sentiment comes back in
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.5% to 1,141.0 to the dollar as risk-off sentiment returned, prompting investors to shift away from risky assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.1% at 2,015.46. This comes after the International Monetary Fund cut global growth forecasts, sparking market volatility. Despite this, offshore investors continued to buy Kospi shares for the 10th straight session, accumulating 180.1 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Australia: Shares close up, New Zealand hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, closing at 5,488.7 points, their largest gain since July 11. New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high of 7,174.7, up 0.25%. Global monetary policy easing hopes fueled the gains.

site_title: Indonesia tax amnesty could be win-win for government's bonds
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty programme may not meet its revenue targets, but analysts say it could still benefit the country's bonds. The government's deficit is expected to be 2.35% of GDP, prompting potential cuts in infrastructure spending and increased borrowing. This could lead Bank Indonesia to cut interest rates to support growth. Analysts predict a decline in 10-year government bond yields, currently at 7.006%, to 6.75% over the next six months, making Indonesian bonds attractive to foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's tax amnesty programme, which the government is counting on to bring home billions of dollars citizens have parked overseas, could be a win-win situation for Indonesian bonds, analysts say.

site_title: China: Stocks end lower as investors await policy clues
summary: China's stocks ended lower on Wednesday as investors await policy clues, with the CSI300 index falling 0.3% to 3,237.61 points. Volumes were weak, with only 13.8 billion shares trading hands. Mixed signals from economic data added to uncertainty over further policy stimulus this year, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Singapore firms lag Asean counterparts in sustainability reporting: study
summary: A study by National University of Singapore's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations and Asean CSR Network found that 71% of Singapore companies practice sustainability reporting, lagging behind regional counterparts. Thailand outperformed with a score of 56.8, followed by Singapore (48.8), Indonesia (48.4), and Malaysia (47.7). Mandatory sustainability reporting enforcement in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand is higher, with 100% of companies in these countries disclosing information. The study suggests that Singapore companies will improve their sustainability reporting once the Singapore Exchange introduces a "comply or explain" basis in 2017.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after six-day rally
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Wednesday, snapping a six-day winning streak, as investors took profits from a rally fueled by Nintendo's Pokémon Go game. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.25% to 16,681.89, while the Topix index of all first-section shares dropped 0.05% to 1,330.75. The decline came ahead of Pokémon Go's launch in Japan, which was expected to boost the gaming sector.

site_title: France National Assembly votes to extend state of emergency
summary: France's National Assembly voted 489-26 in favor of extending the state of emergency for six months following last week's Nice massacre, allowing police extra powers to search and arrest individuals without prior approval. The law must now pass through the Senate. President Francois Hollande initially planned to lift the emergency measures, but changed course after the Bastille Day attack, which killed 84 people and was claimed by the Islamic State group. The extension is seen as a concession to opposition Republicans, who have demanded the state of emergency remain in place through the end of the year.

site_title: EC World set to price Singapore Reit IPO near top of range: IFR
summary: EC World Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is set to price its Singapore IPO near the top end of its range, raising approximately S$346 million. The Reit, backed by properties in Hangzhou, China, will sell 427.6 million units at S$0.81 apiece. Units will be listed on July 28. The IPO is the latest from the Shanghai-based Forchn Holdings Group.

site_title: Taiwan buses recalled after deadly fire disaster
summary: Taiwan authorities have ordered four buses off the road after a deadly fire disaster killed 26 Chinese tourists on board. The bus, operated by Mei Kui Shih Transportation Company, caught fire and crashed through an expressway barrier on its way to Taipei's main airport. Preliminary investigations suggest mechanical or electrical failure near the driver's seat may have led to the disaster. Emergency doors and windows did not open, and the bus operator and travel agency have been questioned by prosecutors. A post-mortem will be carried out on the driver's body to determine the cause of the accident.

images.alt_text: Taiwan authorities ordered some tour buses off the road Wednesday after one caught fire and killed 26 on board as questions swirl over why emergency doors and windows did not open.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai urges structural overhaul to jumpstart economy
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen urged structural reforms to boost the economy, citing the limited impact of conventional monetary and fiscal policies. She emphasized the need to strengthen capital markets, increase domestic investment, and boost innovation in five key industries. Tsai faces challenges, including slowing iPhone sales, strained ties with China, and a projected 1.06% economic growth this year. The government projects growth could slow to less than half that pace, and Tsai must balance economic needs with her pledge to uphold relations with China while pursuing trade deals like the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.

site_title: Transport ministers to discuss future of MH370 search
summary: Transport ministers from Australia, China, and Malaysia will meet Friday to discuss the future of the search for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The Australian-led search, which has scoured a 120,000sq km area of the Indian Ocean, may be completed in the next few weeks. The search will not be expanded without "credible" new evidence, and the meeting will reflect on achievements and discuss next steps. The Boeing 777 vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, and the cause of its disappearance remains unknown.

images.alt_text: Transport ministers from Australia, China and Malaysia will meet Friday to discuss the future of the frustrating deep-sea search for missing flight MH370, officials said on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia on alert for revenge attacks after most-wanted militant killed
summary: Indonesian authorities are on high alert for potential revenge attacks after the country's most-wanted militant, Santoso, was killed in a gun battle with security forces on Sulawesi island. Santoso, a US-designated terrorist, was among the first Indonesians to pledge loyalty to Islamic State. Officials warn of a "possibility of a backlash" and plan to intensify security operations in regions considered hotbeds for radicalism. Around 20 members of Santoso's group remain in hiding, and a man believed to be his right-hand man was also shot by police.

site_title: Spotify focuses on localisation to smooth next expansion in Asia
summary: Spotify is tailoring its service for local tastes in Asia to prepare for expansion, offering topical playlists, tiered pricing, and different payment methods. The streaming service has amassed 100 million global users and aims to gain new customers in Southeast Asia. Spotify has launched in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Taiwan, with more markets planned. The company has also adopted localized pricing, such as S$9.90 in Singapore and 129 pesos in the Philippines, and introduced cash payments in countries where credit cards are rare.

images.alt_text: Spotify is tailoring its service for local tastes, from topical playlists to tiered pricing, as it prepares to expand its music streaming in Asia.

site_title: Twitter announces crackdown after online abuse of Ghostbusters actor
summary: Twitter has permanently suspended several user accounts for online abuse and harassment after Ghostbusters actor Leslie Jones announced she would quit the platform due to racist tweets. Twitter acknowledged it had not done enough to curb abusive behavior, with Milo Yiannopoulos, a Breitbart tech editor, among those banned. The company stated it would invest in improving its tools and enforcement systems to better identify and take action on abuse. Jones had shared several abusive tweets, many comparing her to an ape, and called for guidelines on free speech on Twitter.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc said Tuesday it had moved to permanently suspend a number of user accounts for abuse and harassment after Ghostbusters actor Leslie Jones on Monday drew renewed attention to the issue and announced she would quit the social media site.

site_title: Indonesia central bank seen cutting benchmark rate for 5th time this year: poll
summary: Indonesia's central bank is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate for the fifth time this year, according to a Reuters poll. The benchmark 12-month reference rate is predicted to be reduced by 25 basis points to 6.25% to spur economic growth. Most surveyed economists believe a year-end cut on Thursday will be the last for this year, as they expect growth to stabilize. The move aims to stimulate the economy, which has been slowing down due to various factors.

site_title: Oil prices edge up from two-month lows
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Wednesday, rebounding from two-month lows, after investors sought bargains ahead of official US stockpiles data. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 11 cents to $44.76, while Brent added 19 cents to $46.85. The gains were tempered by concerns about an oversupply and weak demand, as the IMF cut its global economic growth forecasts. Supply disruptions have eased, and the situation in Turkey has stabilized, but the dollar's strength also weighed on oil prices.

site_title: Heavy rain causes disruption in Chinese capital
summary: Heavy rain in Beijing caused widespread disruption, forcing flight delays and cancellations, and closing subway stations. The city government issued an orange alert, warning of 100mm of rain and potential overnight continuation. This marks the second-highest warning level in China's four-tier system. The rain is not unusual for Beijing's summer months, which have previously seen dramatic storms, including one in 2012 that killed 37 people.

site_title: Singapore seeks US Chapter 11 prowess in bankruptcy law reform
summary: Singapore is seeking to enhance its insolvency law by adopting some powers from the US bankruptcy code's Chapter 11. The Law Ministry has accepted 17 recommendations, including an automatic stay of legal actions for debtors and a specialist judges' bench. This move aims to boost debt restructuring and follows 100 global bond defaults this year, the worst since the 2008 financial crisis. The changes may also introduce pre-packaged restructuring, a negotiated deal between debtors and creditors. The aim is to save time and cost in debt restructuring efforts and position Singapore as a global hub for debt restructuring.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit taking, brace for export orders
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% to 8,991.03 points on Wednesday due to profit-taking by local investors amid losses in overseas markets. The decline comes after the index reached a fresh one-year high in the previous session, with gains supported by foreign investors. The drop marks the end of a seven-session rally, which was fueled by foreign investment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as investors eye US earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to a decline in European markets. Investors are watching US second-quarter earnings, which may impact global markets. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.46% to 16,646.92, while the Topix index lost 0.41% to 1,325.92.

site_title: Hot stock update: Wilmar falls nearly 12% in intraday trade after profit warning
summary: Wilmar International's shares fell 11.64% on Wednesday, closing at S$3.16, after the palm oil company warned of a net loss of US$230 million for the second quarter due to "challenging operating conditions" in its oilseeds and grains, and sugar manufacturing segments. The company cited untimely raw material purchases, flooding in Argentina, and volatile futures markets as contributing factors. Despite expecting a loss, Wilmar remains expected to be profitable for the six months ended June 30, 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asahi says settles court battle with Suntory over zero-alcohol beer patent
summary: Asahi Group Holdings Ltd has settled a dispute with Suntory Holdings Ltd over a patent for non-alcohol beer. The Tokyo District Court had previously rejected Suntory's request for an injunction to stop Asahi from selling Dry Zero beer, and Suntory has withdrawn its appeal. Asahi will continue to make and sell Dry Zero beer, while the terms of the settlement remain undisclosed. This settlement comes as Japan's zero-alcohol beer segment remains competitive, with Asahi surpassing Suntory as the top seller of no-alcohol brews last year.

site_title: Singapore companies still keen to send employees for WSQ training: survey
summary: Singapore companies remain committed to WSQ training, with over 97% of companies indicating they will continue sending employees, a 1.7% increase from the previous year. However, the survey found that the training had a lower positive impact on business performance, with only 55% of companies reporting increased productivity. Trainees also reported lower career advancement and promotion outcomes, with 8% experiencing a promotion and 11% a pay increment, down from the previous year. The Workforce Development Agency attributes these findings to weak economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: NZ dollar still under pressure, Aussie slips on rate cut talk
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell 0.2% to US$0.7040, marking its sixth consecutive decline, amid speculation of a potential rate cut as early as August. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand proposed new mortgage lending restrictions to cool house prices. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar surged 3% against the kiwi since nearing parity in early July. The kiwi dollar's decline added to pressure on the NZ dollar, which remains under pressure.

site_title: US dollar underpinned by strong US data, BOJ easing hopes
summary: The US dollar remains strong against a basket of currencies, holding near four-month highs, due to strong US housing data and rising expectations of Bank of Japan easing. The US dollar edged down 0.2% against the yen to 105.96 yen, but still above its recent low. Speculators are unwinding their safe-haven bids in the yen as the BOJ is expected to take additional easing steps, potentially including a combination of measures. The US dollar index remains steady at 97.068, with investors expecting a US interest rate hike in December.

site_title: Hong Kong election candidates must issue China pledge by law: electoral commission
summary: Hong Kong's Electoral Affairs Commission requires candidates in September's legislative council elections to pledge that the city is an "inalienable" part of China. Advocating independence could end a candidate's eligibility. Those making a false declaration are liable to criminal sanction. The Hong Kong government also considers promoting independence "contrary" to the pledge, sparking anger among pro-democracy and independence activists.

site_title: Government accepts recommendations to enhance Singapore's debt-restructuring framework
summary: The Ministry of Law in Singapore has accepted 17 recommendations to enhance the country's debt-restructuring framework. The recommendations focus on creating a bespoke legal framework, deepening the bench with specialist insolvency judges, and increasing the use of Alternative Dispute Resolution processes. This move aims to improve Singapore's effectiveness in facilitating international debt restructuring, following a significant increase in insolvency and debt-restructuring work for regional law firms.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Export curbs 'in line with WTO rules': China
summary: China defended its export curbs as "in line with WTO rules" after the European Union and the US lodged complaints at the World Trade Organization. The curbs, imposed on 11 key materials including graphite and cobalt, were meant to protect the environment. The US and EU claim China's export duties favor local companies, putting pressure on non-Chinese manufacturers to shift production. China will handle the case following WTO dispute settlement procedures, and the EU is set to review trade links with China ahead of a December deadline.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CCT, Keppel Reit, Wilmar, Qian Hu
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.20 cents DPU for the second quarter, while Keppel Reit's distribution per unit dropped to 1.61 cents due to the sale of a Sydney commercial building. Wilmar International expects a net loss of US$230 million for its fiscal second quarter, while Qian Hu Corporation's net profit rose 25% to S$15,000. Despite lower net property income, Keppel Reit's property income and net property income remained stable excluding the sale of the Sydney building.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Yuan rises most in a month as PBOC fixing seen backing currency
summary: China's central bank strengthened the yuan's daily reference rate, limiting onshore moves to 2% on either side, amid speculation that authorities are preventing the currency from weakening beyond 6.7 against the dollar. The yuan rose 0.21% to 6.6831 per dollar, its largest monthly gain in over a month. Experts believe the central bank is defending the 6.70 level to manage market expectations and prevent speculative trades. The move is seen as a sign that China is taking steps to prevent the yuan from depreciating beyond a key level.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.410 points to 1669.140. Volume was 62.11 million lots worth RM15.97 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 48.

site_title: Australia: Shares resume rally but New Zealand stocks edge lower
summary: Australian shares regained momentum, led by financial stocks, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.4% to 5,472.8. Despite a slowdown in Wall Street gains, healthcare and IT stocks surged, while financials like QBE and the big four banks rose. New Zealand stocks, however, edged lower, falling 0.2% to 7,143.01, after a mixed night on Wall Street.

site_title: China Film plans biggest IPO in country's entertainment industry
summary: China Film Co, the nation's largest movie distributor, plans a 4.09 billion yuan (S$828 million) initial public offering on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. The company will offer 467 million shares to fund movie production and cinema investments, aiming to fuel expansion in China's estimated $180 billion media and entertainment industry. The IPO, valued at $828 million, would be the largest in the country's entertainment industry, surpassing a 2014 Hong Kong share sale by Haichang Ocean Park Holdings Ltd.

images.alt_text: China Film Co, the nation's largest movie distributor, is planning a 4.09 billion yuan (S$828 million) initial public offering in what would be the biggest IPO in the country's entertainment industry.

site_title: Gold holds gain as investors weigh outlook for global economy
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,332.95 per ounce amid concerns over a worsening global economy. The International Monetary Fund scrapped its growth forecast, citing Brexit. Despite US data improving, traders still expect less than even odds of a Federal Reserve rate increase until mid-2017. Gold has rallied 26% this year as investors seek haven assets amidst market volatility.

site_title: Indian Muslim women defy tradition - and men - to be judges
summary: An Indian Muslim women's rights organisation, Bharatiya Muslim Mahila Andolan (BMMA), is training its first 30 women to be qazis, or judges, a traditionally male role in India. The programme aims to produce a steady stream of female qazis, who can help prevent child marriage, ensure willing marriages, and fair divorce terms. The move comes amid growing dissent against laws discriminating against Muslim women, with over 90% of Muslim women wanting to end the "triple talaq" divorce tradition and polygamy.

site_title: China backs Philippine's controversial drug war
summary: China has expressed support for the Philippines' controversial drug war led by President Rodrigo Duterte, which has been criticized for extrajudicial killings and vigilante justice. China's embassy stated that the country is willing to work with the Philippine government to crack down on drug-related crimes, and a specific plan of action is to be discussed. This move has been met with criticism from rights groups, but China's support is seen as a significant boost to the Philippine government's efforts.

images.alt_text: China has offered its support to the Philippine's controversial drug crackdown pushed by new President Rodrigo Duterte, which has been slammed by rights groups for encouraging extrajudicial killings and vigilante justice.

site_title: Palm reserves in Indonesia seen shrinking on exports
summary: Palm oil reserves in Indonesia likely declined 3.1% to 1.9 million metric tons in June due to rising exports and stagnant production. This decrease may help stabilize prices, which have fallen 7.3% this year. Indonesia is the world's largest producer of palm oil, and a decline in stockpiles could further exacerbate losses as production increases seasonally. Analysts predict output may recover in September, but inventories could plummet to 1.5 million tons by August if production doesn't pick up.

site_title: US oil prices sink to two-month low
summary: US oil prices dropped to a two-month low of $44.65 a barrel on July 19, 2016, after the IMF lowered its global growth forecasts due to the UK's Brexit vote. This reduction in demand is expected to dampen crude oil prices. The IMF now forecasts a 3.1% global growth rate, lower than its April estimate.

site_title: Thai junta offers million baht raffle to bring tax returns online
summary: Thailand's junta has launched an e-payment scheme to boost tax revenues, with a nationwide lucky draw offering a million baht to those who use the system. The goal is to bring the massive informal economy into the books, with estimated annual tax revenue gains of 100 billion baht (S$3.9 billion). The scheme aims to save 75 billion baht a year for banks and businesses, but may take time for businesses to change their habits.

site_title: IE Singapore, SMF tie up to get local food manufacturers in S-E Asian supermarkets
summary: IE Singapore and the Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) have partnered under the Working In Partnership (WIP) programme to help local food manufacturers sell their products in South-east Asian supermarkets. This comes as the region's emerging middle class increases demand for variety and quality products. The partnership aims to overcome high entry costs and registration difficulties, providing local manufacturers with networks and financial resources to promote their products. The partnership is expected to fast-track the entry of Singapore food manufacturers into the markets, increasing their access to the Asian market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump will seek new law to sack Obama appointees if he wins presidency
summary: Donald Trump's ally, Chris Christie, revealed that if Trump wins the presidency, he plans to purge the federal government of officials appointed by Obama. Christie stated that Trump's campaign is drawing up a list of employees to fire and could ask Congress to pass legislation making it easier to fire public workers. This move is seen as a way to reduce the number of Obama appointees in the government, potentially leading to a significant shake-up in the federal administration.

site_title: Chesapeake sued for allegedly rigging bids on US oil, natural gas leases
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp and former SandRidge Energy Corp CEO Tom Ward are being sued by investors for allegedly rigging bids on US oil and natural gas leases, resulting in losses of over $10 million. The alleged conspiracy began in 2007 and continued until 2012. The lawsuit claims Chesapeake and SandRidge conspired to depress market prices for leases, with some speculating that Aubrey McClendon, a former Chesapeake executive, was involved. The case was filed in federal court in Kansas and seeks treble damages from the court.

images.alt_text: On March 1, 2016, Aubrey McClendon, a former executive of Chesapeake, was indicted along with other unnamed co-conspirators, on federal charges of bid-rigging. Mr McClendon died in a car accident on March 2.

site_title: Taiwan lawmakers, fishermen protest at disputed island
summary: Taiwanese lawmakers and fishermen are protesting at the disputed Taiping island in the South China Sea, citing an international tribunal ruling that undermines Taipei's claims. Eight lawmakers and five fishing boats are set to arrive at the island over the next five days, amid concerns over livelihoods. The protest is in response to the tribunal's decision, which has been seen as a setback for Taiwan's sovereignty claims.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares slide on dollar strength, IMF growth cut
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.3% to 1,139.3 against the US dollar, while shares slid due to the dollar's rise to a four-month high. The International Monetary Fund cut global growth forecasts, fueling risk-aversion and investor caution. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 0.2%, with most recently rallied stocks weakening. Investors await Thursday's European Central Bank meeting for clues on the won's direction.

site_title: Unilever buys razor-maker Dollar Shave Club
summary: Unilever has agreed to buy Dollar Shave Club, a US-based razor-maker, in a deal worth US$1 billion. The acquisition is expected to expand Unilever's men's grooming product catalogue. Dollar Shave Club founder Michael Dublin will remain CEO after the deal, which is expected to close in the third quarter of 2016. The deal comes as Unilever competes with other giants in the sector, including Procter & Gamble Co and Colgate-Palmolive Co.

images.alt_text: Unilever Plc said it has agreed to buy razor-maker Dollar Shave Club in a deal that would expand the consumer goods group's catalogue of men's grooming products.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks start day on a low
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks began trading on a low note on Wednesday, following broad losses in Europe and New York. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.12% to 21,646.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.06% to 3,034.71. The International Monetary Fund's cut to its global growth forecast citing EU exit worries contributed to the market downturn.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall with Korean won as crude oil holds below US$45
summary: Asian stocks fell, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.2%, as crude oil remained below $45 a barrel amid a worsening global economic outlook. South Korea's won weakened, while shares in Japan and South Korea declined. Investors are assessing corporate earnings, with Goldman Sachs and Microsoft reporting profits that beat analyst estimates. The rally is losing momentum, and investors are cautious, waiting for positive momentum from the reporting season.

site_title: Raffles Medical plans to spend S$1b to expand in Asia
summary: Raffles Medical Group plans to invest S$1 billion over the next three years to expand its healthcare presence in Asia, primarily in China, driven by an aging population and government reforms. The investment will be funded mostly through existing cash and may include debt. The group expects sales to grow organically at about 11% in the next few years, with China being a key target market. New hospitals are planned in Beijing and Shenzhen, while its Shanghai hospital is expected to be operational by end-2018.

site_title: Ringgit extends drop on risk appetite soft spot as stocks fall
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has suffered its biggest three-day loss in over two months, depreciating 0.6% to 4.0270 USD, amid a decline in emerging-market assets due to a stronger US dollar. The International Monetary Fund's reduced world growth forecast has contributed to the decline, as well as a failed coup in Turkey and lower oil prices. Malaysian inflation data on Wednesday may support another rate cut in the coming months, exacerbating the region's soft spot in risk appetite.

site_title: Noble said to wind down European power, gas on liquidity crunch
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodities firm, plans to quit European power and natural gas trading by the end of the year due to a liquidity crunch. The company, which has endured a turbulent year amid declining commodity prices, will retain its liquefied natural gas trading desk and continue trading US power and gas. Noble has already lost its investment-grade credit rating and faces allegations of improper accounting, prompting CEO Yusuf Alireza's departure in May. The move follows a series of high-profile departures, including the global head of power and gas trading.

site_title: Obama vows to 'do more' to protect police after fatal shootings
summary: President Barack Obama has vowed to "do more" to protect police officers amid a series of deadly incidents, including the killing of three officers in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. He met with top federal law enforcement officials and published an open letter to US law enforcement seeking to counter criticism that he's indifferent to police concerns. Obama emphasized the need for trust between police and communities, promising to consult with police departments and Congress to provide additional support.

site_title: Singapore shares open 13.74 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 13.74 points, or 0.47%, to 2,933.28 on Wednesday, following a new record for the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The rally was driven by actively traded counters, including Wilmar International and Singtel. The gain was the fifth consecutive day for the STI, ahead of GDP data scheduled for release.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tokyo jolted by third quake in four days
summary: A 5.0 magnitude earthquake struck Tokyo and eastern Japan on July 20, 2016, marking the third quake in four days. The epicenter was located 44km east of Tokyo, with no reports of damage or casualties. Japan's strict building codes and enforcement have minimized damage from powerful tremors. This is the third quake to hit Tokyo this week, following a 4.8 magnitude quake on Tuesday and a 5.0 magnitude quake on Sunday.

site_title: Emissions-cheating claims reach back further in new lawsuits
summary: Volkswagen AG's diesel emissions cheating scandal allegedly began in 1999 and continued for over a decade, with the company perfecting its "defeat devices" to cheat emissions tests in Europe and the US. Former CEO Martin Winterkorn and top executives developed six generations of defeat devices, with the first used in Europe in 2004 and the US in 2008. The company's efforts to evade emissions laws were furthered by the destruction of evidence and failure to disclose discrepancies. New lawsuits filed by state officials claim the scandal may have cost billions of dollars and could result in hundreds of billions of dollars in penalties.

site_title: No retiree left behind: Japan turns to riskier DIY pensions
summary: Japan has introduced laws allowing most working-age individuals to join private defined-contribution retirement plans, similar to US IRAs, to address concerns about the government's ability to fund retirement. The move aims to encourage risk-averse savers to invest in higher-yield investments and boost the country's huge financial assets. With over 27 million people newly eligible to set up private pension accounts, the change has seen a surge in interest, with potential annual capital flows of up to $12.8 billion into the private-pension sector.

images.alt_text: Japan's government loosened laws on pensions in May, allowing almost all working-age Japanese to join private defined-contribution retirement plans - similar to individual retirement accounts (IRAs) in the United States that allow workers to make regular contributions to an investment fund with tax breaks.

site_title: Revenge of the nerds: 130,000 fans expected at Comic-Con
summary: Comic-Con International is expected to draw 130,000 fans to San Diego from Thursday to Sunday, featuring panels, screenings, and attractions. The convention, now America's largest pop culture event, has evolved from a small gathering of geeks in 1970 to a spectacle with big-name stars and high production values. However, piracy concerns have led to some studios pulling back from exclusive material, with 20th Century Fox opting not to participate. Despite this, the event is still expected to raise $140 million for the local economy and provide a platform for fans to connect with filmmakers and actors.

site_title: CCT's Q2 DPU inches up on higher distributions from joint ventures
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.20 Singapore cents distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2 FY2016, up slightly from the same period last year. The company's distribution to unitholders increased 1% to S$65.09 million, despite lower net property income due to higher distributions from joint ventures. Revenue and net property income also declined, with revenue down 2.2% and net property income down 4.5%.

images.alt_text: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) on Wednesday reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.20 Singapore cents for the second quarter of FY2016, up slightly from 2.19 cents a year ago.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Procurri sinks slightly on SGX debut
summary: Procurri Corporation, a technology firm, listed on the Singapore Exchange on July 20, 2016, at 54 Singapore cents, below its IPO price of 56 cents. The company received 1,796 valid applications for its public offer, with a subscription rate of 10.1 times, and 62 million new shares were fully subscribed by institutional and other investors. The overall offering was 1.9 times subscribed, with total application monies amounting to S$73.67 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Possible Zika outbreak detected in Florida
summary: Florida health officials are investigating a possible Zika outbreak in Miami-Dade County, where a case was reported that was not contracted while traveling. This suggests an outbreak may be underway, despite no local spread of the virus reported in the US. As of mid-July, 1,306 Zika cases have been reported in the continental US, with none being the result of local mosquito transmission. Zika prevention kits and repellent are available for pregnant women and the area being studied.

images.alt_text: Florida health officials said Tuesday they were investigating a possible case of Zika that was not contracted while traveling to a region affected by the mosquito-borne virus, suggesting an outbreak may be under way.

site_title: May, Merkel face Brexit red lines on UK premier's Berlin debut
summary: Theresa May, the UK's new prime minister, met with Angela Merkel in Berlin, where they discussed the UK's exit from the European Union. Merkel emphasized the need for the UK to trigger the EU's exit clause before negotiations can begin, while May has ruled out doing so this year. The two leaders are expected to focus on economic and trading relationships, with Merkel pushing for starting exit talks as soon as possible. The meeting is seen as a crucial step in establishing a working relationship between the UK and Europe's dominant political figure, with Merkel signaling that her "red lines" are clear.

site_title: Republicans formally nominate Trump for US presidency
summary: Donald Trump has formally secured the Republican nomination for the 2016 US presidential election after defeating 16 party rivals. He secured the majority of delegates needed to contest the November election with 1,237 delegates. Trump's son, Donald Trump Jr., announced his support, ensuring Trump's nomination. The convention also nominated Indiana Governor Mike Pence as Trump's vice-presidential running mate. The Republican convention, which began on Monday, aimed to present Trump as a job creator and a strong hand on security threats.

site_title: Bank of England must respond to Brexit shock: minister
summary: Britain's new finance minister Philip Hammond declared that the Bank of England must respond to the economic shock from Brexit by implementing monetary measures. The Bank of England kept interest rates steady, but signaled a possible August cut. The International Monetary Fund slashed its global economic forecasts, citing uncertainty from Brexit, and downgraded its growth forecasts for the British economy. Hammond emphasized that Britain remains open for business and determined to keep the country attractive for investors.

site_title: US readies suits to block large health mergers: source
summary: The US Justice Department is preparing to file antitrust lawsuits to block two major health industry mergers: Anthem's acquisition of Cigna and Aetna's purchase of Humana. Officials fear the consolidation would reduce the number of major health insurers from five to three, negatively impacting consumers. The lawsuits could be filed as early as this week or next, following Aetna's $37 billion purchase of Humana announced last year. The mergers would control approximately 33 million customers.

site_title: Twitter eases process for verified accounts
summary: Twitter is streamlining the process for creating verified accounts, a move expected to increase the number of users with a "blue badge" icon. The social network has launched an online application for verified accounts, allowing users to apply for recognition of public figures and organizations as authentic. This change aims to make it easier for users to find creators and influencers on the platform.

site_title: Europe: Shares dented by weak earnings outlooks, but Zalando soars
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, reaching a one-week low, due to weak earnings updates from Ericsson and AkzoNobel. Mobile telecoms gear maker Ericsson plummeted 5.6% after forecasting comparable sales declines for a third consecutive year. Dutch chemicals company AkzoNobel also fell 4.3% despite beating earnings forecasts. However, online fashion retailer Zalando surged 22% after raising its full-year profitability forecast. The IMF cut global growth forecasts, citing uncertainty from Brexit, and European banks were under pressure.

site_title: US: Dow edges to new record; weak Netflix hits Nasdaq
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record for the sixth consecutive day, closing at 18,559.01, while the S&P 500 lost 0.1% to 2,163.78. However, the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.4% to 5,036.37 due to disappointing earnings from Netflix.

site_title: Samsung Bioepis seeks Europe's nod for its Humira drug copy
summary: Samsung Bioepis, a South Korean biosimilars maker, is seeking European regulatory approval to sell its copy of AbbVie's Humira, a rheumatoid arthritis drug worth $14 billion in sales last year. The company's application was accepted by the European Medicines Agency and is expected to be first or second to market with its product. This move is seen as a new growth driver for Samsung Group, which hopes to diversify its earnings beyond the maturing smartphone industry. The biosimilar approval comes after Samsung Bioepis received regulatory approval for its copies of Enbrel and Remicade earlier this year.

site_title: iFashion acquires Dressabelle for S$7.5m
summary: iFashion Group, a Singapore-based online fashion retailer, acquired Dressabelle for S$7.5 million, its largest deal to date. Dressabelle, a homegrown online fashion store, will join iFashion's stable of online fashion startups and benefit from support in expanding its overseas operations in Malaysia and Indonesia. The deal aims to enhance Dressabelle's functions and provide online shoppers with more frequent collection launches and collaborations with other brands. iFashion is targeting an initial public offering on the Australian Securities Exchange by the end of the year.

site_title: North Korea says missile tests simulated nuclear strike on South
summary: North Korea conducted three missile tests, including nuclear simulations on US targets in South Korea, in response to the planned deployment of a US missile defense system. The tests, violating UN resolutions, were ordered and monitored by Supreme Leader Kim Jong-Un. The US, Japan, and South Korea condemned the launch, vowing a collective diplomatic response. The incident heightened tensions between the US and North Korea, with the latter's actions seen as an angry reaction to the US military buildup.

site_title: US dollar higher amid talk of more easing from ECB, BOE
summary: The US dollar rose against the pound and euro amid speculation of further easing from the Bank of England and the European Central Bank. The Bank of England's new finance minister, Philip Hammond, urged the bank to respond to the Brexit shock with a monetary response. The pound fell 1.1% against the dollar, while the euro slipped to a four-year low against the dollar. Analysts expect the ECB to hold fire on monetary policy but prepare for more stimulus measures in September, supporting the dollar's outperformance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's earnings season is expected to have more misses than beats, with potential downgrades for Keppel Corp and Raffles Medical Group due to weaker earnings. DBS may beat expectations with treasury activities and fees from Manulife life bancassurance. OCBC could benefit from accounting profit from non-par fund gains on bond price recovery. SMRT is under review for a potential buyout, and DeClout Limited is overweight due to its potential harvest of Acclivis.

images.alt_text: According to news reports, Temasek is said to be weighing the option of taking SMRT private.

site_title: Microsoft delivers earnings surprise, stock rises
summary: Microsoft reported a profit of $3.1 billion in its fourth fiscal quarter, surpassing forecasts and sparking a 3% gain in stock. The tech giant's revenue dipped to $20.6 billion from $22.2 billion a year ago. Microsoft's "Productivity and Business Processes" unit saw a boost in revenue, while its "Intelligent Cloud" operations grew driven by Azure. The company's "More Personal Computing" division saw a decline in revenue, while Surface tablets saw a 9% revenue gain. Microsoft is shifting its focus to services and cloud computing.

site_title: Furnishing with care
summary: The Furniture Mall, run by the Singapore Furniture Association (SFA), has adapted to the retail industry's challenges, including the rise of e-commerce and online shopping. The mall's unique set-up allows tenants to pool resources for joint promotions and marketing campaigns, resulting in cost savings. To combat online competition, The Furniture Mall uses social media and has an active Facebook page to engage with customers. The mall also has a mediation service to resolve customer-seller disputes amicably. SFA plans to open a second mall with a different concept, aiming to become a one-stop service provider by forming an alliance with various trade associations and suppliers.

site_title: Yahoo reports dull results as sale of search business looms
summary: Yahoo's quarterly earnings fell short of analysts' expectations, with adjusted earnings of 9 US cents per share and a net loss of $439.9 million. The company reported a writedown of $482 million on Tumblr, acquired in 2013 for $1.1 billion. Yahoo's search business continues to decline, with gross search revenue down 17% from the same period last year. The company is auctioning off its search and advertising business, with Verizon, AT&T, and private equity firm TPG Capital among potential buyers.

site_title: Surbana Jurong to set up Sri Lanka consultancy
summary: Surbana Jurong has signed a memorandum of understanding with Sri Lanka's investment promotion agency to set up a technical consultancy services company. The company will provide professional services for urbanisation and infrastructure projects in Sri Lanka and overseas, aiming to accelerate project identification, planning, and implementation. This joint initiative will give Sri Lankan professionals opportunities to develop cutting-edge management tools and support Surbana Jurong's consultancy works globally, strengthening Sri Lanka's position as an attractive investment destination.

site_title: Asia's wealthy should look towards lifestyle preservation
summary: Asia's wealthy individuals are underprepared for a longer retirement, with many neglecting to plan ahead for lifestyle preservation. A UBS survey found that affluent investors in the US, UK, Germany, Singapore, and Hong Kong are not adequately preparing for retirement, with many relying on a single pot of savings and ignoring the need for multiple sources of passive income. However, first-generation entrepreneurs in Asia tend to have a different mindset, with some setting up new businesses upon retirement and prioritizing legacy and inheritance. Experts advise seeking objective advice from professionals to improve returns and provide peace of mind.

site_title: Follow Me Japan: A travel ambassador with a human touch
summary: Follow Me Japan, a travel agency specializing in high-end consumer market in Japan, aims to connect people from both countries through meaningful cultural exchange. Chairman Ven Nishimura, who has been in the industry for 35 years, prioritizes customer satisfaction and accountability, showcasing his commitment through numerous accolades. After starting his business in 1979, Nishimura overcame obstacles to pioneer a travel agency that provides quality service with a human touch, exemplified by his willingness to help a customer afford a trip to see her ailing mother.

images.alt_text: 'Money is not as important as trust. One should try to do something meaningful and make a difference in someone's life.' - Ven Nishimura, Follow Me Japan chairman

site_title: More defensive allocation as political risks rise
summary: Markets have seen a shift towards more defensive allocation as political risks rise, particularly following the UK Brexit referendum. Despite this, the global economy remains stable, with the US economy supporting domestic consumption and global growth. Investors are advised to be cautious, with Europe and Japan being underweight due to increased market volatility and political uncertainties. Asia Ex-Japan equities remain resilient, but valuations are not yet attractive. The focus is on cyclical names, particularly consumer discretionary, healthcare, and technology, and investing in innovation to generate alpha returns.

site_title: Steering OCBC through a complex world
summary: OCBC Bank, winner of the Best Managed Board (Large-Cap) award, is navigating a complex environment by fostering a culture of openness and debate among its board members. Chairman Ooi Sang Kuang emphasizes the importance of considering trade-offs in decisions and seeking collective insight to achieve good and sound decision-making. The bank is also focusing on empathy for clients struggling in a volatile market, including those affected by the oil price plunge, and extending this empathy to society at large for long-term sustainability.

site_title: French PM warns there will be more deadly attacks
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned that France must prepare for more deadly attacks, stating that the country must "learn to live with the threat." The warning comes after 84 people were killed in the Bastille Day massacre in Nice, and President Francois Hollande announced a possible extension of the state of emergency for six months. Suspected Islamist Reda Kriket was planning to target the Euro 2016 football tournament, and investigators found evidence of jihadist activity on the attacker's computer. The attack has hit tourism hard, with hotel cancellation rates reaching 20-40% in the affected area.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned on Tuesday that the country must be prepared for more deadly attacks and will have to "learn to live with the threat".

site_title: Transforming private wealth management
summary: The private wealth management industry is slowly adopting fintech innovations, primarily through algorithms and data-driven platforms known as Robo-Advisories. While these services have primarily targeted mass-market investors, there is a growing presence in Asia. To innovate and respond to fintech, private wealth companies should focus on client needs, collaborating with fintech to develop technology solutions that cater to these needs. This requires a shift in mindset, with wealth managers upskilling to handle new technologies and hiring non-traditional talent. Ultimately, fintech is a tool to enhance private wealth management, and understanding people's needs and goals is key to its success.

site_title: Rate-starved US banks happily gobble up mortgage business
summary: US banks have seen a surge in mortgage business as mortgage rates dropped to historic lows after the Federal Reserve dashed expectations for near-term rate hikes. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup originated $94 billion in new mortgages in the second quarter, a 31% increase from the first quarter. The banks predict the trend will continue, with JPMorgan expecting $1.8 trillion in mortgage loans this year. However, low rates and rising costs of funding pose challenges to generating substantial income for banks.

site_title: STI weakens in line with HK, Dow futures
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore ended with a 9.22-point loss on July 19, 2016, at 2,919.54, following losses in Hong Kong and Dow futures. The index had previously bounced 193 points in 15 trading sessions since the June 23 Brexit referendum. Strong support was seen for Jardine Cycle & Carriage, which rose S$1.03 to S$37. Market sentiment was influenced by concerns over China's growth and the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, with Morgan Stanley warning of downside risks.

site_title: Centurion thrives on the human touch, says CEO
summary: Centurion Corporation's CEO, Kong Chee Min, emphasizes the importance of staff happiness in the company's business success, citing an average employee tenure of over 20 years. The company's accommodation business, which serves foreign workers and students, is driven by a culture of collaboration and respect. Despite the transition from optical disk manufacturing, Centurion has thrived, with staff loyalty fueled by a sense of community and fair treatment. The company's expansion into student accommodation in Australia and the UK has also contributed to its growth.

site_title: Pressure on military research bound to increase in Japan
summary: Japan is set to increase pressure on military research, driven by its ambitions to become a techno-industrial superpower and reposition itself in global value chains. The Cross-ministerial Strategic Innovation Promotion Program (SIP) aims to develop 10 sectors of industrial and technological excellence, including artificial intelligence, robotics, and ocean resource exploitation. SIP's efforts are expected to be influenced by Japan's changing stance on national security, which may lead to increased military research and potential "spin-offs" for civilian applications.

site_title: Tharman optimistic about future of Chinese economy
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam expressed optimism about China's economic future, stating that while its economy won't crash, it won't grow at its past pace. He emphasized the importance of China transitioning to a more market-based, innovative, and inclusive economy. This sentiment comes as China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US farmers hit the sweet potato spot
summary: US farmers are experiencing a surge in demand for sweet potatoes, with shipments doubling in five years and reaching an all-time high. The tuber has become a popular, healthier alternative to white potatoes, with more fibre and fewer calories. Americans are eating twice as many sweet potatoes as they did in 2005, and the trend is also seen in Europe. Nutritionists attribute the growth in demand to consumers seeking fewer grains and processed foods, as sweet potatoes offer a nutritious and versatile option.

site_title: Philippines rejects China's terms for South China Sea talks
summary: The Philippines has rejected China's terms for talks on their South China Sea dispute, citing Beijing's request to disregard a UN-backed tribunal ruling. China had asked Manila to disregard the ruling, which found no legal basis for China's claims to most of the strategic waters. The ruling also stated that China had violated the Philippines' sovereign rights to exploit resources in waters beyond its coast. The Philippines' foreign minister, Perfecto Yasay, stated that direct talks with China were unlikely due to Beijing's refusal to accept the ruling, and the country will instead focus on managing the situation to regain access to the Scarborough Shoal for Filipino fishermen.

site_title: FCL CEO adept at tackling property market challenges
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) CEO Lim Ee Seng has demonstrated his ability to navigate the challenges of the Singapore residential market and overseas markets. In 2004, FCL successfully disposed of over 1,300 unsold units by offering moderate price discounts and incentives. Lim warns that a price cut of 30% or more could lead to a ripple effect in the industry. He expects the current oversupply of residential units to persist unless cooling measures are eased. FCL has diversified into overseas markets, with overseas contributions now making up over half of its operating profit, and has set a wider margin buffer to minimize risks.

site_title: Hard disk and software failure root cause of SGX outage: CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) experienced its longest trading halt in history due to a combination of a hard disk failure and a software application that failed to detect the problem. The disruption, which lasted for several hours, was prolonged by challenges in the orders and trade reconciliation process. SGX's CEO, Loh Boon Chye, attributed the outage to a faulty disk supplied by HP and a software application from Nasdaq that failed to automatically switch to a backup system. The exchange is working to review the application and implement necessary changes to prevent similar disruptions in the future.

site_title: IMF downgrades global outlook on Brexit vote
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its global economic outlook due to the UK's Brexit vote, citing increased economic, political, and institutional uncertainty. The IMF has reduced its global growth forecasts for 2016 and 2017 by 0.1 percentage points, to 3.1% and 3.4% respectively. The impact on advanced European economies, particularly the UK, is expected to be significant, while the US and China are expected to be less affected. The IMF warns that a material slowdown in the European Union's growth could have a significant impact on China, and policymakers must work to reduce post-Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Investor presses Nintendo for strategy change
summary: A Nintendo investor, Seth Fischer, is pressing the company for a strategy change after the success of Pokémon Go, a mobile game that has increased Nintendo's market value by $17 billion. Fischer, a vocal advocate for Nintendo to develop and sell games for mobile platforms, believes the company can capitalize on its popular characters and generate significant revenue through licensing. He estimates Nintendo could earn $30-60 billion annually from mobile gaming. Despite Nintendo's previous caution, Fischer hopes the company will shift its focus to monetizing its mobile gaming patents.

site_title: Keppel and CapitaLand groups sweep corporate governance 'Oscars'
summary: The 11th Singapore Corporate Awards, also known as the "Oscars" for Singapore-listed companies, honored top corporate governance practices at a ceremony in Resorts World Sentosa. Keppel group swept five awards, while CapitaLand secured three. OCBC and Singtel won gold for Best Managed Board in the large-cap category, and Frasers Centrepoint Ltd's Lim Ee Seng won Best CEO award for large-caps. Other winners included Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation, Keppel Reit, and CapitaLand Retail China Trust. The awards recognized excellence in investor relations, annual reports, and corporate governance practices.

site_title: Exodus of professional workers reshaping Qatar
summary: Qatar is experiencing an exodus of professional workers, with many leaving due to layoffs in the wake of a fall in energy prices. Businesses, competing for the dwindling middle class, are cutting costs, affecting expats and locals alike. A restaurateur, Samer Habib, notes that customers are saying it's their last visit, highlighting the tough economic conditions. This exodus may weigh on Qatar's economy, as the country struggles to maintain its business environment and attract new talent.

site_title: A strong business case for sustainability
summary: CDL CEO Grant Kelley emphasizes that sustainability is no longer a secondary consideration for businesses, but a necessary aspect of their operations. The company's strong ESG initiatives have created stronger brand equity and product differentiation, and have helped reduce its carbon footprint. Kelley expects that in five years, businesses will be held accountable for their carbon footprint, and that good ESG performance will enhance a company's reputation and contribute to its bottom line. CDL's sustainable development strategy has been recognized globally, with the company being listed on three leading sustainability benchmarks.

site_title: Going for gas
summary: A coalition of 14 major shipping companies, including Carnival Corporation and Shell, has formed the SEA\LNG initiative to promote the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a marine fuel. The group aims to address market barriers and help transform LNG into a global reality, with the goal of achieving a 10% market share by 2030. However, critics argue that the initiative is more "political" and that LNG infrastructure and investment are needed to support its growth, rather than relying on public funding.

site_title: Thinking out of the box
summary: This article highlights three Singaporean SMEs - Tee Yih Jia, ASA Holidays, and The Furniture Mall - that are innovating to stay ahead in the rapidly changing market conditions. Tee Yih Jia is a food manufacturer introducing frozen crystal skin for Chinese shrimp dumplings, while ASA Holidays is adapting to the disruption caused by the Internet in the travel industry. The Furniture Mall is also adapting its strategies to compete with e-commerce and plans to open a second mall with a unique concept. These SMEs demonstrate the enterprising spirit and resilience of Singaporean businesses, with OCBC Bank supporting the efforts to recognize and honor their contributions to the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Honda audit finds Takata engineers manipulated air-bag data
summary: Honda's audit of air-bag supplier Takata Corp has found evidence of data manipulation and misrepresentation, including the removal of test results to artificially reduce variability in air-bag inflator performance. Former Insurance Institute for Highway Safety president Brian O'Neill stated that engineers selectively edited results to make them appear better. The findings could complicate Takata's efforts to restructure and secure buyers, as the company faces costs of recalls that may exceed 100 million air bags worldwide.

images.alt_text: Findings of pervasive data manipulation and misrepresentations to carmakers could complicate Takata's efforts to restructure and secure potential buyers following the car industry's biggest safety crisis.

site_title: CFOs have to be on top of rapid changes
summary: Three Best CFO award winners discuss the current challenges and new requirements of their field. CFOs must adapt to rapid changes, including sustainability reporting and integrated reporting, in a turbulent business landscape. They must balance financial strategy with overall business strategy, take on risk management and business development roles, and maintain professionalism while advising executives. The CFOs advise new CFOs to be prepared to take on multiple roles, prioritize integrity and compliance, and weigh the costs of sustainability reporting against business costs. They also emphasize the importance of adapting to changing business landscapes and embracing new opportunities.

site_title: Brexit a symptom of how global business has been operating
summary: The UK's exit from the European Union, or Brexit, is a symptom of a larger issue: the pursuit of economic efficiency and profit at the expense of workers and communities. As businesses seek to minimize costs by outsourcing and relocating production, they create a ripple effect of job losses, economic instability, and social inequality. To mitigate this, countries must adopt a more holistic approach to business, incorporating social and environmental responsibility into their economic frameworks. This can be achieved through corporate sustainability, equal opportunity policies, and effective governance, ultimately prioritizing the well-being of citizens over the pursuit of profit.

site_title: Finding the right balance
summary: The 2016 Singapore Corporate Awards recognized the importance of good corporate governance in navigating transformation. Winners emphasized a culture of effective engagement, diversity, sustainability, and timely communication with investors. The prestigious Best Managed Board prize saw two gold winners in the large-cap category, OCBC and Singtel, while the Best CEO award went to Frasers Centrepoint Limited's Lim Ee Seng, a developer. The awards highlighted the need for a balanced approach to change, with winners citing robust controls and leadership as key to success.

site_title: Singapore to KL in 90 minutes: High-speed rail targets 2026 start date
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are set to sign a bilateral agreement on the high-speed rail linking the two cities, with trains expected to start running by 2026. The 350km journey is expected to take 90 minutes, connecting Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. The project, which has been in the works for years, aims to boost economic ties between the two countries and provide a faster alternative to flying. A memorandum of understanding was signed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, marking a significant step towards the project's completion.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee and Mr Najib witness the signing of the MOU by Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan and Malaysia's Minister in the Prime Minister's Department Abdul Rahman Dahlan in Putrajaya on Tuesday.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Communication and transparency are vital
summary: Singapore-listed Reits are adjusting their communication strategies to meet the demands of sophisticated investors, who seek timely and quality information. Companies like CapitaLand Retail China Trust are engaging investors regularly, hosting mall tours and addressing concerns through various channels. Investors are becoming more vocal, providing feedback on management strategies and macroeconomic developments, highlighting the importance of transparency and communication in the industry. This shift in investor behavior is driving companies to adapt their communication approaches to better understand and address investor needs.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan says CRCT engages investors regularly to understand and address their concerns.
Mr Cerf stresses the importance of maintaining open and transparent communications with investors.

site_title: Consumption continues to shrink as Russians forego food, medicine
summary: Russia's consumer market continues to shrink, with average purchases falling 2% in the second quarter, marking the first decline since 2006. Retail sales dropped 5.4% in June, and real disposable incomes are expected to decline 5% in the same period. The crisis is decimating the middle class, with almost a third of Russians buying less food and 49% saving on medicine due to expensive treatments. The nation's largest supermarket chain, Magnit, has seen its sales drop 17% in 2016, as the government's response to falling oil prices has failed to boost consumer confidence.

site_title: Massive inventory hangover seen hurting oil market ahead
summary: Oil market faces a massive inventory hangover due to high fuel production and low demand, particularly in Europe and Asia. Despite peak summer driving, fuel inventories remain high, leading to the use of floating storage and on-shore storage limits. Analysts predict a sustained contango in diesel and petrol futures, making storing profitable, and a "massive inventory hangover" that could last for months. Crude oil prices may struggle to recover in the near term, with production tapering off and global oil stocks refusing to decrease.

site_title: Bar Russia from Rio Games: officials
summary: Russia's leading anti-doping officials have called for the country to be barred from the Rio Games following a damning report confirming government-ordered cheating at the 2014 Sochi Olympics. The report, led by Canadian lawyer Richard McLaren, found a state-run doping program was executed during the Sochi Games and beyond. Evidence included tampered urine samples, cocktails of performance-enhancing drugs, and a security badge for an intelligence service member. The International Olympic Committee is set to discuss "provisional measures and sanctions" against Russia, with President Vladimir Putin refusing to rule out a ban.

site_title: Power of testimonies drives business growth
summary: Bee Choo Origin, a Singapore-based herbal hair care company, has expanded its global presence to 11 countries, with 137 stores in 11 territories. The company's growth is attributed to the power of customer testimonials, which have enabled it to enter new markets without the need for extensive advertising. Founded by Cheah Bee Chew in 2000, the company has seen significant revenue and profit increases over the past five years, with plans to enter the US and Australia markets this year. The company's success is attributed to its effective products, affordability, and commitment to cultural sensitivity.

site_title: Pre-sales of London homes down 34% on Brexit woes
summary: London home sales under construction dropped 34% in the second quarter due to Brexit uncertainty, partly caused by higher taxes. Resale sales also declined 23% from the first quarter. Despite a record 5,655 homes completed in the quarter, demand remains weak. Analysts attribute the decline to reduced returns from landlords due to tax breaks and new lending rules, which may lead to a "major shock" in home values.

site_title: China needs new growth driver as urbanisation is reaching its limit
summary: China's 40-year urbanisation program is reaching its limits, with the country's population growth slowing and demographic changes posing significant challenges. The government plans to develop over 3,500 new urban areas, but these settlements are unlikely to be viable due to a decline in the working-age population and a rise in rural incomes. Instead, a more sustainable approach is needed, focusing on investing in basic urban amenities and reforming the hukou permit system to encourage workers to choose where to live.

site_title: Deskera to invest S$50m in Singapore data centre
summary: Deskera Holdings, a Singapore-based company, plans to invest S$50 million over three years to build a cloud data centre in Singapore. The location was chosen due to its security, talent availability, power quality, scalability, environmental and natural disaster impact. Singapore's status as a trans-Pacific cable landing point also contributed to the decision, allowing for faster transmission speeds. This investment aims to enhance the company's cloud capabilities and improve its operations.

site_title: Be adaptable, agile for investing success
summary: Investors must adapt to long-term structural drivers influencing investment returns, including economic growth, interest rates, inflation, corporate profits, geopolitical risk, and technological innovation. Over the last 50 years, global economic expansion has been fueled by population growth, productivity growth, and globalization. As younger workers in emerging markets replace aging populations in developed economies, it's essential to understand these trends to make informed investment decisions for sustainable returns.

site_title: Asian equities shine post-Brexit
summary: Asian equity markets have surged since the Brexit decision, with the MSCI AC Asia ex-Japan index rising 4% over two weeks. Despite uncertainty, investors are shifting to Asian equities for higher returns, as the region's growth is expected to continue at a faster pace than many economies globally. Asia's economies are more insulated from external shocks, driven by a growing services sector and a large population. With attractive dividend yields and low valuations, Asian equities offer an attractive alternative to other asset classes, particularly in a low-for-longer interest rate environment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Data Centres Holding has partnered with Quann, a managed security services provider, to offer a range of cyber-security solutions to customers. The partnership will begin in August and provide consultancy, network protection, and incident response services. Some services will be available on a pay-as-you-use model, offering cost and operational efficiencies. Meanwhile, SPH has relaunched a new indoor digital advertising screen at 313@somerset with high-quality sound and a static wrap option.

site_title: Opportunities amid market dislocations
summary: The UK's vote to leave the European Union has created uncertainty, with a two-year negotiation period expected to follow. The impact on the UK will be negative, with consumer and business spending slowing, while firms with international exposure may demonstrate greater resilience. The broader implications include potential referendums in Scotland and Northern Ireland, and a relatively more significant impact on Europe than the global economy. Global monetary policy is expected to remain accommodative, with emerging market currencies potentially strengthening in the long term.

site_title: KL-S'pore High Speed Rail
summary: The KL-S'pore High Speed Rail project remains unmentioned. Vietnam reacts to US tariffs, bracing for a higher impact on the Asian garment industry.
